Download free eBooks of classic literature , books and novels at Planet eBook . Subscribe to [our]312-our free eBooks blog and email newsletter . 1984 By [George Orwell]124-george orwell

1984 Part One

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Chapter 1 [I]0-the la - dle t was a bright cold day in April , and the clocks were strik - ing thirteen . [Winston Smith]132-winston , [his]132-winston chin nuzzled into [his]132-winston breast in an effort to escape the vile wind , slipped quickly through the glass doors of [Victory Mansions]1-victory mansions , though not quickly enough to prevent a swirl of gritty dust from enter - ing along with [him]132-winston . The hallway smelt of boiled cabbage and old rag mats . At one end of it a coloured poster , too large for indoor display , had been tacked to the wall . It depicted simply an enor - mous face , more than a metre wide : the face of [a man of about forty - five , with a heavy black moustache and rugged - ly handsome features]313-a man of about forty - five , with a heavy black moustache and rugged - ly handsome features . [Winston]132-winston made for [the stairs]314-the stairs . It was no use trying the lift . Even at the best of times it was sel - dom working , and at present the electric current was cut off during daylight hours . It was part of the economy drive in preparation for Hate Week . [The flat]315-the flat was seven flights up , and [Winston]132-winston , who was thirty - nine and had a varicose ulcer above [his]132-winston right ankle , went slowly , resting several times on the way . On each landing , opposite the lift - shaft , the poster with the enormous face gazed from the wall . It was one of those pictures which are so contrived that the eyes follow [you]316-you about when [you]316-you move . [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother IS WATCHING [YOU]316-you , the caption beneath it ran . Inside the flat a fruity voice was reading out a list of fig -

19844 ures which had something to do with the production of pig - iron . The voice came from an oblong metal plaque like a dulled mirror which formed part of the surface of the right - hand wall . [Winston]132-winston turned a switch and the voice sank somewhat , though the words were still distinguish - able . The instrument ( the telescreen , it was called ) could be dimmed , but there was no way of shutting it off complete - ly . [He]132-winston moved over to the window : [a smallish , frail figure]317-a smallish , frail figure , the meagreness of [his]132-winston body merely emphasized by the blue overalls which were the uniform of the party . [His]132-winston hair was very fair , [his]132-winston face naturally sanguine , [his]132-winston skin roughened by coarse soap and blunt razor blades and the cold of the win - ter that had just ended . Outside , even through the shut window - pane , [the world]318-the world looked cold . Down in [the street]319-the street little eddies of wind were whirling dust and torn paper into spirals , and though the sun was shining and the sky a harsh blue , there seemed to be no colour in anything , except the posters that were plastered everywhere . The blackmoustachio’d face gazed down from [every commanding corner]320-every commanding corner . There was one on [the house]321-the house - front immediately opposite . [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother IS WATCHING [YOU]316-you , [the caption]322-the caption said , while the dark eyes looked deep into [Winston]132-winston ’s own . Down at street level an - other poster , torn at one corner , flapped fitfully in the wind , alternately covering and uncovering the single word IN - GSOC . In the far distance [a helicopter]323-a helicopter skimmed down between the roofs , hovered for an instant like a bluebottle , and darted away again with a curving flight . It was the po - lice patrol , snooping into [people]324-people ’s windows . [The patrols]325-the patrols did

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com not matter , however . Only the Thought Police mattered . Behind [Winston]132-winston ’s back the voice from the telescreen was still babbling away about pig - iron and the overfulfilment of the Ninth Three - Year Plan . The telescreen received and transmitted simultaneously . Any sound that [Winston]132-winston made , above the level of a very low whisper , would be picked up by it , moreover , so long as [he]132-winston remained within the field of vi - sion which the metal plaque commanded , [he]132-winston could be seen as well as heard . There was of course no way of knowing whether [you]326-you were being watched at any given moment . How often , or on what system , the Thought Police plugged in on any individual wire was guesswork . It was even conceivable that [they]327-they watched [everybody]328-everybody all the time . But at any rate [they]327-they could plug in [your]326-you wire whenever [they]327-they wanted to . [You]326-you had to live — did live , from habit that became instinct — in the assumption that every sound [you]326-you made was overheard , and , except in darkness , every movement scrutinized . [Winston]132-winston kept [his]132-winston back turned to the telescreen . It was safer , though , as [he]132-winston well knew , even a back can be revealing . A kilometre away [the Ministry of Truth]329-the ministry of truth , [his]132-winston place of work , towered vast and white above [the grimy landscape]330-the grimy landscape . This , [he]132-winston thought with a sort of vague distaste — this was [London]2-london , [chief city of [Airstrip One]3-airstrip one]331-chief city of airstrip one , itself [the third most populous of [the provinces of Oceania]333-the provinces of oceania]332-the third most populous of the provinces of oceania . [He]132-winston tried to squeeze out some childhood memory that should tell [him]132-winston whether [London]2-london had always been quite like this . Were there always these vis - tas of [rotting nineteenth - century houses]334-rotting nineteenth - century houses , [their]334-rotting nineteenth - century houses sides shored up with baulks of timber , [their]334-rotting nineteenth - century houses windows patched with card - board and [their]334-rotting nineteenth - century houses roofs with corrugated iron , [their]334-rotting nineteenth - century houses crazy

1984 garden walls sagging in all directions ? And the bombed sites where the plaster dust swirled in the air and the wil - low - herb straggled over the heaps of rubble ; and the places where the bombs had cleared a larger patch and there had sprung up sordid colonies of [wooden dwellings like [chick - en - houses]336-chick - en - houses]335-wooden dwellings like chick - en - houses ? But it was no use , [he]132-winston could not remember : nothing remained of [his]132-winston childhood except a series of bright- lit tableaux occurring against no background and mostly unintelligible . The Ministry of Truth — Minitrue , in [Newspeak]134-newspeak [ New - speak was the official language of [Oceania]5-oceania . For an account of its structure and etymology see Appendix.]—was star - tlingly different from any other object in sight . It was an enormous pyramidal structure of glittering white con - crete , soaring up , terrace after [terrace]337-terrace , 300 metres into the air . From where [Winston]132-winston stood it was just possible to read , picked out on [its]132-winston white face in elegant lettering , the three slogans of the Party : WAR IS PEACE FREEDOM IS SLAVERY IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH The Ministry of Truth contained , it was said , three thousand rooms above ground level , and corresponding ramifications below . Scattered about [London]2-london there were [just three other buildings of similar appearance and size]338-just three other buildings of similar appearance and size . So completely did [they]338-just three other buildings of similar appearance and size dwarf the surrounding architec - ture that from the roof of [Victory Mansions]1-victory mansions [you]339-you could see

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [all four of [them]338-just three other buildings of similar appearance and size]340-all four of them simultaneously . [They]338-just three other buildings of similar appearance and size were [the homes of [the four Ministries between which the entire apparatus of government]342-the four ministries between which the entire apparatus of government]341-the homes of the four ministries between which the entire apparatus of government was divided . The Ministry of Truth , which concerned itself with news , entertainment , education , and the fine arts . [The Ministry of Peace]6-the ministry of peace , which concerned itself with war . [The Ministry of Love , which maintained law and order]343-the ministry of love , which maintained law and order . And [the Ministry of Plenty , which was responsible for economic affairs]344-the ministry of plenty , which was responsible for economic affairs . [Their]344-the ministry of plenty , which was responsible for economic affairs names , in [Newspeak]134-newspeak : Minitrue , [Minipax]127-minipax , [Miniluv]128-miniluv , and [Miniplenty]129-miniplenty . [The Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love was the really frightening one . There were no windows in [it]345-the ministry of love at all . [Winston]132-winston had never been inside [the Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love , nor within half a kilometre of it . It was a place impossible to enter except on official business , and then only by penetrating through a maze of barbed- wire entanglements , steel doors , and hidden machine - gun nests . Even [the streets leading up to [its]347-the streets leading up to its outer barriers outer barriers]347-the streets leading up to its outer barriers were roamed by gorilla - faced guards in black uniforms , armed with jointed truncheons . [Winston]132-winston turned round abruptly . [He]132-winston had set [his]132-winston features into the expression of quiet optimism which it was advis - able to wear when facing the telescreen . [He]132-winston crossed [the room]348-the room into [the tiny kitchen]349-the tiny kitchen . By leaving [the Ministry]350-the ministry at this time of day [he]132-winston had sacrificed [his]132-winston lunch in [the canteen]351-the canteen , and [he]132-winston was aware that there was no food in [the kitchen]352-the kitchen except a hunk of dark - coloured bread which had got to be saved for tomorrow ’s breakfast . [He]132-winston took down from the shelf a bottle of colourless liquid with a plain white label marked [VICTORY GIN]130-victory gin . It gave off a sickly , oily smell , as of Chinese rice - spirit . [Winston]132-winston poured out nearly a teacupful , nerved

19848 [himself]132-winston for a shock , and gulped it down like a dose of medi - cine . Instantly [his]132-winston face turned scarlet and the water ran out of [his]132-winston eyes . The stuff was like nitric acid , and moreover , in swallowing it one had the sensation of being hit on the back of the head with a rubber club . The next moment , however , the burning in [his]132-winston belly died down and [the world]318-the world began to look more cheerful . [He]132-winston took a cigarette from a crumpled packet marked VICTORY CIGARETTES and incautiously held it upright , whereupon the tobacco fell out on to the floor . With the next [he]132-winston was more successful . [He]132-winston went back to [the living - room]354-the living - room and sat down at a small table that stood to the left of the telescreen . From the table drawer [he]132-winston took out a penholder , a bottle of ink , and a thick , quarto - sized blank book with a red back and a marbled cover . For some reason the telescreen in [the living - room]354-the living - room was in an unusual position . Instead of being placed , as was normal , in the end wall , where it could command [the whole room]356-the whole room , it was in the longer wall , opposite the window . To one side of [it]356-the whole room there was a shallow alcove in which [Winston]132-winston was now sitting , and which , when [the flats]357-the flats were built , had probably been intended to hold bookshelves . By sitting in [the alcove]358-the alcove , and keeping well back , [Winston]132-winston was able to remain outside the range of the telescreen , so far as sight went . [He]132-winston could be heard , of course , but so long as [he]132-winston stayed in [his]132-winston present position [he]132-winston could not be seen . It was partly the unusual ge - ography of [the room]348-the room that had suggested to [him]132-winston the thing that [he]132-winston was now about to do . But it had also been suggested by the book that [he]132-winston had

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com just taken out of the drawer . It was a peculiarly beautiful book . Its smooth creamy paper , a little yellowed by age , was of a kind that had not been manufactured for at least for - ty years past . [He]132-winston could guess , however , that the book was much older than that . [He]132-winston had seen it lying in the window of [a frowsy little junk - shop in [a slummy quarter of [the town]362-the town]361-a slummy quarter of the town]360-a frowsy little junk - shop in a slummy quarter of the town ( just what quarter [he]132-winston did not now remember ) and had been stricken immediately by an overwhelming desire to possess it . [Party members]363-party members were supposed not to go into [ordinary shops]364-ordinary shops ( ’ dealing on the free market ’[363-party members] , it was called ) , but the rule was not strictly kept , because there were various things , such as shoelaces and razor blades , which it was impossible to get hold of in any other way . [He]132-winston had given a quick glance up and down [the street]319-the street and then had slipped inside and bought the book for two dollars fifty . At the time [he]132-winston was not conscious of wanting it for any particular purpose . [He]132-winston had carried it guiltily [home]366-home in [his]132-winston briefcase . Even with nothing written in it , it was a compromising possession . The thing that [he]132-winston was about to do was to open a diary . This was not illegal ( nothing was illegal , since there were no longer any laws ) , but if detected it was reasonably certain that it would be punished by death , or at least by twenty- five years in [a forced - labour camp]367-a forced - labour camp . [Winston]132-winston fitted a nib into the penholder and sucked it to get the grease off . The pen was an archaic instrument , seldom used even for signatures , and [he]132-winston had procured one , furtively and with some difficulty , simply because of a feeling that the beautiful creamy paper deserved to be written on with a real nib instead of being scratched with an ink - pencil . Actually [he]132-winston was not used to

198410 writing by hand . Apart from very short notes , it was usu - al to dictate everything into the speak - write which was of course impossible for [his]132-winston present purpose . [He]132-winston dipped the pen into the ink and then faltered for just a second . A trem - or had gone through [his]132-winston bowels . To mark the paper was the decisive act . In small clumsy letters [he]132-winston wrote : April 4th , 1984 . [He]132-winston sat back . A sense of complete helplessness had de - scended upon [him]132-winston . To begin with , [he]132-winston did not know with any certainty that this was 1984 . It must be round about that date , since [he]132-winston was fairly sure that [his]132-winston age was thirty - nine , and [he]132-winston believed that [he]132-winston had been born in 1944 or 1945 ; but it was never possible nowadays to pin down any date within a year or two . For whom , it suddenly occurred to [him]132-winston to wonder , was [he]132-winston writing this diary ? For the future , for the unborn . [His]132-winston mind hovered for a moment round the doubtful date on the page , and then fetched up with a bump against the Newspeak word DOUBLETHINK . For the first time the magnitude of what [he]132-winston had undertaken came [home]366-home to [him]132-winston . How could [you]369-you communicate with the future ? It was of its nature impossi - ble . Either the future would resemble the present , in which case it would not listen to [him]132-winston : or it would be different from it , and [his]132-winston predicament would be meaningless . For some time [he]132-winston sat gazing stupidly at the paper . The telescreen had changed over to strident military music . It was curious that [he]132-winston seemed not merely to have lost the pow-

11Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com er of expressing [himself]132-winston , but even to have forgotten what it was that [he]132-winston had originally intended to say . For weeks past [he]132-winston had been making ready for this moment , and it had nev - er crossed [his]132-winston mind that anything would be needed except courage . The actual writing would be easy . All [he]132-winston had to do was to transfer to paper the interminable restless mono - logue that had been running inside [his]132-winston head , literally for years . At this moment , however , even the monologue had dried up . [Moreover]370-moreover [his]132-winston varicose ulcer had begun itching unbearably . [He]132-winston dared not scratch it , because if [he]132-winston did so it always became inflamed . The seconds were ticking by . [He]132-winston was conscious of nothing except the blankness of the page in front of [him]132-winston , the itching of the skin above [his]132-winston ankle , the blaring of the music , and a slight booziness caused by the gin . Suddenly [he]132-winston began writing in sheer panic , only imper - fectly aware of what [he]132-winston was setting down . [His]132-winston small but childish handwriting straggled up and down the page , shed - ding first its capital letters and finally even its full stops : April 4th , 1984 . Last night to the flicks . All war films . [One very good one of [[a ship]372-a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in [the Mediterranean]7-the mediterranean]373-a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in the mediterranean]371-one very good one of a ship full of refugees being bombed somewhere in the mediterranean . [Audience]374-audience much amused by shots of [a great huge fat man]375-a great huge fat man trying to swim away with [a helicopter]323-a helicopter after [him]375-a great huge fat man , first [you]377-you saw [him]375-a great huge fat man wallowing along in the water like a porpoise , then [you]377-you saw [him]375-a great huge fat man through the helicopters gunsights , then [he]375-a great huge fat man was full of holes and [the sea]378-the sea round [him]375-a great huge fat man turned pink and [he]375-a great huge fat man sank as suddenly as though the holes had let in the water , [audience]374-audience shouting with laughter

19841 when [he]375-a great huge fat man sank . then [you]377-you saw [a lifeboat full of [children with a helicopter hovering over it]381-children with a helicopter hovering over it]380-a lifeboat full of children with a helicopter hovering over it . there was [a middle - aged woman]382-a middle - aged woman might have been [a jewess]383-a jewess sitting up in the bow with [a little boy about three years old in [her]382-a middle - aged woman arms]384-a little boy about three years old in her arms . [little boy]385-little boy screaming with fright and hiding [his]385-little boy head between [her]382-a middle - aged woman breasts as if [he]385-little boy was trying to burrow right into [her]382-a middle - aged woman and [the woman]386-the woman putting [her]386-the woman arms round [him]385-little boy and comforting [him]385-little boy although [she]386-the woman was blue with fright [herself]386-the woman , all the time covering [him]385-little boy up as much as possible as if [she]386-the woman thought [her]386-the woman arms could keep the bullets off [him]385-little boy . then [the helicopter]387-the helicopter planted a 20 kilo bomb in among [them]387-the helicopter terrific flash and [the boat]388-the boat went all to matchwood . then there was a wonderful shot of [a child]389-a child ’s arm going up up up right up into the air [a helicopter]323-a helicopter with a camera in its nose must have followed it up and there was a lot of applause from the party seats but [a woman down in [the prole part of [the house]321-the house]392-the prole part of the house]391-a woman down in the prole part of the house suddenly started kicking up a fuss and shouting [they]394-they did nt oughter of showed it not in front of [kids]395-kids [they]394-they did nt it ai nt right not in front of [kids]395-kids [it]392-the prole part of the house ai nt until [the police]397-the police turned [her]391-a woman down in the prole part of the house turned [her]391-a woman down in the prole part of the house out [i]0-the la - dle do nt suppose anything happened to [her]391-a woman down in the prole part of the house [nobody]398-nobody cares what the proles say typical prole reaction [they]394-they never — — [Winston]132-winston stopped writing , partly because [he]132-winston was suffer - ing from cramp . [He]132-winston did not know what had made [him]132-winston pour out this stream of rubbish . But the curious thing was that while [he]132-winston was doing so a totally different memory had clar - ified itself in [his]132-winston mind , to the point where [he]132-winston almost felt equal to writing it down . It was , [he]132-winston now realized , because of this other incident that [he]132-winston had suddenly decided to come

1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [home]366-home and begin the diary today . It had happened that morning at [the Ministry]350-the ministry , if any - thing so nebulous could be said to happen . It was nearly eleven hundred , and in [the Records De - partment]401-the records de - partment , where [Winston]132-winston worked , [they]394-they were dragging the chairs out of the cubicles and grouping [them]394-they in the cen - tre of [the hall]402-the hall opposite the big telescreen , in preparation for the Two Minutes Hate . [Winston]132-winston was just taking [his]132-winston place in one of [the middle rows]403-the middle rows when [two people whom [he]132-winston knew by sight , but had never spoken to , came unexpectedly into [the room]348-the room]404-two people whom he knew by sight , but had never spoken to , came unexpectedly into the room . [One of [them]404-two people whom he knew by sight , but had never spoken to , came unexpectedly into the room]406-one of them was [a girl whom [he]406-one of them often passed in [the corridors]408-the corridors]407-a girl whom he often passed in the corridors . [He]406-one of them did not know [her]407-a girl whom he often passed in the corridors name , but [he]406-one of them knew that [she]407-a girl whom he often passed in the corridors worked in [the Fiction Department]409-the fiction department . 19841 none in which [Goldstein]132-winston was not [the principal figure]451-the principal figure . [Winston]132-winston ’s diaphragm was constricted . [He]132-winston could never see the face of [Goldstein]132-winston without a painful mixture of emo - tions . It was a lean Jewish face , with a great fuzzy aureole of white hair and a small goatee beard — a clever face , and yet somehow inherently despicable , with a kind of senile sil - liness in the long thin nose , near the end of which a pair of spectacles was perched . It resembled the face of a sheep , and the voice , too , had a sheep - like quality . [Goldstein]132-winston was delivering [his]132-winston usual venomous attack upon the doctrines of [the Party]418-the party — an attack so exaggerated and perverse that [a child]389-a child should have been able to see through it , and yet just plausible enough to fill one with an alarmed feeling that [other people]460-other people , less level - headed than [oneself]461-oneself , might be taken in by it . 1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com bitual style of the orators of [the Party]418-the party , and even contained [Newspeak]134-newspeak words : more Newspeak words , indeed , than [any Party member]464-any party member would normally use in real life . 19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com a part , but , on the contrary , that it was impossible to avoid joining in . Within thirty seconds any pretence was always unnecessary . 1984 ing of ‘ B - B! ... B - B ! ’[126-big brother] always filled [him]126-big brother with horror . Of course [he]126-big brother chanted with the rest : it was impossible to do otherwise . Perhaps the rumours of vast underground conspiracies were true after all — perhaps [the Brotherhood]473-the brotherhood really existed ! It was impossible , in spite of the endless arrests and confessions

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com and executions , to be sure that [the Brotherhood]473-the brotherhood was not simply a myth . Some days [he]132-winston believed in it , some days not . There was no evidence , only fleeting glimpses that might mean anything or nothing : snatches of overheard conver - sation , faint scribbles on lavatory walls — once , even , when [two strangers]514-two strangers met , a small movement of the hand which had looked as though it might be a signal of recognition . It was all guesswork : very likely [he]132-winston had imagined everything . [He]132-winston had gone back to [his]132-winston cubicle without looking at [O’Brien]216-o’brien again . For a second , two seconds , [they]514-two strangers had exchanged an equivo - cal glance , and that was the end of the story . But even that was a memorable event , in the locked loneliness in which [one]441-one had to live . [Winston]132-winston roused [himself]132-winston and sat up straighter . [He]132-winston let out a belch . The gin was rising from [his]132-winston stomach . [His]132-winston eyes re - focused on the page . [He]132-winston discovered that while [he]132-winston sat helplessly musing [he]132-winston had also been writing , as though by automatic action . And it was no longer the same cramped , awkward handwriting as before . [His]132-winston pen had slid voluptuously over the smooth paper , printing in large neat capitals — DOWN WITH [[BIG BROTHER DOWN WITH [BIG BROTHER DOWN]126-big brother]11-big brother down with big brother down]516-big brother down with big brother down WITH [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother DOWN WITH [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother DOWN WITH [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother over and over again , filling half a page . [He]126-big brother could not help feeling a twinge of panic . It was ab - surd , since the writing of those particular words was not

19844 more dangerous than the initial act of opening the diary , but for a moment [he]126-big brother was tempted to tear out the spoiled pages and abandon the enterprise altogether . [He]126-big brother did not do so , however , because [he]126-big brother knew that it was useless . Whether [he]126-big brother wrote DOWN WITH [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother , or whether [he]126-big brother refrained from writing it , made no differ - ence . Whether [he]126-big brother went on with the diary , or whether [he]126-big brother did not go on with it , made no difference . [The Thought Police]137-police would get [him]126-big brother just the same . [He]126-big brother had committed — would still have committed , even if [he]126-big brother had never set pen to pa - per — the essential crime that contained all others in itself . Thoughtcrime , [they]517-they called it . Thoughtcrime was not a thing that could be concealed for ever . [You]518-you might dodge success - fully for a while , even for years , but sooner or later [they]517-they were bound to get [you]518-you . It was always at night — the arrests invariably happened at night . The sudden jerk out of sleep , the rough hand shak - ing [your]518-you shoulder , the lights glaring in [your]518-you eyes , the ring of hard faces round the bed . In the vast majority of cases there was no trial , no report of the arrest . [People]324-people simply disap - peared , always during the night . [Your]518-you name was removed from the registers , every record of everything [you]518-you had ever done was wiped out , [your]518-you one - time existence was denied and then forgotten . [You]518-you were abolished , annihilated : [VA - PORIZED]140-va - porized was the usual word . For a moment [he]140-va - porized was seized by a kind of hysteria . Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com neck [i]0-the la - dle do [nt]520-nt care down with [big brother]521-big brother [they]517-they always shoot [you]522-you in the back of the neck [i]0-the la - dle do nt care down with [big brother]521-big brother — — [He]521-big brother sat back in [his]521-big brother chair , slightly ashamed of [himself]521-big brother , and laid down the pen . The next moment [he]521-big brother started violently . There was a knocking at the door . Already ! [He]521-big brother sat as still as a mouse , in the futile hope that whoever it was might go away after a single attempt . But no , the knocking was repeated . The worst thing of all would be to delay . [His]521-big brother heart was thumping like a drum , but [his]521-big brother face , from long habit , was probably expressionless . [He]521-big brother got up and moved heavily towards the door .

1984 Chapter 2 A s [he]521-big brother put [his]521-big brother hand to the door - knob [Winston]132-winston saw that [he]521-big brother had left the diary open on the table . DOWN WITH [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother was written all over it , in letters almost big enough to be legible across [the room]348-the room . It was an inconceiv - ably stupid thing to have done . 19844 Down in [the street]319-the street the wind flapped the torn poster to and fro , and the word [INGSOC]145-ingsoc fitfully appeared and van - ished . [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . The sacred principles of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . Newspeak , doublethink , the mutability of the past . [He]132-winston felt as though [he]132-winston were wandering in [the forests of [the sea bottom]584-the sea bottom]583-the forests of the sea bottom , lost in a monstrous world where [he]132-winston [himself]132-winston was the monster . [He]132-winston was alone . The past was dead , the future was unimaginable . What certainty had [he]132-winston that a single human creature now living was on [his]132-winston side ? And what way of knowing that the dominion of [the Party]418-the party would not endure FOR EVER ? Like an answer , the three slogans on the white face of [the Minis]586-the minis - try of Truth came back to [him]132-winston : WAR IS PEACE FREEDOM IS SLAVERY IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH [He]132-winston took a twenty - five cent piece out of [his]132-winston pocket . There , too , in tiny clear lettering , the same slogans were inscribed , and on the other face of the coin the head of [Big Broth - er]146-big broth - er . Even from the coin the eyes pursued [you]587-you . On coins , on stamps , on the covers of books , on banners , on posters , and on the wrappings of a cigarette packet — everywhere . [Al]147-al - ways the eyes watching [you]587-you and the voice enveloping [you]587-you . Asleep or awake , working or eating , indoors or out of doors , in the bath or in bed — no escape . Nothing was [your]587-you own ex- cept the few cubic centimetres inside [your]587-you skull . The sun had shifted round , and the myriad windows of [the Ministry of Truth]329-the ministry of truth , with the light no longer shining on

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com them , looked grim as the loopholes of [a fortress]589-a fortress . [His]132-winston heart quailed before the enormous pyramidal shape . It was too strong , it could not be stormed . A thousand rocket bombs would not batter it down . [He]132-winston wondered again for whom [he]132-winston was writing the diary . For the future , for the past — for an age that might be imaginary . And in front of [him]132-winston there lay not death but annihilation . The diary would be reduced to ashes and [himself]132-winston to vapour . Only the Thought [Police]137-police would read what [he]132-winston had written , before [they]590-they wiped it out of existence and out of memory . How could [you]591-you make appeal to the future when not a trace of [you]591-you , not even an anony - mous word scribbled on a piece of paper , could physically survive ? The telescreen struck fourteen . [He]132-winston must leave in ten min- utes . [He]132-winston had to be back at work by fourteen - thirty . Curiously , the chiming of the hour seemed to have put new heart into [him]132-winston . [He]132-winston was a lonely ghost uttering a truth that [nobody]398-nobody would ever hear . But so long as [he]132-winston uttered it , in some obscure way the continuity was not broken . It was not by making [yourself]587-you heard but by staying sane that [you]587-you carried on the human heritage . [He]132-winston went back to the table , dipped [his]132-winston pen , and wrote : To the future or to the past , to a time when thought is free , when [men]593-men are different from [one another]594-one another and do not live alone — to a time when truth exists and what is done can not be undone : From the age of uniformity , from the age of solitude , from the age of [Big Brother]126-big brother , from the age of doublethink — greetings !

1984 [He]132-winston was already dead , [he]132-winston reflected . It seemed to [him]132-winston that it was only now , when [he]132-winston had begun to be able to formulate [his]132-winston thoughts , that [he]132-winston had taken the decisive step . The conse - quences of every act are included in the act itself . [He]132-winston wrote : Thoughtcrime does not entail death : thoughtcrime IS death . Now [he]132-winston had recognized [himself]132-winston as [a dead man it became important to stay alive]595-a dead man it became important to stay alive as long as possible . Two fingers of [his]132-winston right hand were inkstained . It was exactly the kind of detail that might betray [you]587-you . Some nosing zealot in [the Ministry]350-the ministry ( [a woman]597-a woman , probably : someone like [the little sandy - haired woman]445-the little sandy - haired woman or [the dark - haired girl from [the Fiction Depart - ment]600-the fiction depart - ment]599-the dark - haired girl from the fiction depart - ment ) might start wondering why [he]132-winston had been writing during the lunch interval , why [he]132-winston had used an old - fash - ioned pen , WHAT [he]132-winston had been writing — and then drop a hint in the appropriate quarter . [He]132-winston went to [the bathroom]601-the bathroom and carefully scrubbed the ink away with the gritty dark- brown soap which rasped [your]587-you skin like sandpaper and was therefore well adapted for this purpose . [He]132-winston put the diary away in the drawer . It was quite useless to think of hiding it , but [he]132-winston could at least make sure whether or not its existence had been discovered . A hair laid across the page - ends was too obvious . With the tip of [his]132-winston finger [he]132-winston picked up an identifiable grain of whitish dust and depos - ited it on the corner of the cover , where it was bound to be shaken off if the book was moved .

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Chapter 3 [W inston]148-w inston was dreaming of [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother . [The two of [them]607-the two of them]607-the two of them must evidently have been swallowed up in one of the first great purges of the fifties . At this moment [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother was sitting in some place deep down beneath [him]132-winston , with [[his]132-winston young sister]609-his young sister in [her]609-his young sister arms . [Both of [them]3354-both of them]3354-both of them were looking up at [him]132-winston . [They]3354-both of them were down in [some subter - ranean place]613-some subter - ranean place — the bottom of a well , for instance , or [a very deep grave]614-a very deep grave — but it was a place which , already far below [him]132-winston , was itself moving downwards . [They]3354-both of them were in [the saloon of [a sinking ship]616-a sinking ship]615-the saloon of a sinking ship , looking up at [him]132-winston through [the darkening water]617-the darkening water . There was still air in [the saloon]618-the saloon , [they]3354-both of them could still see [him]132-winston and [he]132-winston [them]3354-both of them , but all the while [they]3354-both of them were sinking down , down into [the green waters]619-the green waters which in another moment must hide [them]3354-both of them from sight for ever . [He]132-winston was out in the light and air while [they]3354-both of them were being sucked down to death , and [they]3354-both of them

19848 were down there because [he]132-winston was up here . [He]132-winston knew it and [they]3354-both of them knew it , and [he]132-winston could see the knowledge in [their]3354-both of them faces . There was no reproach either in [their]3354-both of them faces or in [their]3354-both of them hearts , only the knowledge that [they]3354-both of them must die in order that [he]132-winston might remain alive , and that this was part of the unavoid - able order of things . [He]132-winston could not remember what had happened , but [he]132-winston knew in [his]132-winston dream that in some way the lives of [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother and [[his]132-winston sister]610-his sister had been sacrificed to [his]132-winston own . It was one of those dreams which , while retaining the characteristic dream scenery , are a continuation of [one]441-one ’s intellectual life , and in which one becomes aware of facts and ideas which still seem new and valuable after [one]441-one is awake . The thing that now suddenly struck [Winston]132-winston was that [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother ’s death , nearly thirty years ago , had been tragic and sorrowful in a way that was no longer possible . Tragedy , [he]132-winston perceived , be - longed to the ancient time , to a time when there was still privacy , love , and friendship , and when [the members of [a family]626-a family]625-the members of a family stood by [one another]594-one another without needing to know the reason . [[His]132-winston mother]602-his mother ’s memory tore at [his]132-winston heart because [she]602-his mother had died loving [him]132-winston , when [he]132-winston was too young and selfish to love [her]602-his mother in return , and because somehow , [he]132-winston did not re - member how , [she]602-his mother had sacrificed [herself]602-his mother to a conception of loyalty that was private and unalterable . Such things , [he]132-winston saw , could not happen today . Today there were fear , hatred , and pain , but no dignity of emotion , no deep or complex sorrows . All this [he]132-winston seemed to see in the large eyes of [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother and [[his]132-winston sister]610-his sister , looking up at [him]132-winston through the green water , hundreds of fathoms down and still sinking .

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Suddenly [he]132-winston was standing on [short springy turf]631-short springy turf , on a summer evening when the slanting rays of the sun gilded the ground . The landscape that [he]132-winston was looking at recurred so often in [his]132-winston dreams that [he]132-winston was never fully certain whether or not [he]132-winston had seen it in [the real world]632-the real world . In [his]132-winston wak - ing thoughts [he]132-winston called it [the Golden Country]633-the golden country . In the ragged hedge on the opposite side of the field the boughs of the elm trees were swaying very faintly in the breeze , [their]634-their leaves just stirring in dense masses like [women]635-women ’s hair . [The girl with dark hair]439-the girl with dark hair was coming towards [them]439-the girl with dark hair across [the field]637-the field . 4Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com ous , though strictly speaking it had not always been the same war . For several months during [his]665-the old man childhood there had been confused street fighting in [London]2-london itself , some of which [he]665-the old man remembered vividly . But to trace out the history of the whole period , to say who was fighting whom at any given moment , would have been utterly impossible , since no written record , and no spoken word , ever made mention of any other alignment than the existing one . At this mo - ment , for example , in 1984 ( if it was 1984 ) , [Oceania]5-oceania was at war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia and in alliance with [Eastasia]9-eastasia . In no pub - lic or private utterance was it ever admitted that the three powers had at any time been grouped along different lines . Actually , as [Winston]132-winston well knew , it was only four years since [Oceania]5-oceania had been at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia and in alliance with [Eurasia]8-eurasia . But that was merely a piece of furtive knowledge which [he]132-winston happened to possess because [his]132-winston memory was not satisfactorily under control . Officially the change of [part - ners]670-part - ners had never happened . [Oceania]5-oceania was at war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia : therefore [Oceania]5-oceania had always been at war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia . [The enemy of the moment]671-the enemy of the moment always represented absolute evil , and it followed that any past or future agreement with [him]671-the enemy of the moment was impossible . The frightening thing , [he]671-the enemy of the moment reflected for the ten thou - sandth time as [he]671-the enemy of the moment forced [his]671-the enemy of the moment shoulders painfully backward ( with hands on hips , [they]672-they were gyrating [their]672-they bodies from the waist , an exercise that was supposed to be good for the back muscles)—the frightening thing was that it might all be true . If [the Party]418-the party could thrust its hand into the past and say of this or that event , IT NEVER HAPPENED — that ,

198444 surely , was more terrifying than mere torture and death ? [The Party]418-the party said that [Oceania]5-oceania had never been in alliance with [Eurasia]8-eurasia . [He]671-the enemy of the moment , [Winston Smith]132-winston , knew that [Oceania]5-oceania had been in alliance with [Eurasia]8-eurasia as short a time as four years ago . But where did that knowledge exist ? Only in [his]671-the enemy of the moment own consciousness , which in any case must soon be annihilated . And if [all others]675-all others accepted the lie which [the Party]418-the party imposed — if all records told the same tale — then the lie passed into history and became truth . ‘ Who controls the past , ’[418-the party] ran the Party slogan , ‘ controls the future : who controls the present controls the past . ’[418-the party] And yet the past , though of its nature al - terable , never had been altered . Whatever was true now was true from everlasting to everlasting . It was quite simple . All that was needed was an unending series of victories over [your]677-your own memory . ‘ Reality control ’[672-they] , [they]672-they called it : in New - speak , ‘ doublethink ’[672-they] . ‘ Stand easy ! ’[678-the instructress] barked [the instructress]678-the instructress , a little more genial - ly . [Winston]132-winston sank [his]132-winston arms to [his]132-winston sides and slowly refilled [his]132-winston lungs with air . [His]132-winston mind slid away into the labyrin - thine world of doublethink . To know and not to know , to be conscious of complete truthfulness while telling care - fully constructed lies , to hold simultaneously two opinions which cancelled out , knowing [them]675-all others to be contradictory and believing in both of [them]675-all others , to use logic against logic , to repudiate morality while laying claim to it , to believe that democracy was impossible and that [the Party]14-the party was the guardian of democracy , to forget whatever it was necessary to forget , then to draw it back into memory again at the

4Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com moment when it was needed , and then promptly to forget it again : and above all , to apply the same process to the pro - cess itself . That was the ultimate subtlety : consciously to induce unconsciousness , and then , once again , to become unconscious of the act of hypnosis [you]679-you had just performed . Even to understand the word ‘ doublethink ’[681-she] involved the use of doublethink . [The instructress]678-the instructress had called [them]675-all others to attention again . ‘ And now let ’s see which of [us]3380-us can touch [our]3380-us toes ! ’[681-she] [she]681-she said en - thusiastically . ‘ Right over from the hips , please , [comrades]3378-comrades . [ONE - two ! ONE - two]3382-one - two ! one - two ! ... ’[681-she] [Winston]132-winston loathed this exercise , which sent shooting pains all the way from [his]132-winston heels to [his]132-winston buttocks and often ended by bringing on another coughing fit . The half - pleasant qual - ity went out of [his]132-winston meditations . The past , [he]132-winston reflected , had not merely been altered , it had been actually destroyed . For how could [you]679-you establish even the most obvious fact when there existed no record outside [your]679-you own memory ? [He]132-winston tried to remember in what year [he]132-winston had first heard mention of [Big Brother]126-big brother . [He]132-winston thought it must have been at some time in the sixties , but it was impossible to be certain . In the Party histories , of course , [Big Brother]126-big brother figured as [the leader and guardian of the Revolution]682-the leader and guardian of the revolution since its very earliest days . 19844 and how much invented . [Winston]132-winston could not even remem - ber at what date the Party itself had come into existence . Everything melted into mist . Sometimes , indeed , [you]3383-you could put [your]3383-you finger on a definite lie . It was not true , for example , as was claimed in the Party history books , that [the Party]418-the party had invented aeroplanes . [He]126-big brother remembered aeroplanes since [his]126-big brother earliest childhood . But [you]3383-you could prove nothing . There was never any evidence . 198448 Chapter 4 W ith the deep , unconscious sigh which not even the nearness of the telescreen could prevent [him]3329-comrade from uttering when [his]3329-comrade day ’s work started , [Winston]132-winston pulled the speakwrite towards [him]3329-comrade , blew the dust from its mouthpiece , and put on [his]3329-comrade spectacles . Then [he]3329-comrade unrolled and clipped together four small cylinders of paper which had already flopped out of the pneumatic tube on the right - hand side of [his]3329-comrade desk . In the walls of the cubicle there were three orifices . To the right of the speakwrite , a small pneumatic tube for writ - ten messages , to the left , a larger one for newspapers ; and in the side wall , within easy reach of [Winston]132-winston ’s arm , a large oblong slit protected by a wire grating . This last was for the disposal of waste paper . Similar slits existed in thousands or tens of thousands throughout [the building]698-the building , not only in [ev - ery room]699-ev - ery room but at short intervals in [every corridor]700-every corridor . For some reason [they]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses were nicknamed memory holes . When [one]441-one knew that any document was due for destruction , or even when [one]441-one saw a scrap of waste paper lying about , it was an automatic action to lift the flap of the nearest memory hole and drop it in , whereupon it would be whirled away on a current of warm air to the enormous furnaces which were hidden somewhere in the recesses of [the building]698-the building . [Winston]132-winston examined the four slips of paper which [he]132-winston had

49Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com unrolled . Each contained a message of only one or two lines , in the abbreviated jargon — not actually [Newspeak]134-newspeak , but con - sisting largely of [Newspeak]134-newspeak words — which was used in [the Ministry]350-the ministry for internal purposes . [They]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses ran : times 17.3.84 bb speech malreported africa rectify times 19.12.83 forecasts 3 yp 4th quarter 83 misprints verify current issue times 14.2.84 miniplenty malquoted chocolate rectify times 3.12.83 reporting bb dayorder doubleplusungood refs unpersons rewrite fullwise upsub antefiling With a faint feeling of satisfaction [Winston]132-winston laid the fourth message aside . It was an intricate and responsible job and had better be dealt with last . [The other three]705-the other three were rou - tine matters , though the second one would probably mean some tedious wading through lists of figures . [Winston]132-winston dialled ‘ back numbers ’[132-winston] on the telescreen and called for the appropriate issues of ‘ The Times ’[132-winston] , which slid out of the pneumatic tube after only a few minutes ’ delay . The messages [he]132-winston had received referred to articles or news items which for one reason or another it was thought neces- sary to alter , or , as the official phrase had it , to rectify . For example , it appeared from ‘[132-winston] The Times ’ of the seventeenth of March that [Big Brother]126-big brother , in [his]126-big brother speech of the previous day , had predicted that [the South Indian front]3387-the south indian front would re - main quiet but that a Eurasian offensive would shortly be[132-winston]

19840 launched in [North Africa]25-north africa . As it happened , the Eurasian Higher Command had launched its offensive in [South In - dia]26-south in - dia and left [North Africa]25-north africa alone . It was therefore necessary to rewrite a paragraph of [Big Brother]126-big brother ’s speech , in such a way as to make [him]132-winston predict the thing that had actually hap - pened . Or again , ‘ The Times ’[126-big brother] of the nineteenth of December had published the official forecasts of the output of various classes of consumption goods in the fourth quarter of 1983 , which was also the sixth quarter of the Ninth Three - Year Plan . Today ’s issue contained a statement of the actual out - put , from which it appeared that the forecasts were in every instance grossly wrong . [Winston]132-winston ’s job was to rectify the original figures by making [them]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses agree with [the later ones]706-the later ones . As for the third message , it referred to a very simple error which could be set right in a couple of minutes . As short a time ago as February , [the Ministry of Plenty]707-the ministry of plenty had issued a promise ( a ‘ categorical pledge ’[132-winston] were the official words ) that there would be no reduction of the chocolate ration during 1984 . Actually , as [Winston]132-winston was aware , the chocolate ration was to be reduced from thirty grammes to twenty at the end of the present week . All that was needed was to substitute for the original promise a warning that it would probably be necessary to reduce the ration at some time in April . As soon as [Winston]132-winston had dealt with each of the messages , [he]132-winston clipped [his]132-winston speakwritten corrections to the appropriate copy of ‘ The Times ’[132-winston] and pushed [them]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses into the pneumatic tube . Then , with a movement which was as nearly as possi - ble unconscious , [he]132-winston crumpled up the original message and any notes that [he]132-winston [himself]132-winston had made , and dropped [them]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses into

1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com the memory hole to be devoured by the flames . What happened in the unseen labyrinth to which the pneumatic tubes led , [he]132-winston did not know in detail , but [he]132-winston did know in general terms . As soon as all the corrections which happened to be necessary in any particular number of ‘ The Times ’[132-winston] had been assembled and collated , that number would be reprinted , the original copy destroyed , and the corrected copy placed on the files in its stead . This process of con - tinuous alteration was applied not only to newspapers , but to books , periodicals , pamphlets , posters , leaflets , films , sound - tracks , cartoons , photographs — to every kind of lit - erature or documentation which might conceivably hold any political or ideological significance . Day by day and almost minute by minute the past was brought up to date . In this way every prediction made by [the Party]418-the party could be shown by documentary evidence to have been correct , nor was any item of news , or any expression of opinion , which conflicted with the needs of the moment , ever allowed to remain on record . All history was a palimpsest , scraped clean and reinscribed exactly as often as was necessary . In no case would it have been possible , once the deed was done , to prove that any falsification had taken place . [The largest section of [the Records Department]435-the records department]709-the largest section of the records department , far larger than [the one on which [Winston]132-winston worked]711-the one on which winston worked , consisted simply of [persons whose duty it was to track down and collect all copies of books]712-persons whose duty it was to track down and collect all copies of books , newspapers , and other documents which had been superseded and were due for destruction . A number of ‘ The Times ’[126-big brother] which might , because of changes in political align - ment , or mistaken prophecies uttered by [Big Brother]126-big brother , have

1984 been rewritten a dozen times still stood on the files bearing its original date , and no other copy existed to contradict it . Books , also , were recalled and rewritten again and again , and were invariably reissued without any admission that any alteration had been made . Even the written instruc - tions which [Winston]132-winston received , and which [he]132-winston invariably got rid of as soon as [he]132-winston had dealt with [them]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses , never stated or implied that an act of forgery was to be committed : always the reference was to slips , errors , misprints , or misquota - tions which it was necessary to put right in the interests of accuracy . But actually , [he]132-winston thought as [he]132-winston re - adjusted the Ministry of [Plenty]152-plenty ’s figures , it was not even forgery . It was merely the substitution of one piece of nonsense for another . Most of the material that [you]713-you were dealing with had no connexion with anything in [the real world]632-the real world , not even the kind of con - nexion that is contained in a direct lie . Statistics were just as much a fantasy in [their]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses original version as in [their]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses recti - fied version . A great deal of the time [you]713-you were expected to make [them]696-the sailors in the floating fortresses up out of [your]713-you head . For example , the Minis - try of Plenty ’s forecast had estimated the output of boots for the quarter at 145 million pairs . The actual output was given as sixty - two millions . [Winston]132-winston , however , in rewriting the forecast , marked [the figure down to fifty - seven millions]715-the figure down to fifty - seven millions , so as to allow for the usual claim that the quota had been overfulfilled . In any case , sixty - two millions was no near - er the truth than fifty - seven millions , or than 145 millions . Very likely no boots had been produced at all . [Likelier]716-likelier still , [nobody]398-nobody knew how many had been produced , much less

Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com cared . [All one]718-all one knew was that every quarter astronomical numbers of boots were produced on paper , while perhaps half [the population of [Oceania]5-oceania]719-the population of oceania went barefoot . And so it was with every class of recorded fact , great or small . Everything faded away into a shadow - world in which , finally , even the date of the year had become uncertain . [Winston]132-winston glanced across [the hall]402-the hall . There was a whole chain of separate departments dealing with proletarian lit - erature , music , drama , and entertainment generally . Here were produced rubbishy newspapers containing almost nothing except sport , crime and astrology , sensational five - cent novelettes , films oozing with sex , and sentimen - tal songs which were composed entirely by mechanical means on a special kind of kaleidoscope known as a ver - sificator . Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [their]823-them pannikins . From the table at [Winston]132-winston ’s left , a little behind [his]132-winston back , [someone]571-someone was talking rapidly and contin - uously , a harsh gabble almost like the quacking of a duck , which pierced the general uproar of [the room]348-the room . ‘ How is the Dictionary getting on ? ’[132-winston] said [Winston]132-winston , raising [his]132-winston voice to overcome the noise . ‘ Slowly , ’[160-syme] said [Syme]160-syme . ‘ [I]160-syme ’m[160-syme] on the adjectives . It ’s fascinat - ing . ’ [He]132-winston had brightened up immediately at the mention of [Newspeak]134-newspeak . [He]132-winston pushed [his]132-winston pannikin aside , took up [his]132-winston hunk of bread in one delicate hand and [his]132-winston cheese in the other , and leaned across the table so as to be able to speak without shouting . ‘[132-winston] The Eleventh Edition is the definitive edition , ’ [he]132-winston said . ‘[826-we] [We]826-we ’re getting the language into its final shape — the shape it ’s going to have when [nobody]398-nobody speaks anything else . When [we]826-we ’ve finished with it , [people]324-people like [you]3406-you will have to learn it all over again . [You]3406-you think , [I]826-we dare say , that [our]826-we chief job is inventing new words . But not a bit of it ! [We]826-we ’re[826-we] destroying words — scores of [them]827-them , hundreds of [them]827-them , every day . [We]826-we ’re cutting the language down to the bone . The Eleventh Edi - tion wo n’t contain a single word that will become obsolete before the year 2050 . ’[828-he] [He]828-he bit hungrily into [his]828-he bread and swallowed a couple of mouthfuls , then continued speaking , with a sort of ped - ant ’s passion . [His]828-he thin dark face had become animated , [his]828-he eyes had lost [their]828-he mocking expression and grown almost dreamy . ‘ It ’s a beautiful thing , the destruction of words . Of course[828-he]

1984 the great wastage is in the verbs and adjectives , but there are hundreds of nouns that can be got rid of as well . It is n’t only the synonyms ; there are also the antonyms . After all , what justification is there for a word which is simply the opposite of some other word ? A word contains its opposite in itself . Take ‘ good ’[829-you] , for instance . If [you]829-you have a word like ‘ good ’[829-you] , what need is there for a word like ‘ bad ’[829-you] ? ‘ [Ungood]162-ungood ’[829-you] will do just as well — better , because it ’s an exact opposite , which the other is not . Or again , if [you]829-you want a stronger ver - sion of ‘ good ’[829-you] , what sense is there in having a whole string of vague useless words like ‘ excellent ’[829-you] and ‘ splendid ’[829-you] and all the rest of [them]827-them ? ‘ [Plusgood]163-plusgood ’[829-you] covers the meaning , or ‘ double - plusgood ’[829-you] if [you]829-you want something stronger still . Of course [we]826-we use those forms already . but in the final version of New - speak there ’ll be nothing else . In the end the whole notion of goodness and badness will be covered by only six words — in reality , only one word . Do n’t [you]829-you see the beauty of that , [Winston]132-winston ? It was [B.B.]164-b.b. ’s idea originally , of course , ’ [he]828-he added as an afterthought . A sort of vapid eagerness flitted across [Winston]132-winston ’s face at the mention of [Big Brother]126-big brother . Nevertheless [Syme]160-syme immediately detected a certain lack of enthusiasm . ‘[829-you] [You]829-you have n’t a real appreciation of [Newspeak]134-newspeak , [Winston]132-winston , ’ [he]828-he said almost sadly . ‘[132-winston] Even when [you]829-you write it [you]829-you ’re still thinking in [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak . [You]829-you do n’t grasp the beauty of the destruction of[830-they]

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com words . Do [you]829-you know that [Newspeak]134-newspeak is the only language in the world whose vocabulary gets smaller every year ? ’ [Winston]132-winston did know that , of course . [Syme]160-syme bit off another fragment of the dark - coloured bread , chewed it briefly , and went on : ‘[829-you] Do n’t [you]829-you see that the whole aim of [Newspeak]134-newspeak is to narrow the range of thought ? In the end [we]831-we shall make thoughtcrime literally impossible , because there will be no words in which to express it . Every concept that can ever be needed , will be expressed by exactly one word , with its meaning rigidly defined and all its subsidiary meanings rubbed out and forgotten . Already , in the Eleventh Edition , [we]831-we ’re not far from that point . But the process will still be continuing long after [you]829-you and [I]134-newspeak are dead . Every year fewer and fewer words , and the range of consciousness always a little smaller . Even now , of course , there ’s no reason or ex - cuse for committing thoughtcrime . It ’s merely a question of self - discipline , reality - control . But in the end there wo n’t be any need even for that . The Revolution will be com - plete when the language is perfect . [He]132-winston meditated resentfully on the physical texture of life . Had it always been like this ? Had food always tasted like this ? [He]132-winston looked round [the canteen]351-the canteen . [A low - ceilinged , crowded room]892-a low - ceilinged , crowded room , [its]892-a low - ceilinged , crowded room walls grimy from the contact of innu - merable bodies ; battered metal tables and chairs , placed so close together that [you]893-you sat with elbows touching ; bent spoons , dented trays , coarse white mugs ; all surfaces greasy , grime in every crack ; and a sourish , composite smell of bad gin and bad coffee and metallic stew and dirty clothes . [Al]147-al -

1984 ways in [your]893-you stomach and in [your]893-you skin there was a sort of protest , a feeling that [you]893-you had been cheated of something that [you]893-you had a right to . It was true that [he]132-winston had no memories of anything greatly different . In any time that [he]132-winston could ac - curately remember , there had never been quite enough to eat , [one]441-one had never had socks or underclothes that were not full of holes , furniture had always been battered and rickety , rooms underheated , tube trains crowded , [houses]895-houses falling to pieces , bread dark - coloured , tea a rarity , coffee filthy - tast - ing , cigarettes insufficient — nothing cheap and plentiful except synthetic gin . The aim of [the Party]418-the party was not merely to prevent [men]593-men and [women]635-women from forming loyalties which it might not be able to control . Its real , undeclared purpose was to remove all pleasure from the sexual act . Not love so much as [eroti - cism]976-eroti - cism was [the enemy]977-the enemy , inside marriage as well as outside it . 198484 ognized purpose of marriage was to [beget children for the service of [the Party]418-the party]981-beget children for the service of the party . 89Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Chapter 7 ‘ If there is hope , ’[132-winston] wrote [Winston]132-winston , ‘ it lies in the proles . ’[132-winston] If there was hope , it MUST lie in the proles , because only there in those swarming disregarded masses , [85 per cent of the population of [Oceania]5-oceania]1012-85 per cent of the population of oceania , could the force to [de - stroy the Party]1013-de - stroy the party ever be generated . [The Party]418-the party could not be overthrown from within . [[Its]418-the party enemies]1015-its enemies , if it had [any enemies]1016-any enemies , had no way of coming together or even of identifying [one another]594-one another . Even if [the legendary Brotherhood]1018-the legendary brotherhood existed , as just possibly it might , it was inconceivable that [its members]1019-its members could ever assemble in larger numbers than twos and threes . Rebellion meant a look in the eyes , an inflexion of the voice , at the most , an occasional whispered word . But the proles , if only [they]1019-its members could somehow become conscious of [their]1019-its members own strength . would have no need to conspire . [They]1019-its members needed only to rise up and shake [themselves]1019-its members like a horse shaking off flies . If [they]1019-its members chose [they]1019-its members could blow the Party to pieces tomorrow morning . Surely sooner or later it must occur to [them]1019-its members to do it ? And yet — — ! [He]132-winston remembered how once [he]132-winston had been walking down [a crowded street]1020-a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices [women]635-women ’s voices — had burst from [a side - street]1022-a side - street a little way ahead . 198490 ed ! [he]132-winston had thought . A riot ! The proles are breaking loose at last ! When [he]132-winston had reached the spot it was to see [a mob of two or three hundred women]1024-a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of [a street market]1025-a street market , with faces as tragic as though [they]1024-a mob of two or three hundred women had been [the doomed passengers on [a sinking ship]616-a sinking ship]1026-the doomed passengers on a sinking ship . But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels . It appeared that one of [the stalls]1028-the stalls had been selling tin saucepans . [They]1028-the stalls were wretched , flimsy things , but cooking - pots of any kind were always difficult to get . Now the supply had unexpectedly given out . [The successful women]1029-the successful women , bumped and jostled by [the rest]1030-the rest , were trying to make off with [their]1029-the successful women saucepans while [dozens of others]1031-dozens of others clamoured round [the stall]1032-the stall , accusing [the stall - keeper of favouritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve]1033-the stall - keeper of favouritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve . There was a fresh outburst of yells . [Two bloat - ed women]1034-two bloat - ed women , one of [them]1034-two bloat - ed women with [her]1034-two bloat - ed women hair coming down , had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of [one another]594-one another ’s hands . For a moment [they]1034-two bloat - ed women were both tugging , and then the handle came off . [Winston]132-winston watched [them]1034-two bloat - ed women disgustedly . And yet , just for a moment , what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats ! Why was it that [they]1034-two bloat - ed women could never shout like that about anything that mattered ? [He]132-winston wrote : Until [they]1034-two bloat - ed women become conscious [they]1034-two bloat - ed women will never rebel , and until after [they]1034-two bloat - ed women have rebelled [they]1034-two bloat - ed women can not become conscious . 91Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com tion from one of [the Party]14-the party textbooks . [The Party]418-the party claimed , of course , to have liberated the proles from bondage . Before the Revolution [they]1034-two bloat - ed women had been hideously oppressed by [the capitalists]1037-the capitalists , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women had been starved and flogged , [women]635-women had been forced to work in [the coal mines]1039-the coal mines ( [women]635-women still did work in [the coal mines]1039-the coal mines , as a matter of fact ) , [children]3366-children had been sold into [the factories]1043-the factories at the age of six . In reality very little was known about the proles . It was not necessary to know much . So long as [they]1034-two bloat - ed women contin - ued to work and breed , [their]1034-two bloat - ed women other activities were without importance . Left to [themselves]1034-two bloat - ed women , like cattle turned loose upon [the plains of [Argentina]35-argentina]1047-the plains of argentina , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women had reverted to a style of life that appeared to be natural to [them]1034-two bloat - ed women , a sort of ancestral pattern . [They]1034-two bloat - ed women were born , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women grew up in the gutters , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women went to work at twelve , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women passed through a brief blos - soming - period of beauty and sexual desire , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women married at twenty , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women were middle - aged at thirty , [they]1034-two bloat - ed women died , for the most part , at sixty . Heavy physical work , the care of [home]366-home and [children]3366-children , petty quarrels with [neighbours]1050-neighbours , films , foot - ball , beer , and above all , gambling , filled up the horizon of [their]1034-two bloat - ed women minds . To keep [them]1034-two bloat - ed women in control was not difficult . [A few agents of [the Thought Police]569-the thought police]1051-a few agents of the thought police moved always among [them]1051-a few agents of the thought police , spreading false rumours and marking down and eliminating [the few individuals who were judged capable of becoming dangerous]1053-the few individuals who were judged capable of becoming dangerous ; but no attempt was made to indoctri - nate [them]1051-a few agents of the thought police with the ideology of [the Party]418-the party . It was not desirable

19849 that [the proles]1045-the proles should have strong political feelings . All that was required of [them]1051-a few agents of the thought police was a primitive patriotism which could be appealed to whenever it was necessary to make [them]1051-a few agents of the thought police accept longer working - hours or shorter rations . [The Party]418-the party claimed , for example , that today 40 per cent of adult proles were literate : before the Revolution , it was said , the number had only been 15 per cent . [The Party]418-the party claimed that the infant mortality rate was now only 160 per thousand , whereas before the Revolution it had been 300 — and so it went on . It was like a single equation with two unknowns .
