About five years after this , in 1973 , [Winston]132-winston was unrolling a wad of docu - ments which had just flopped out of the pneumatic tube on to [his]132-winston desk when [he]132-winston came on a fragment of paper which had evidently been slipped in among the others and then forgotten . The instant [he]132-winston had flattened it out [he]132-winston saw its sig - nificance . It was a half - page torn out of ‘ The Times ’[132-winston] of about ten years earlier — the top half of the page , so that it included the date — and it contained a photograph of [the delegates]1177-the delegates at [some Party function in [New York]36-new york]1178-some party function in new york . Prominent in the middle of the group were [Jones]183-jones , [Aaronson]184-aaronson , and [Rutherford]185-rutherford . There was no mistaking [them]1146-all three , in any case [their]1146-all three names were in the caption at the bottom . The point was that at both trials [all three men]936-all three men had con - fessed that on that date [they]936-all three men had been on [Eurasian soil]1180-eurasian soil . [They]936-all three men had flown from [a secret airfield in [Canada]37-canada]1181-a secret airfield in canada to [a rendezvous somewhere in [Siberia]38-siberia]1182-a rendezvous somewhere in siberia , and had conferred with [members of the Eurasian General Staff]1183-members of the eurasian general staff , to whom [they]1183-members of the eurasian general staff had betrayed [i]0-the la - dle m -

1984100 portant military secrets . The date had stuck in [Winston]132-winston ’s memory because it chanced to be midsummer day ; but the whole story must be on record in countless other places as well . There was only one possible conclusion : the confes - sions were lies . Of course , this was not in itself a discovery . Even at that time [Winston]132-winston had not imagined that [the people who were wiped out in the purges]1184-the people who were wiped out in the purges had actually committed the crimes that [they]1184-the people who were wiped out in the purges were accused of . But this was concrete evidence ; it was a fragment of the abolished past , like a fossil bone which turns up in the wrong stratum and destroys a geo - logical theory . It was enough to blow [the Party]418-the party to atoms , if in some way it could have been published to [the world]318-the world and its significance made known . [He]132-winston had gone straight on working . As soon as [he]132-winston saw what the photograph was , and what it meant , [he]132-winston had covered it up with another sheet of paper . Luckily , when [he]132-winston unrolled it , it had been upside - down from the point of view of the telescreen . [He]132-winston took [his]132-winston scribbling pad on [his]132-winston knee and pushed back [his]132-winston chair so as to get as far away from the telescreen as pos - sible . To keep [your]1187-your face expressionless was not difficult , and even [your]1187-your breathing could be controlled , with an effort : but [you]1187-your could not control the beating of [your]1187-your heart , and the telescreen was quite delicate enough to pick it up . [He]132-winston let what [he]132-winston judged to be ten minutes go by , tormented all the while by the fear that some accident — a sudden draught blowing across [his]132-winston desk , for instance — would betray [him]132-winston . Then , without uncovering it again , [he]132-winston dropped the photo -

101Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com graph into the memory hole , along with some other waste papers . Within another minute , perhaps , it would have crumbled into ashes . That was ten — eleven years ago . Today , probably , [he]132-winston would have kept that photograph . It was curious that the fact of having held it in [his]132-winston fingers seemed to [him]132-winston to make a difference even now , when the photograph itself , as well as the event it recorded , was only memory . Was [the Party]418-the party ’s hold upon the past less strong , [he]132-winston wondered , because a piece of evidence which existed no longer HAD ONCE existed ? But today , supposing that it could be somehow resur - rected from its ashes , the photograph might not even be evidence . Already , at the time when [he]132-winston made [his]132-winston discov - ery , [Oceania]5-oceania was no longer at war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia , and it must have been to [the agents of [Eastasia]9-eastasia]1189-the agents of eastasia that [the three dead men]1190-the three dead men had betrayed [[their]1190-the three dead men country]1191-their country . Since then there had been oth - er changes — two , three , [he]132-winston could not remember how many . Very likely the confessions had been rewritten and rewritten until the original facts and dates no longer had the small - est significance . The past not only changed , but changed continuously . What most afflicted [him]132-winston with the sense of nightmare was that [he]132-winston had never clearly understood why the huge imposture was undertaken . The immediate advan - tages of falsifying the past were obvious , but the ultimate motive was mysterious . [He]132-winston took up [his]132-winston pen again and wrote : [I]0-the la - dle understand HOW : [I]0-the la - dle do not understand WHY .

198410 [He]132-winston wondered , as [he]132-winston had many times wondered before , whether [he]132-winston [himself]132-winston was [a lunatic]1192-a lunatic . Perhaps [a lunatic]1192-a lunatic was simply [a minority of one]1194-a minority of one . At one time it had been a sign of madness to believe that [the earth]651-the earth goes round the sun ; today , to believe that the past is inalterable . [He]132-winston might be ALONE in holding that belief , and if alone , then [a lunatic]1192-a lunatic . But the thought of being [a lunatic]1192-a lunatic did not greatly trouble [him]132-winston : the horror was that [he]132-winston might also be wrong . [He]132-winston picked up [the children]535-the children ’s history book and looked at the portrait of [Big Brother]126-big brother which formed its frontispiece . The hypnotic eyes gazed into [his]132-winston own . It was as though some huge force were pressing down upon [you]1199-you — something that penetrated inside [your]1199-you skull , battering against [your]1199-you brain , frightening [you]1199-you out of [your]1199-you beliefs , persuading [you]1199-you , almost , to deny the evidence of [your]1199-you senses . In the end [the Party]418-the party would announce that two and two made five , and [you]1199-you would have to believe it . It was inevitable that [they]535-the children should make that claim sooner or later : the logic of [their]535-the children position demanded it . Not merely the validity of experience , but the very existence of external reality , was tacitly denied by [their]535-the children philosophy . The heresy of heresies was common sense . And what was terrifying was not that [they]535-the children would kill [you]1199-you for thinking otherwise , but that [they]535-the children might be right . For , after all , how do [we]1201-we know that two and two make four ? Or that the force of gravity works ? Or that the past is unchange - able ? If both the past and [the external world]1202-the external world exist only in the mind , and if the mind itself is controllable what then ? But no ! [His]132-winston courage seemed suddenly to stiffen of its own accord . The face of [O’Brien]216-o’brien , not called up by any obvi -

10Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet ous association , had floated into [his]132-winston mind . [He]132-winston knew , with more certainty than before , that [O’Brien]216-o’brien was on [his]132-winston side . [He]132-winston was writing the diary for [O’Brien]216-o’brien — TO [O’Brien]216-o’brien : it was like an interminable letter which [no one]1135-no one would ever read , but which was addressed to [a particular person]1204-a particular person and took its colour from that fact . [The Party]418-the party told [you]1199-you to reject the evidence of [your]1199-you eyes and ears . It was [their]418-the party final , most essential command . [His]132-winston heart sank as [he]132-winston thought of the enormous power arrayed against [him]132-winston , the ease with which [any Party intellectual]1206-any party intellectual would over - throw [him]132-winston in debate , the subtle arguments which [he]132-winston would not be able to understand , much less answer . And yet [he]132-winston was in the right ! [They]418-the party were wrong and [he]132-winston was right . The obvious , the silly , and the true had got to be defended . [Tru]186-tru - isms are true , hold on to that ! [The solid world]1207-the solid world exists , its laws do not change . [Stones]187-stones are hard , water is wet , objects unsup - ported fall towards [the earth]651-the earth ’s centre . With the feeling that [he]132-winston was speaking to [O’Brien]216-o’brien , and also that [he]132-winston was setting forth an important axiom , [he]132-winston wrote : Freedom is the freedom to say that two plus two make four . If that is granted , all else follows .

1984104 Chapter 8 F rom somewhere at the bottom of a passage the smell of roasting coffee — real coffee , not [Victory Coffee]188-victory coffee — came floating out into [the street]319-the street . [Winston]132-winston paused involuntarily . For perhaps two seconds [he]132-winston was back in [the half - forgotten world of [his]132-winston childhood]1210-the half - forgotten world of his childhood . Then a door banged , seeming to cut off the smell as abruptly as though it had been a sound . [He]132-winston had walked several kilometres over [pavements]1211-pavements , and [his]132-winston varicose ulcer was throbbing . This was the second time in three weeks that [he]132-winston had missed an evening at [the Com - munity Centre]39-the com - munity centre : a rash act , since [you]1212-you could be certain that the number of [your]1212-you attendances at [the Centre]1213-the centre was care - fully checked . In principle [a Party member]948-a party member had no spare time , and was never alone except in bed . It was assumed that when [he]132-winston was not working , eating , or sleeping [he]132-winston would be taking part in some kind of communal recreation : to do anything that suggested a taste for solitude , even to go for a walk by [yourself]1212-you , was always slightly dangerous . There was a word for it in [Newspeak]134-newspeak : OWNLIFE , it was called , mean - ing individualism and eccentricity . But this evening as [he]132-winston came out of the Ministry the balminess of the April air had tempted [him]132-winston . The sky was a warmer blue than [he]132-winston had seen it that year , and suddenly the long , noisy evening at [the Cen - tre]1215-the cen - tre , the boring , exhausting games , the lectures , the creaking camaraderie oiled by gin , had seemed intolerable . On [i]0-the la - dle m -

But in effect it was unanswerable even now , since the few scattered sur -

1984118 vivors from [the ancient world]1150-the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another . [They]1353-they remembered a million useless things , a quarrel with [a workmate]1354-a workmate , a hunt for a lost bicy - cle pump , the expression on [a long - dead sister]1355-a long - dead sister ’s face , the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago : but all the relevant facts were outside the range of [their]1353-they vision . [They]1353-they were like the ant , which can see small objects but not large ones . And when memory failed and written records were falsified — when that happened , the claim of [the Party]418-the party to have improved the conditions of human life had got to be accepted , because there did not exist , and never again could exist , any standard against which it could be tested . At this moment [his]132-winston train of thought stopped abruptly . [He]132-winston halted and looked up . [He]132-winston was in [a narrow street]1357-a narrow street , with [a few dark little shops]1358-a few dark little shops , interspersed among [dwelling - houses]1359-dwelling - houses . Immediately above [his]132-winston head there hung three discoloured metal balls which looked as if [they]1353-they had once been gilded . [He]132-winston seemed to know the place . Of course ! [He]132-winston was standing outside [the junk - shop]1360-the junk - shop where [he]132-winston had bought the diary . A twinge of fear went through [him]132-winston . It had been a suf - ficiently rash act to buy the book in the beginning , and [he]132-winston had sworn never to come near [the place]3337-the place again . It was precisely against suicidal impulses of this kind that [he]132-winston had hoped to guard [himself]132-winston by opening the diary . 198410 have n’t seen a brass candlestick in years . ’ The tiny interior of [the shop]1363-the shop was in fact uncomfortably full , but there was almost nothing in it of the slightest val - ue . [The floorspace]3507-the floorspace was very restricted , because all round the walls were stacked innumerable dusty picture - frames . In the window there were trays of nuts and bolts , worn - out chisels , penknives with broken blades , tarnished watches that did not even pretend to be in going order , and other miscellaneous rubbish . Only on a small table in the corner was there a litter of odds and ends — lacquered snuffbox - es , agate brooches , and the like — which looked as though [they]1372-they might include something interesting . As [Winston]132-winston wandered towards the table [his]132-winston eye was caught by a round , smooth thing that gleamed softly in the lamplight , and [he]132-winston picked it up . It was a heavy lump of glass , curved on one side , flat on the other , making almost a hemisphere . There was a peculiar softness , as of rainwater , in both the colour and the texture of the glass . At the heart of it , magnified by the curved surface , there was a strange , pink , convoluted object that recalled a rose or a sea anemone . ‘[0-the la - dle] What is it ? ’ said [Winston]132-winston , fascinated . ‘[0-the la - dle] That ’s coral , that is , ’ said [the old man]665-the old man . ‘[0-the la - dle] It must have come from [the Indian Ocean]45-the indian ocean . 11Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com if it so happened that [you]1370-you wanted to buy it , that ’d cost [you]1370-you four dollars . [I]0-the la - dle can remember when a thing like that would have fetched eight pounds , and eight pounds was — well , [I]0-the la - dle ca n’t work it out , but it was a lot of money . But who cares about genuine antiques nowadays — even the few that ’s left ? ’ [Winston]132-winston immediately paid over the four dollars and slid the coveted thing into [his]132-winston pocket . What appealed to [him]132-winston about it was not so much its beauty as the air it seemed to possess of belonging to an age quite different from the pres - ent one . The soft , rainwatery glass was not like any glass that [he]132-winston had ever seen . The thing was doubly attractive because of its apparent uselessness , though [he]132-winston could guess that it must once have been intended as a paperweight . It was very heavy in [his]132-winston pocket , but fortunately it did not make much of a bulge . It was a queer thing , even a compromising thing , for [a Party member]948-a party member to have in [his]132-winston possession . Anything old , and for that matter anything beautiful , was always vaguely suspect . [The old man]665-the old man had grown noticeably more cheerful after receiving the four dollars . [Winston]132-winston realized that [he]665-the old man would have accepted three or even two . ‘[1370-you] There ’s [another room [upstairs]1374-upstairs]1373-another room upstairs that [you]1370-you might care to take a look at , ’ [he]132-winston said . ‘[1370-you] There ’s not much in it . [We]1375-we ’ll do with a light if [we]1375-we ’re going [upstairs]1374-upstairs . ’[0-the la - dle] [He]0-the la - dle lit another lamp , and , with bowed back , led the way slowly up the steep and worn stairs and along a tiny passage , into [a room which did not give on [the street]319-the street]1376-a room which did not give on the street but looked out on [a cobbled yard]1378-a cobbled yard and a forest of chimney - pots . [Winston]132-winston noticed that the furniture was still arranged as though [the

19841 room]1379-the 19841 room were meant to be lived in . There was a strip of car - pet on the floor , a picture or two on the walls , and a deep , slatternly arm - chair drawn up to the fireplace . An old - fash - ioned glass clock with a twelve - hour face was ticking away on the mantelpiece . Under the window , and occupying nearly a quarter of [the room]348-the room , was an enormous bed with the mattress still on it . ‘ [We]1375-we lived [here]3512-here till [[my]665-the old man wife]3513-my wife died , ’[665-the old man] said [the old man]665-the old man half apologetically . ‘ [I]665-the old man ’m[665-the old man] selling the furniture off by little and little . Now that ’s a beautiful mahogany bed , or at least it would be if [you]1382-you could get the bugs out of it . But [I]0-the la - dle dare say [you]665-the old man ’d find it a little bit cumbersome . ’ [He]665-the old man was holdlng the lamp high up , so as to illuminate [the whole room]356-the whole room , and in the warm dim light [the place]3337-the place looked curiously inviting . The thought flitted through [Winston]132-winston ’s mind that it would probably be quite easy to rent [the room]348-the room for a few dollars a week , if [he]132-winston dared to take the risk . 198418 for several seconds wondering vaguely what to do , then turned round and began to retrace [his]132-winston steps . [He]132-winston sat staring at the marbled cover of the book , trying without success to shut the voice out of [his]132-winston consciousness . It was at night that [they]1441-they came for [you]1442-you , always at night . The proper thing was to kill [yourself]1442-you before [they]1441-they got [you]1442-you . 19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com kill [yourself]1442-you in a world where firearms , or any quick and certain poison , were completely unprocurable . [He]132-winston thought with a kind of astonishment of the biological uselessness of pain and fear , the treachery of the human body which always freezes into inertia at exactly the moment when a special effort is needed . [He]132-winston might have silenced [the dark- haired girl]1444-the dark- haired girl if only [he]132-winston had acted quickly enough : but precisely because of the extremity of [his]132-winston danger [he]132-winston had lost the power to act . It struck [him]132-winston that in moments of crisis one is nev - er fighting against [an external enemy]1445-an external enemy , but always against [one]441-one ’s own body . Even now , in spite of the gin , the dull ache in [his]132-winston belly made consecutive thought impossible . And it is the same , [he]132-winston perceived , in all seemingly heroic or trag - ic situations . On the battlefield , in [the torture chamber]1447-the torture chamber , on [a sinking ship]616-a sinking ship , the issues that [you]1449-you are fighting for are al - ways forgotten , because the body swells up until it fills the universe , and even when [you]1449-you are not paralysed by fright or screaming with pain , life is a moment - to - moment struggle against hunger or cold or sleeplessness , against a sour stom - ach or an aching tooth . [He]132-winston opened the diary . It was important to write some - thing down . [The woman on the telescreen]1450-the woman on the telescreen had started a new song . 198410]1453-everybody 198410 knew of [them]1453-everybody 198410 ) there was the routine of confession that had to be gone through : the grovelling on the floor and scream - ing for mercy , the crack of broken bones , the smashed teeth , and bloody clots of hair . Probably [she]439-the girl with dark hair had crushed [her]439-the girl with dark hair hand while swing - ing round one of the big kaleidoscopes on which the plots of novels were ‘ roughed in ’[439-the girl with dark hair] . It was a common accident in [the Fiction Department]409-the fiction department . [They]1464-they were perhaps four metres apart when [the girl]3411-the girl stum - bled and fell almost flat on [her]3411-the girl face . A sharp cry of pain was wrung out of [her]3411-the girl . [She]3411-the girl must have fallen right on the injured arm . [Winston]132-winston stopped short . [The girl]3411-the girl had risen to [her]3411-the girl knees . [Her]3411-the girl face had turned a milky yellow colour against which [her]3411-the girl mouth stood out redder than ever . [Her]3411-the girl eyes were fixed on [his]132-winston , with an appealing expression that looked more like fear than pain . A curious emotion stirred in [Winston]132-winston ’s heart . Already [he]132-winston had instinctively started forward

198414 to help [her]3411-the girl . [She]3411-the girl had regained some of [her]3411-the girl colour , and appeared very much better . ‘ It ’s nothing , ’[3411-the girl] [she]3411-the girl repeated shortly . ‘ [I]3411-the girl only gave [my]3411-the girl wrist a bit of a bang . Thanks , [comrade]3329-comrade ! ’[3411-the girl] And with that [she]3411-the girl walked on in the direction in which [she]3411-the girl had been going , as briskly as though it had really been nothing . The whole incident could not have taken as much as half a minute . Not to let [one]441-one ’s feelings appear in one ’s face was a habit that had acquired the status of an instinct , and in any case [they]1471-they had been standing straight in front of a telescreen when the thing happened . Nevertheless it had been very difficult not to betray a momentary surprise , for in the two or three seconds while [he]132-winston was helping [her]3411-the girl up [the girl]3411-the girl had slipped something into [his]132-winston hand . There was no question that [she]3411-the girl had done it intentionally . It was some - thing small and flat . As [he]132-winston passed through the lavatory door [he]132-winston transferred it to [his]132-winston pocket and felt it with the tips of [his]132-winston fingers . It was a scrap of paper folded into a square . While [he]132-winston stood at the urinal [he]132-winston managed , with a little

1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com more fingering , to get it unfolded . Obviously there must be a message of some kind written on it . For a moment [he]132-winston was tempted to take it into one of the water - closets and read it at once . But that would be shocking folly , as [he]132-winston well knew . There was no place where [you]1473-you could be more certain that the telescreens were watched continuously . [He]132-winston went back to [his]132-winston cubicle , sat down , threw the frag - ment of paper casually among the other papers on the desk , put on [his]132-winston spectacles and hitched the speakwrite towards [him]132-winston . ‘ Five minutes , ’[132-winston] [he]132-winston told [himself]132-winston , ‘ five minutes at the very least ! ’[132-winston] [His]132-winston heart bumped in [his]132-winston breast with frightening loudness . Fortunately the piece of work [he]132-winston was engaged on was mere routine , the rectification of a long list of figures , not needing close attention . Whatever was written on the paper , it must have some kind of political meaning . So far as [he]132-winston could see there were two possibilities . One , much the more likely , was that [the girl]3411-the girl was [an agent of the Thought Police]422-an agent of the thought police , just as [he]132-winston had feared . [He]132-winston did not know why [the Thought Police]569-the thought police should choose to deliver [their]569-the thought police messages in such a fashion , but perhaps [they]569-the thought police had [their]569-the thought police reasons . The thing that was written on the paper might be a threat , a summons , an order to commit suicide , a trap of some description . But there was another , wilder possibility that kept raising its head , though [he]132-winston tried vain - ly to suppress it . This was , that the message did not come from the Thought Police at all , but from some kind of un - derground organization . Perhaps [the Brotherhood]473-the brotherhood existed after all ! Perhaps [the girl]3411-the girl was part of it ! No doubt the idea was absurd , but it had sprung into [his]132-winston mind in the very in -

19841 stant of feeling the scrap of paper in [his]132-winston hand . It was not till a couple of minutes later that the other , more probable ex - planation had occurred to [him]132-winston . And even now , though [his]132-winston intellect told [him]132-winston that the message probably meant death — still , that was not what [he]132-winston believed , and the unreasonable hope persisted , and [his]132-winston heart banged , and it was with diffi - culty that [he]132-winston kept [his]132-winston voice from trembling as [he]132-winston murmured [his]132-winston figures into the speakwrite . [He]132-winston rolled up the completed bundle of work and slid it into the pneumatic tube . Eight minutes had gone by . [He]132-winston re- adjusted [his]132-winston spectacles on [his]132-winston nose , sighed , and drew the next batch of work towards [him]132-winston , with the scrap of paper on top of it . [He]132-winston flattened it out . On it was written , in a large un- formed handwriting : [I]0-the la - dle LOVE [YOU]1479-you . For several seconds [he]132-winston was too stunned even to throw the incriminating thing into the memory hole . When [he]132-winston did so , although [he]132-winston knew very well the danger of showing too much interest , [he]132-winston could not resist reading it once again , just to make sure that the words were really there . For the rest of the morning it was very difficult to work . What was even worse than having to focus [his]132-winston mind on a series of niggling jobs was the need to conceal [his]132-winston agitation from the telescreen . [He]132-winston felt as though a fire were burning in [his]132-winston belly . Lunch in [the hot , crowded , noise - filled canteen]1480-the hot , crowded , noise - filled canteen was torment . [He]132-winston had hoped to be alone for a little while during the lunch hour , but as bad luck would have it the

1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com imbecile [Parsons]141-parsons flopped down beside [him]132-winston , the tang of [his]132-winston sweat almost defeating the tinny smell of stew , and kept up a stream of talk about the preparations for Hate Week . [He]132-winston was particularly enthusiastic about a papier - mache model of [Big Brother]126-big brother ’s head , two metres wide , which was being made for the occasion by [[his]132-winston daughter]1481-his daughter ’s troop of Spies . The irri - tating thing was that in the racket of voices [Winston]132-winston could hardly hear what [Parsons]141-parsons was saying , and was constantly having to ask for some fatuous remark to be repeated . Just once [he]132-winston caught a glimpse of [the girl]3411-the girl , at a table with [two oth - er girls at [the far end of [the room]348-the room]1484-the far end of the room]1483-two oth - er girls at the far end of the room . [She]3411-the girl appeared not to have seen [him]132-winston , and [he]132-winston did not look in that direction again . The afternoon was more bearable . Immediately after lunch there arrived a delicate , difficult piece of work which would take several hours and necessitated putting everything else aside . It consisted in falsifying a series of production re - ports of two years ago , in such a way as to cast discredit on [a prominent member of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party , who was now under a cloud]1486-a prominent member of the inner party , who was now under a cloud . This was the kind of thing that [Winston]132-winston was good at , and for more than two hours [he]132-winston succeeded in shutting [the girl]3411-the girl out of [his]132-winston mind altogether . Then the memory of [her]3411-the girl face came back , and with it a raging , intolerable desire to be alone . Until [he]132-winston could be alone it was impossible to think this new development out . Tonight was one of [his]132-winston nights at [the Community Centre]50-the community centre . [He]132-winston wolfed another tasteless meal in [the canteen]351-the canteen , hurried off to [the Centre]1213-the centre , took part in the solemn foolery of [a ‘ discussion group]3537-a ‘ discussion group ’[132-winston] , played two games of table tennis , swallowed several glasses of gin , and sat for half an hour through a lecture entitled ‘ [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc in relation to[132-winston]

198418 chess ’ . [His]132-winston soul writhed with boredom , but for once [he]132-winston had had no impulse to shirk [his]132-winston evening at [the Centre]1213-the centre . At the sight of the words [I]132-winston LOVE [YOU]3539-you the desire to stay alive had welled up in [him]132-winston , and the taking of minor risks suddenly seemed stupid . It was not till twenty - three hours , when [he]132-winston was [home]366-home and in bed — in the darkness , where [you]3539-you were safe even from the telescreen so long as [you]3539-you kept silent — that [he]132-winston was able to think continuously . It was a physical problem that had to be solved : how to get in touch with [the girl]3411-the girl and arrange a meeting . [He]132-winston did not consider any longer the possibility that [she]3411-the girl might be laying some kind of trap for [him]132-winston . [He]132-winston knew that it was not so , because of [her]3411-the girl unmistakable agitation when [she]3411-the girl handed [him]132-winston the note . Obviously [she]3411-the girl had been frightened out of [her]3411-the girl wits , as well [she]3411-the girl might be . Nor did the idea of refusing [her]3411-the girl advances even cross [his]132-winston mind . Only five nights ago [he]132-winston had contemplated smashing [her]3411-the girl skull in with a cobblestone , but that was of no importance . [He]132-winston thought of [her]3411-the girl naked , youth - ful body , as [he]132-winston had seen it in [his]132-winston dream . 1984140 ably [she]3411-the girl had been changed on to a later shift . [They]1507-they passed each other without a glance . 1984148 Chapter 2 [W inston]148-w inston picked [his]132-winston way up [the lane]1593-the lane through dappled light and shade , stepping out into pools of gold wher - ever the boughs parted . Under the trees to the left of [him]132-winston the ground was misty with bluebells . The air seemed to kiss [one]441-one ’s skin . It was the second of May . From somewhere deep- er in the heart of the wood came the droning of ring doves . [He]132-winston was a bit early . There had been no difficulties about the journey , and [the girl]3411-the girl was so evidently experienced that [he]132-winston was less frightened than [he]132-winston would normally have been . Presumably [she]3411-the girl could be trusted to find [a safe place]1596-a safe place . In general [you]1597-you could not assume that [you]1597-you were much safer in [the country]1598-the country than in [London]2-london . 19841 almost at the level of [their]1642-them faces . Perhaps it had not seen [them]1642-them . It was in the sun , [they]1642-them in the shade . It spread out its wings , fitted them carefully into place again , ducked its head for a moment , as though making a sort of obeisance to the sun , and then began to pour forth a torrent of song . In the afternoon hush the volume of sound was startling . [Win - ston]132-winston and [Julia]207-julia clung together , fascinated . The music went on and on , minute after minute , with astonishing variations , never once repeating itself , almost as though the bird were deliberately showing off its virtuosity . Sometimes it stopped for a few seconds , spread out and resettled its wings , then swelled its speckled breast and again burst into song . [Win - ston]132-winston watched it with a sort of vague reverence . For whom , for what , was that bird singing ? [No mate]1645-no mate , [no rival]1646-no rival was watch - ing it . But [you]1657-you could not have pure love or pure lust nowadays . No emo - tion was pure , because everything was mixed up with fear and hatred . [Their]1660-their embrace had been a battle , the climax a victory . It was a blow struck against the Party . It was a po - litical act .

198410 Chapter 3 ‘ [We]3584-we can come here once again , ’[207-julia] said [Julia]207-julia . ‘ It ’s generally safe to use any hide - out twice . 198418 For how could the fear , the hatred , and the lunatic credulity which [the Party]418-the party needed in [[its]418-the party members]1019-its members be kept at the right pitch , except by bottling down some powerful instinct and using it as a driving force ? The sex impulse was dangerous to [the Party]418-the party , and [the Party]14-the party had turned it to account . [They]1019-its members had played a similar trick with the instinct of parenthood . [The family]1733-the family could not actually be abolished , and , indeed , [people]324-people were encouraged to be fond of [[their]324-people children]1735-their children , in almost the old - fashioned way . [The children]535-the children , on the other hand , were systematically turned against [[their]535-the children parents]1737-their parents and taught to spy on [them]535-the children and report [their]535-the children deviations . [The family]1733-the family had become in effect an extension of the Thought Police . It was a device by means of which [everyone]503-everyone could be surrounded night and day by [informers who knew [him]132-winston intimately]1740-informers who knew him intimately . Abruptly [his]132-winston mind went back to [Katharine]177-katharine . But what really recalled [her]177-katharine to [him]132-winston at this moment was the stifling heat of the afternoon , which had brought the sweat out on [his]132-winston forehead . [He]132-winston began telling [Julia]207-julia of something that had happened , or rather had failed to happen , on another sweltering summer afternoon , eleven years ago . [They]1733-the family had only lagged behind the others for a couple of min - utes , but [they]1733-the family took a wrong turning , and presently found [themselves]1733-the family pulled up short by the edge of [an old chalk quarry]1741-an old chalk quarry . It was a sheer drop of ten or twenty metres , with

19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com boulders at the bottom . There was [nobody of whom [they]1733-the family could ask the way]1742-nobody of whom they could ask the way . 19841 Chapter 4 [W inston]148-w inston looked round [the shabby little room above [[Mr Charrington]201-mr charrington ’s shop]1758-mr charrington ’s shop]1757-the shabby little room above mr charrington ’s shop . And next time [we]1839-we come here [I]3553-dear ’ll bring some plaster and bung it up properly . ’[3553-dear] Already the black instant of panic was half - forgotten . What was even better than the taste of the coffee was the silky texture given to it by the sugar , a thing [Winston]132-winston had almost forgotten after years of saccharine . [He]132-winston turned over towards the light and lay gazing into the glass paperweight . The inexhaustibly interesting thing was not the fragment of coral but the in - terior of the glass itself . There was such a depth of it , and yet it was almost as transparent as air . It was as though the surface of the glass had been the arch of the sky , enclosing a tiny world with its atmosphere complete . [He]132-winston had the feel - ing that [he]132-winston could get inside it , and that in fact [he]132-winston was inside

198418 Chapter 5 S yme had vanished . A morning came , and [he]132-winston was miss - ing from work : [a few thoughtless people]1849-a few thoughtless people commented on [his]132-winston absence . On the next day [nobody]398-nobody mentioned [him]132-winston . On the third day [Winston]132-winston went into the vestibule of [the Re - cords Department]1851-the re - cords department to look at the notice - board . One of the notices carried a printed list of [the members of [the Chess Committee]1853-the chess committee]1852-the members of the chess committee , of whom [Syme]160-syme had been one . It looked almost exactly as it had looked before — nothing had been crossed out — but it was one name shorter . It was enough . [Syme]160-syme had ceased to exist : [he]160-syme had never existed . The weather was baking hot . In [the labyrinthine Ministry]1854-the labyrinthine ministry [the windowless , air - conditioned rooms]1855-the windowless , air - conditioned rooms kept [their]1855-the windowless , air - conditioned rooms normal temperature , but outside the pavements scorched one ’s feet and the stench of the Tubes at the rush hours was [a hor - ror]1856-a hor - ror . The preparations for Hate Week were in full swing , and [the staffs of [all the Ministries]1858-all the ministries]1857-the staffs of all the ministries were working overtime . Pro - cessions , meetings , military parades , lectures , waxworks , displays , film shows , telescreen programmes all had to be organized ; stands had to be erected , effigies built , slogans coined , songs written , rumours circulated , photographs faked . [[Julia]207-julia ’s unit in [the Fiction Department]409-the fiction department]1859-julia ’s unit in the fiction department had been tak - en off the production of novels and was rushing out a series of atrocity pamphlets . [Winston]132-winston , in addition to [his]132-winston regular work , spent long periods every day in going through back

18Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com files of ‘ The Times ’[132-winston] and altering and embellishing news items which were to be quoted in speeches . Late at night , when crowds of rowdy proles roamed [the streets]3435-the streets , [the town]362-the town had a curiously febrile air . The rocket bombs crashed of - tener than ever , and sometimes in the far distance there were enormous explosions which [no one]1135-no one could explain and about which there were wild rumours . The new tune which was to be the theme - song of Hate Week ( the Hate Song , it was called ) had already been com - posed and was being endlessly plugged on the telescreens . It had a savage , barking rhythm which could not exactly be called music , but resembled the beating of a drum . Roared out by hundreds of voices to the tramp of marching feet , it was terrifying . [The proles]1045-the proles had taken a fancy to it , and in [the midnight streets]1865-the midnight streets [it]1045-the proles competed with the still - popular ‘ It was only a hopeless fancy ’[1045-the proles] . [The Parsons children]1866-the parsons children played it at all hours of the night and day , unbearably , on a comb and a piece of toilet paper . [Winston]132-winston ’s evenings were fuller than ever . [Squads of [volunteers]1868-volunteers , organized by [Parsons]141-parsons]1867-squads of volunteers , organized by parsons , were pre - paring [the street]319-the street for Hate Week , stitching banners , painting posters , erecting flagstaffs on the roofs , and perilously sling - ing wires across [the street]319-the street for the reception of [streamers]1871-streamers . [Parsons]141-parsons boasted that [Victory Mansions]1-victory mansions alone would display four hundred metres of bunting . [He]132-winston was in [his]132-winston native ele - ment and as happy as a lark . The heat and the manual work had even given [him]132-winston a pretext for reverting to shorts and an open shirt in the evenings . [He]132-winston was everywhere at once , pushing , pulling , sawing , hammering , improvising , jolly - ing [everyone]503-everyone along with comradely exhortations and giving

1984188 out from every fold of [his]132-winston body what seemed an inexhaust - ible supply of acrid - smelling sweat . A new poster had suddenly appeared all over [London]2-london . It had no caption , and represented simply the monstrous fig - ure of [a Eurasian soldier]1873-a eurasian soldier , three or four metres high , striding forward with expressionless Mongolian face and enor - mous boots , a submachine gun pointed from [his]132-winston hip . From whatever angle [you]1874-you looked at the poster , the muzzle of the gun , magnified by the foreshortening , seemed to be point - ed straight at [you]1874-you . The thing had been plastered on every blank space on every wall , even outnumbering the por - traits of [Big Brother]126-big brother . The proles , normally apathetic about the war , were being lashed into one of [their]1867-squads of volunteers , organized by parsons periodical fren - zies of patriotism . [The rat]1891-the rat had never come back , but the bugs had multiplied hideously in the heat . It did not seem to matter . Dirty or clean , [the room]348-the room was paradise . As soon as [they]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction arrived [they]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction would sprinkle everything with pepper bought on [the black market]1893-the black market , tear off [their]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction clothes , and make love with sweating bodies , then fall asleep and wake to find that the bugs had rallied and were massing for the counter - attack . Four , five , six — seven times [they]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction met during the month of June . [Winston]132-winston had dropped [his]132-winston habit of drinking gin at all hours . [He]132-winston seemed to have lost the need for it . [He]132-winston had grown fatter , [his]132-winston varicose ulcer had subsided , leaving only a brown stain on the skin above [his]132-winston ankle , [his]132-winston fits of cough - ing in the early morning had stopped . The process of life had ceased to be intolerable , [he]132-winston had no longer any impulse to make faces at the telescreen or shout curses at the top of [his]132-winston voice . Now that [they]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction had a secure hiding - place , almost [a home]1894-a home , it did not even seem a hardship that [they]1887-an old couple who were suspected of being of foreign extraction could only meet infrequently and for a couple of hours at a time . What mattered was that [the room]348-the room over [the junk - shop]1360-the junk - shop should exist . To know that it was there , inviolate , was almost the same as being in it . [The room]348-the room was [a world]1898-a world , a pocket of the past where extinct animals could walk . [Mr Charrington]201-mr charrington , thought [Win - ston]132-winston , was another extinct animal . [He]201-mr charrington usually stopped to talk with [Mr Charrington]201-mr charrington for a few minutes on [his]201-mr charrington way [upstairs]1374-upstairs . [The old man]665-the old man seemed seldom or never to go out of doors ,

1984190 and on the other hand to have [almost no customers]1901-almost no customers . [He]201-mr charrington led a ghostlike existence between [the tiny , dark shop]1902-the tiny , dark shop , and an even tinier back kitchen where [he]201-mr charrington prepared [his]201-mr charrington meals and which contained , among other things , an unbelievably ancient gramophone with an enormous horn . [He]201-mr charrington seemed glad of the opportunity to talk . Wandering about among [his]201-mr charrington worthless stock , with [his]201-mr charrington long nose and thick spectacles and [his]201-mr charrington bowed shoulders in the velvet jacket , [he]201-mr charrington had always vaguely the air of being [a collector]1903-a collector rather than [a tradesman]1904-a tradesman . [He]132-winston had dragged out from the corners of [his]132-winston memory some more fragments of forgotten rhymes . [Both of [them]3354-both of them]3354-both of them knew — in a way , it was never out of [their]3354-both of them minds that what was now happening could not last long . There were times when the fact of impending death seemed as palpable as the bed [they]3354-both of them lay on , and [they]3354-both of them would cling to - gether with a sort of despairing sensuality , like a damned soul grasping at [his]132-winston last morsel of pleasure when the clock

191Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com is within five minutes of striking . But there were also times when [they]3354-both of them had the illusion not only of safety but of per - manence . Often [they]3354-both of them gave [themselves]3354-both of them up to daydreams of escape . [Their]3354-both of them luck would hold indefinitely , and [they]3354-both of them would carry on [their]3354-both of them intrigue , just like this , for the remainder of [their]3354-both of them natural lives . Or [Katharine]177-katharine would die , and by [subtle manoeuvrings Winston]132-winston and [Julia]207-julia would succeed in get - ting married . Or [they]3354-both of them would commit suicide together . Or [they]3354-both of them would disappear , alter [themselves]3354-both of them out of recognition , learn to speak with proletarian accents , get jobs in [a factory]1910-a factory and live out [their]3354-both of them lives undetected in [a back - street]1911-a back - street . It was all nonsense , as [they]3354-both of them both knew . In reality there was no es - cape . Even the one plan that was practicable , suicide , [they]3354-both of them had no intention of carrying out . To hang on from day to day and from week to week , spinning out a present that had no future , seemed an unconquerable instinct , just as [one]441-one ’s lungs will always draw the next breath so long as there is air available . Sometimes , too , [they]3354-both of them talked of engaging in active rebel - lion against [the Party]418-the party , but with no notion of how to take the first step . Even if [the fabulous Brotherhood]1914-the fabulous brotherhood was a real - ity , there still remained the difficulty of finding one ’s way into it . [He]1914-the fabulous brotherhood told [her]177-katharine of the strange intimacy that existed , or

198419 seemed to exist , between [himself]1914-the fabulous brotherhood and [O’Brien]216-o’brien , and of the impulse [he]1914-the fabulous brotherhood sometimes felt , simply to walk into [O’Brien]216-o’brien ’s presence , announce that [he]1914-the fabulous brotherhood was [the enemy of [the Party]418-the party]1915-the enemy of the party , and demand [his]1914-the fabulous brotherhood help . [She]177-katharine was used to judg - ing people by [their]3354-both of them faces , and it seemed natural to [her]177-katharine that [Winston]132-winston should believe [O’Brien]216-o’brien to be trustworthy on the strength of a single flash of the eyes . Moreover [she]177-katharine took it for granted that [everyone]503-everyone , or nearly [everyone]503-everyone , secretly hated the Party and would break the rules if [he]132-winston thought it safe to do so . But [she]177-katharine refused to believe that widespread , organized opposition existed or could exist . The tales about [Goldstein]132-winston and [[his]132-winston underground army]1919-his underground army , [she]177-katharine said , were simply a lot of rubbish which [the Party]418-the party had invented for its own purposes and which [you]1921-you had to pretend to believe in . When public trials were happening [she]177-katharine had taken [her]177-katharine place in the detach - ments from [the Youth League who surrounded [the courts]1922-the courts from morning to night , chanting at intervals ‘ Death to [the traitors]3647-the traitors]3646-the youth league who surrounded the courts from morning to night , chanting at intervals ‘ death to the traitors ! ’[3646-the youth league who surrounded the courts from morning to night , chanting at intervals ‘ death to the traitors] During the Two Minutes Hate [she]177-katharine always excelled all others in shouting insults at [Goldstein]132-winston . Yet [she]177-katharine had only the dimmest idea of who [Goldstein]132-winston was and what doctrines [he]132-winston was supposed to represent . [She]177-katharine had grown up since the Revolution and was too young to remember the ideological battles of the fifties and sixties . Such a thing as an indepen - dent political movement was outside [her]177-katharine imagination : and

19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com in any case [the Party]418-the party was invincible . It would always ex - ist , and it would always be the same . [You]1924-you could only rebel against it by secret disobedience or , at most , by isolated acts of violence such as killing [somebody]1770-somebody or blowing something up . In some ways [she]177-katharine was far more acute than [Winston]132-winston , and far less susceptible to Party propaganda . Once when [he]132-winston happened in some connexion to mention the war against [Eurasia]8-eurasia , [she]177-katharine startled [him]132-winston by saying casually that in [her]177-katharine opin- ion the war was not happening . [She]177-katharine also stirred a sort of envy in [him]132-winston by telling [him]132-winston that during the Two Minutes Hate [her]177-katharine great difficulty was to avoid bursting out laughing . But [she]177-katharine only questioned the teachings of the Party when [they]1926-they in some way touched upon [her]177-katharine own life . Often [she]177-katharine was ready to accept the official mythology , simply because the difference between truth and falsehood did not seem important to [her]177-katharine . [She]177-katharine believed , for instance , having learnt it at [school]1005-school , that [the Party]418-the party had invented [aeroplanes]1929-aeroplanes . ( In [[his]132-winston own schooldays]1930-his own schooldays , [Winston]132-winston remembered , in the late fifties , it was only the helicopter that [the Party]418-the party claimed to have invented ; a dozen years later , when [Julia]207-julia was at [school]1005-school , it was already claiming [the aeroplane]1933-the aeroplane ; one generation more , and it would be claiming the steam engine . ) And when [he]132-winston told [her]207-julia that aeroplanes had been in existence before [he]132-winston was born and long before the Revolution , the fact struck [her]207-julia as totally uninteresting . After all , what did it matter who had

1984194 invented aeroplanes ? It was rather more of a shock to [him]132-winston when [he]132-winston discovered from some chance remark that [she]207-julia did not remember that [Oceania]5-oceania , four years ago , had been at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia and at peace with [Eurasia]8-eurasia . [He]132-winston argued with [her]207-julia about it for perhaps a quarter of an hour . 19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com to the old days , before the Revolution . [I]0-the la - dle barely knew [them]1937-they by sight . ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] Then what was there to worry about ? [People]324-people are being killed off all the time , are n’t [they]324-people ? ’ [He]324-people tried to make [her]3655-her understand . ‘[324-people] This was an excep - tional case . It was n’t just a question of [somebody being killed]1939-somebody being killed . Do [you]1940-you realize that the past , starting from yester - day , has been actually abolished ? If it survives anywhere , it ’s in a few solid objects with no words attached to [them]324-people , like that lump of glass there . Already [we]1941-we know almost lit - erally nothing about the Revolution and the years before the Revolution . Every record has been destroyed or falsi - fied , every book has been rewritten , every picture has been repainted , every statue and [street]1942-street and [building]1943-building has been renamed , every date has been altered . And that process is continuing day by day and minute by minute . History has stopped . Nothing exists except an endless present in which [the Party]418-the party is always right . [I]0-the la - dle know , of course , that the past is falsified , but it would never be possible for [me]0-the la - dle to prove it , even when [I]0-the la - dle did the falsification [myself]0-the la - dle . After the thing is done , no evidence ever remains . The only evidence is inside [my]0-the la - dle own mind , and [I]0-the la - dle do n’t know with any certainty that any other human being shares [my]0-the la - dle memories . Just in that one instance , in [my]0-the la - dle whole life , [I]0-the la - dle did possess actual concrete evi - dence after the event — years after it . ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] And what good was that ? ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] It was no good , because [I]0-the la - dle threw it away a few minutes lat- er . But if the same thing happened today , [I]0-the la - dle should keep it . ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] Well , [I]0-the la - dle would n’t ! ’ said [Julia]207-julia . ‘[0-the la - dle] [I]0-the la - dle ’m quite ready to take[0-the la - dle]

198419 risks , but only for something worth while , not for bits of old newspaper . What could [you]1940-you have done with it even if [you]1940-you had kept it ? ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] Not much , perhaps . But it was evidence . It might have planted a few doubts here and there , supposing that [I]0-the la - dle ’d dared to show it to [anybody]1072-anybody . [I]0-the la - dle do n’t imagine that [we]1946-we can alter anything in [our]1946-we own lifetime . But one can imagine lit - tle knots of resistance springing up here and there — small groups of people banding [themselves]1947-themselves together , and gradu - ally growing , and even leaving a few records behind , so that [the next generations]1948-the next generations can carry on where [we]1946-we leave off . ’ ‘[0-the la - dle] [I]0-the la - dle ’m not interested in [the next generation]3656-the next generation , [dear]3553-dear . [I]0-the la - dle ’m[0-the la - dle] inter- ested in [US]1949-us . ’ ‘[1950-she] [You]1950-she ’re only [a rebel from the waist downwards]3658-a rebel from the waist downwards , ’[0-the la - dle] [he]0-the la - dle told [her]1950-she . [She]1950-she thought this brilliantly witty and flung [her]1950-she arms round [him]0-the la - dle in delight . In the ramifications of party doctrine [she]1950-she had not the faintest interest . Whenever [he]0-the la - dle began to talk of the princi - ples of Ingsoc , doublethink , the mutability of the past , and the denial of objective reality , and to use Newspeak words , [she]1950-she became bored and confused and said that [she]1950-she never paid any attention to that kind of thing . [One]441-one knew that it was all rubbish , so why let [oneself]1952-oneself be worried by it ? [She]1950-she knew when to cheer and when to boo , and that was all one needed . If [he]0-the la - dle persisted in talking of such subjects , [she]1950-she had a disconcerting habit of falling asleep . [She]1950-she was one of [those people who can go to sleep at any hour]1953-those people who can go to sleep at any hour and in any position . Talking to [her]1950-she , [he]0-the la - dle realized how easy it was to present an appearance of or -

19Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com thodoxy while having no grasp whatever of what orthodoxy meant . In a way , the world - view of [the Party]418-the party imposed itself most successfully on [people]324-people incapable of understanding it . [They]324-people could be made to accept the most flagrant violations of reality , because [they]324-people never fully grasped the enormity of what was demanded of [them]324-people , and were not sufficiently interested in public events to notice what was happening . By lack of understanding [they]324-people remained sane . [They]324-people simply swallowed everything , and what [they]324-people swallowed did [them]324-people no harm , because it left no residue behind , just as a grain of corn will pass undigested through the body of a bird .

1984198 Chapter 6 [I]0-the la - dle t had happened at last . The expected message had come . All [his]0-the la - dle life , it seemed to [him]0-the la - dle , [he]0-the la - dle had been waiting for this to happen . [He]0-the la - dle was walking down the long corridor at [the Minis]586-the minis - try and [he]0-the la - dle was almost at the spot where [Julia]207-julia had slipped the note into [his]0-the la - dle hand when [he]0-the la - dle became aware that some - one larger than [himself]0-the la - dle was walking just behind [him]0-the la - dle . [The person]1957-the person , whoever it was , gave a small cough , evidently as a prelude to speaking . [Winston]132-winston stopped abruptly and turned . It was [O’Brien]216-o’brien . At last [they]324-people were face to face , and it seemed that [his]132-winston only impulse was to run away . [His]132-winston heart bounded violently . [He]132-winston would have been incapable of speaking . [O’Brien]216-o’brien , however , had continued forward in the same movement , laying a friendly hand for a moment on [Winston]132-winston ’s arm , so that [the two of [them]607-the two of them]607-the two of them were walking side by side . 01Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com be found , ’ was what [O’Brien]216-o’brien had been saying to [him]216-o’brien . [Per - haps]3664-per - haps there would even be a message concealed somewhere in the dictionary . But at any rate , one thing was certain . The conspiracy that [he]216-o’brien had dreamed of did exist , and [he]216-o’brien had reached the outer edges of it . [He]148-w inston had moved from thoughts to words , and now from words to actions . The last step was something that would happen in the Ministry of Love . [He]148-w inston had accepted it . The end was contained in the be - ginning . But it was frightening : or , more exactly , it was like a foretaste of death , like being a little less alive . Even while [he]148-w inston was speaking to [O’Brien]216-o’brien , when the meaning of the words had sunk in , a chilly shuddering feeling had taken posses - sion of [his]148-w inston body . 19840 Chapter 7 [W inston]148-w inston had woken up with [his]148-w inston eyes full of tears . [Ju - lia]196-ju - lia rolled sleepily against [him]148-w inston , murmuring something that might have been ‘ What ’s the matter ? ’[196-ju - lia] ‘ [I]148-w inston dreamt — ’[148-w inston] [he]148-w inston began , and stopped short . It was too com- plex to be put into words . There was the dream itself , and there was a memory connected with it that had swum into [his]148-w inston mind in the few seconds after waking . [He]148-w inston lay back with [his]148-w inston eyes shut , still sodden in the atmo - sphere of the dream . It was a vast , luminous dream in which [his]148-w inston whole life seemed to stretch out before [him]148-w inston like [a land - scape]1973-a land - scape on a summer evening after rain . It had all occurred inside the glass paperweight , but the surface of the glass was the dome of the sky , and inside the dome everything was flooded with clear soft light in which [one]441-one could see into interminable distances . The dream had also been compre - hended by — indeed , in some sense it had consisted in — a gesture of the arm made by [[his]148-w inston mother]602-his mother , and made again thirty years later by [the Jewish woman [he]148-w inston had seen on the news film]1976-the jewish woman he had seen on the news film , trying to shelter [the small boy]1977-the small boy from the bullets , before [the helicopter]387-the helicopter blew [them]387-the helicopter both to pieces . ‘ Do [you]207-julia know , ’[148-w inston] [he]148-w inston said , ‘ that until this moment [I]148-w inston believed [I]148-w inston had murdered [[my]148-w inston mother]3666-my mother ? ’[148-w inston] ‘ Why did [you]207-julia murder [her]3666-my mother ? ’[207-julia] said [Julia]207-julia , almost asleep . ‘ [I]207-julia did n’t murder [her]3666-my mother . 0Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com In the dream [he]148-w inston had remembered [his]148-w inston last glimpse of [[his]148-w inston mother]602-his mother , and within a few moments of waking the cluster of small events surrounding it had all come back . It was a memory that [he]148-w inston must have deliberately pushed out of [his]148-w inston consciousness over many years . [He]148-w inston was not certain of the date , but [he]148-w inston could not have been less than ten years old , pos- sibly twelve , when it had happened . [[His]148-w inston father]605-his father had disappeared some time earlier , how much earlier [he]148-w inston could not remember . [He]148-w inston remembered better the rackety , uneasy circumstances of the time : the periodical panics about air - raids and the sheltering in [Tube stations]1981-tube stations , the piles of rubble everywhere , the unintelligible proc - lamations posted at [street corners]1982-street corners , the gangs of [youths in shirts all the same colour]1983-youths in shirts all the same colour , the enormous queues outside [the bakeries]1984-the bakeries , the intermittent machine - gun fire in the dis - tance — above all , the fact that there was never enough to eat . [He]148-w inston remembered long afternoons spent with [other boys in scrounging round dustbins and rubbish heaps]1985-other boys in scrounging round dustbins and rubbish heaps , picking out the ribs of cabbage leaves , potato peelings , sometimes even scraps of stale breadcrust from which [they]1985-other boys in scrounging round dustbins and rubbish heaps carefully scraped away the cinders ; and also in waiting for the pass - ing of [trucks]1986-trucks which travelled over a certain route and were known to carry cattle feed , and which , when [they]1985-other boys in scrounging round dustbins and rubbish heaps jolted over the bad patches in [the road]1566-the road , sometimes spilt [a few frag - ments of oil - cake]1988-a few frag - ments of oil - cake . When [[his]148-w inston father]605-his father disappeared , [[his]148-w inston mother]602-his mother did not show any surprise or any violent grief , but a sudden change came over [her]602-his mother . [She]602-his mother seemed to have become completely spiritless . It was evident even to [Winston]132-winston that [she]602-his mother was waiting for

198404 something that [she]602-his mother knew must happen . [She]602-his mother did everything that was needed — cooked , washed , mended , made the bed , swept the floor , dusted the mantelpiece — always very slowly and with a curious lack of superfluous motion , like [an art - ist]1991-an art - ist ’s lay - figure moving of its own accord . [Her]602-his mother large shapely body seemed to relapse naturally into stillness . For hours at a time [she]602-his mother would sit almost immobile on the bed , nurs - ing [[his]148-w inston young sister]609-his young sister , [a tiny , ailing , very silent child of two or three , with a face made simian by thinness]1993-a tiny , ailing , very silent child of two or three , with a face made simian by thinness . [He]132-winston was aware , in spite of [his]132-winston youthfulness and selfishness , that this was somehow connected with the never - mentioned thing that was about to happen . [He]132-winston remembered [the room where [they]1995-they lived]1994-the room where they lived , [a dark , close- smelling room that seemed half filled by a bed with a white counterpane]1996-a dark , close- smelling room that seemed half filled by a bed with a white counterpane . There was a gas ring in the fender , and a shelf where food was kept , and on the landing outside there was a brown earthenware sink , common to [several rooms]1997-several rooms . [He]132-winston remembered [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother ’s statuesque body bending over the gas ring to stir at something in a saucepan . Above all [he]132-winston remembered [his]132-winston continuous hunger , and the fierce sordid battles at mealtimes . [He]132-winston would ask [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother naggingly , over and over again , why there was not more food , [he]132-winston would shout and storm at [her]602-his mother ( [he]132-winston even remembered the tones of [his]132-winston voice , which was beginning to break prematurely and sometimes boomed in a peculiar way ) , or [he]132-winston would attempt a snivelling note of pathos in [his]132-winston efforts to get more than [his]132-winston share . [[His]132-winston mother]602-his mother was quite ready to give [him]132-winston more than

0Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [his]132-winston share . [She]602-his mother took it for granted that [he]132-winston , ‘ [the boy]3356-the boy ’[132-winston] , should have the biggest portion ; but however much [she]602-his mother gave [him]132-winston [he]132-winston invariably demanded more . At every meal [she]602-his mother would be - seech [him]132-winston not to be selfish and to remember that [[his]132-winston little sister]2001-his little sister was sick and also needed food , but it was no use . [He]132-winston would cry out with rage when [she]602-his mother stopped ladling , [he]132-winston would try to wrench the saucepan and spoon out of [her]602-his mother hands , [he]132-winston would grab bits from [[his]132-winston sister]610-his sister ’s plate . [He]132-winston knew that [he]132-winston was starving the other two , but [he]132-winston could not help it ; [he]132-winston even felt that [he]132-winston had a right to do it . The clamorous hunger in [his]132-winston bel- ly seemed to justify [him]132-winston . Between meals , if [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother did not stand guard , [he]132-winston was constantly pilfering at the wretched store of food on the shelf . One day a chocolate - ration was issued . There had been no such issue for weeks or months past . [He]132-winston remembered quite clearly that precious little morsel of chocolate . It was a two - ounce slab ( [they]2004-they still talked about ounces in those days ) between the three of [them]2004-they . It was obvious that it ought to be divided into three equal parts . Suddenly , as though [he]132-winston were listening to [somebody else]2005-somebody else , [Winston]132-winston heard [himself]132-winston demanding in a loud booming voice that [he]132-winston should be giv - en the whole piece . [[His]132-winston mother]602-his mother told [him]132-winston not to be greedy . In the end [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother broke off three - quarters of the chocolate and gave it to [Winston]132-winston , giving the other quarter to [[his]132-winston sister]610-his sister . [The little girl]548-the little girl took hold

19840 of it and looked at it dully , perhaps not knowing what it was . [Winston]132-winston stood watching [her]548-the little girl for a moment . [He]132-winston never saw [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother again . The dream was still vivid in [his]132-winston mind , especially the en - veloping protecting gesture of the arm in which its whole meaning seemed to be contained . [His]132-winston mind went back to another dream of two months ago . [He]132-winston told [Julia]207-julia the story of [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother ’s disappearance . [He]132-winston would have liked to continue talking about [[his]132-winston mother]602-his mother . [He]132-winston did not suppose , from what [he]132-winston could remember of [her]207-julia , that [she]207-julia had been [an unusual woman]2039-an unusual woman , still less [an intelligent one]2040-an intelligent one ; and yet [she]207-julia had possessed a kind of nobility , a kind of purity , simply because the standards that [she]207-julia obeyed were [private ones]2041-private ones . [Her]207-julia feelings were [her]207-julia own , and could not be altered from outside . It would not have occurred to [her]207-julia that an action which is ineffectual thereby becomes meaningless . If [you]2042-you loved [someone]571-someone , [you]2042-you loved [him]571-someone , and when [you]2042-you had nothing else to give , [you]2042-you still gave [him]571-someone love . When the last of the chocolate was gone , [[his]571-someone mother]602-his mother had clasped [the child]2017-the child in [her]207-julia arms . It was no use , it changed

198408 nothing , it did not produce more chocolate , it did not avert [the child]2017-the child ’s death or [her]207-julia own ; but it seemed natural to [her]207-julia to do it . 19841 Chapter 8 T hey had done it , [they]2058-they had done it at last ! [The room [they]2058-they were standing in]2069-the room they were standing in was long - shaped and softly lit . It occurred to [Winston]132-winston that a synthetic face was perhaps incapable of changing its expression . Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Chapter 9 [W inston]148-w inston was gelatinous with fatigue . [Gelatinous]217-gelatinous was the right word . It had come into [his]217-gelatinous head spontane - ously . [His]217-gelatinous body seemed to have not only the weakness of a jelly , but its translucency . [He]217-gelatinous felt that if [he]217-gelatinous held up [his]217-gelatinous hand [he]217-gelatinous would be able to see the light through it . All the blood and lymph had been drained out of [him]217-gelatinous by an enormous debauch of work , leaving only a frail structure of nerves , bones , and skin . All sensations seemed to be magnified . [His]217-gelatinous overalls fretted [his]217-gelatinous shoulders , the pavement tickled [his]217-gelatinous feet , even the opening and closing of a hand was an effort that made [his]217-gelatinous joints creak . [He]217-gelatinous had worked more than ninety hours in five days . So had everyone else in [the Ministry]350-the ministry . Now it was all over , and [he]217-gelatinous had literally nothing to do , no Party work of any descrip- tion , until tomorrow morning . [He]217-gelatinous could spend six hours in [the hiding - place]2131-the hiding - place and another nine in [his]217-gelatinous own bed . 19848 opened , nor even looked at . On the sixth day of Hate Week , after the processions , the speeches , the shouting , the singing , the banners , the posters , the films , the waxworks , the rolling of drums and squeal - ing of trumpets , the tramp of marching feet , the grinding of [the caterpillars of tanks]2134-the caterpillars of tanks , the roar of massed planes , the booming of guns — after six days of this , when the great or - gasm was quivering to its climax and the general hatred of [Eurasia]218-eurasia had boiled up into such delirium that if [the crowd]1237-the crowd could have got [their]1237-the crowd hands on the 2,000 Eurasian war - crim - inals who were to be publicly hanged on the last day of the proceedings , [they]1237-the crowd would unquestionably have torn [them]1237-the crowd to pieces — at just this moment it had been announced that [Oceania]5-oceania was not after all at war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia . [Oceania]5-oceania was at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia . [Eurasia]8-eurasia was [an ally]2136-an ally . There was , of course , no admission that any change had taken place . Merely it became known , with extreme sud - denness and everywhere at once , that [Eastasia]9-eastasia and not [Eurasia]8-eurasia was [the enemy]977-the enemy . [Winston]132-winston was taking part in a dem - onstration in one of the central [London]2-london squares at the moment when it happened . It was night , and the white fac - es and the scarlet banners were luridly floodlit . 9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com microphone with one hand while the other , enormous at the end of a bony arm , clawed the air menacingly above [his]2144-a little rumpelstiltskin figure head . It was almost impossible to listen to [him]2144-a little rumpelstiltskin figure without being first convinced and then maddened . 19840 the neck of the microphone , [his]2144-a little rumpelstiltskin figure shoulders hunched forward , [his]2144-a little rumpelstiltskin figure free hand clawing at the air , had gone straight on with [his]2144-a little rumpelstiltskin figure speech . [The entire staff of [the Ministry]350-the ministry]2165-the entire staff of the ministry had done likewise . The orders already issu - ing from the telescreen , recalling [them]2165-the entire staff of the ministry to [their]2165-the entire staff of the ministry posts , were hardly necessary . [Oceania]5-oceania was at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia : [Oceania]5-oceania had always been at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia . A large part of the political lit - erature of five years was now completely obsolete . Reports and records of all kinds , newspapers , books , pamphlets , films , sound - tracks , photographs — all had to be rectified at lightning speed . Although no directive was ever issued , it was known that [the chiefs of [the Department]2168-the department]2167-the chiefs of the department intended that within one week no reference to the war with [Eurasia]8-eurasia ,

1Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet or the alliance with [Eastasia]9-eastasia , should remain in existence anywhere . The work was overwhelming , all the more so because the processes that it involved could not be called by [their]2167-the chiefs of the department true names . [Everyone in the Records Department]2169-everyone in the records department worked eighteen hours in the twenty - four , with two three- hour snatches of sleep . Mattresses were brought up from [the cellars]2170-the cellars and pitched all over [the corridors]408-the corridors : meals con - sisted of sandwiches and [Victory Coffee]188-victory coffee wheeled round on trolleys by [attendants]2172-attendants from [the canteen]351-the canteen . Each time that [Winston]132-winston broke off for one of [his]132-winston spells of sleep [he]132-winston tried to leave [his]132-winston desk clear of work , and each time that [he]132-winston crawled back sticky - eyed and aching , it was to find that another shower of paper cylinders had covered the desk like a snow - drift , halfburying the speakwrite and overflowing on to the floor , so that the first job was always to stack them into a neat enough pile to give [him]132-winston room to work . What was worst of all was that the work was by no means purely mechanical . Often it was enough merely to substitute one name for an - other , but any detailed report of events demanded care and imagination . Even the geographical knowledge that one needed in transferring the war from [one part of [the world]318-the world]2174-one part of the world to another was considerable . By the third day [his]132-winston eyes ached unbearably and [his]132-winston spectacles needed wiping every few minutes . It was like struggling with some crushing physical task , something which [one]441-one had the right to refuse and which [one]441-one was never - theless neurotically anxious to accomplish . In so far as [he]132-winston had time to remember it , [he]132-winston was not troubled by the fact that every word [he]132-winston murmured into the speakwrite , every stroke

1984 of [his]132-winston ink - pencil , was a deliberate lie . [He]132-winston was as anxious as [anyone else in [the Department that the forgery]2179-the department that the forgery]2178-anyone else in the department that the forgery should be perfect . On the morning of the sixth day the dribble of cyl - inders slowed down . For as much as half an hour nothing came out of the tube ; then one more cylinder , then nothing . Everywhere at about the same time the work was easing off . A deep and as it were secret sigh went through [the Depart - ment]2180-the depart - ment . A mighty deed , which could never be mentioned , had been achieved . It was now impossible for any human being to prove by documentary evidence that the war with [Eurasia]218-eurasia had ever happened . At twelve hundred it was unexpectedly announced that [all workers in [the Ministry]350-the ministry]2181-all workers in the ministry were free till tomorrow morning . [Winston]132-winston , still carrying the brief - case containing the book , which had remained between [his]132-winston feet while [he]132-winston worked and under [his]132-winston body while [he]132-winston slept , went [home]366-home , shaved [himself]132-winston , and almost fell asleep in [his]132-winston bath , al - though the water was barely more than tepid . With a sort of voluptuous creaking in [his]132-winston joints [he]132-winston climbed the stair above [[Mr Charrington]201-mr charrington ’s shop]1758-mr charrington ’s shop . [He]132-winston was tired , but not sleepy any longer . [He]132-winston opened the window , lit the dirty little oilstove and put on a pan of water for coffee . [Julia]207-julia would arrive presently : meanwhile there was the book . [He]132-winston sat down in the sluttish armchair and undid the straps of the brief - case . A heavy black volume , amateurishly bound , with no name or title on the cover . The print also looked slightly irregular . The pages were worn at the edges , and fell apart , easily , as though the book had passed through many hands . The inscription on the title - page ran :

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com THE THEORY AND PRACTICE OF OLIGARCHICAL COLLECTIVISM by [Emmanuel Goldstein Winston]132-winston began reading : Chapter I Ignorance is Strength Throughout recorded time , and probably since the end of the Neolithic Age , there have been [three kinds of people in [the world]318-the world]2185-three kinds of people in the world , the High , [the Middle]2187-the middle , and [the Low]63-the low . [They]2185-three kinds of people in the world have been subdivided in many ways , [they]2185-three kinds of people in the world have borne count - less different names , and [their]2185-three kinds of people in the world relative numbers , as well as [their]2185-three kinds of people in the world attitude towards one another , have varied from age to age : but the essential structure of society has never altered . Even after enormous upheavals and seemingly irrevocable changes , the same pattern has always reasserted itself , just as a gyroscope will always return to equilibrium , however far it is pushed one way or the other . The aims of [these groups]2188-these groups are entirely irreconcilable ... [Winston]132-winston stopped reading , chiefly in order to appreciate the fact that [he]132-winston was reading , in comfort and safety . [He]132-winston was alone : no telescreen , no ear at the keyhole , no nervous [i]0-the la - dle m - pulse to glance over [his]132-winston shoulder or cover the page with [his]132-winston hand . 19844 dren : in [the room]348-the room itself there was no sound except the insect voice of the clock . [He]132-winston settled deeper into the arm - chair and put [his]132-winston feet up on the fender . It was bliss , it was etemity .
