[He]132-winston went on reading : Chapter III War is Peace The splitting up of [the world]318-the world into [three great super - states]2193-three great super - states was an event which could be and indeed was foreseen before the middle of the twentieth century . With the ab - sorption of [Europe]65-europe by [Russia]66-russia and of [the British Empire]2194-the british empire by [the United States]2195-the united states , two of the three existing powers , [Eurasia]8-eurasia and [Oceania]5-oceania , were already effectively in being . The third , [Eastasia]9-eastasia , only emerged as a distinct unit after another de - cade of confused fighting . The frontiers between [the three super - states]2196-the three super - states are in some places arbitrary , and in others [they]2196-the three super - states fluctuate according to the fortunes of war , but in general [they]2196-the three super - states follow geographical lines . [Eurasia]8-eurasia comprises [the whole of [the northern part of [the European and Asiatic land - mass]2199-the european and asiatic land - mass]2198-the northern part of the european and asiatic land - mass]2197-the whole of the northern part of the european and asiatic land - mass , from [Portugal]67-portugal to [the Bering Strait]68-the bering strait . [Oceania]5-oceania comprises [the Americas]2200-the americas , [the Atlantic islands]2201-the atlantic islands including [the British Isles]69-the british isles , Australasia , and [the southern portion of [Africa]70-africa]2202-the southern portion of africa . Eastasia , smaller than the others and with a less definite western frontier , comprises [China]71-china and [the countries]2203-the countries to the south of

Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet [it]12-planet , [the Japanese islands]2204-the japanese islands and [a large but fluctuating portion of [Manchuria]73-manchuria]2205-a large but fluctuating portion of manchuria , [Mongolia]74-mongolia , and [Tibet]75-tibet . In one combination or another , [these three super - states]2206-these three super - states are permanently at war , and have been so for the past twen - ty - five years . War , however , is no longer the desperate , annihilating struggle that it was in the early decades of the twentieth century . It is a warfare of limited aims between [combatants who are unable to destroy one another]2207-combatants who are unable to destroy one another , have no material cause for fighting and are not divided by any genu - ine ideological difference This is not to say that either the conduct of war , or the prevailing attitude towards it , has be - come less bloodthirsty or more chivalrous . On the contrary , war hysteria is continuous and universal in [all countries]2208-all countries , and such acts as raping , looting , the slaughter of [children]3366-children , the reduction of whole populations to slavery , and reprisals against [prisoners which extend even to boiling and burying alive]2210-prisoners which extend even to boiling and burying alive , are looked upon as normal , and , when [they]2210-prisoners which extend even to boiling and burying alive are com - mitted by one ’s own side and not by [the enemy]977-the enemy , meritorious . But in a physical sense war involves very small numbers of [people , mostly highly - trained specialists]2212-people , mostly highly - trained specialists , and causes com - paratively few casualties . The fighting , when there is any , takes place on the vague frontiers whose whereabouts [the average man]2213-the average man can only guess at , or round the Floating For - tresses which guard strategic spots on [the sea lanes]2214-the sea lanes . In the centres of civilization war means no more than a contin - uous shortage of consumption goods , and the occasional crash of a rocket bomb which may cause a few scores of deaths . War has in fact changed its character . More exactly , the reasons for which war is waged have changed in [their]2210-prisoners which extend even to boiling and burying alive

1984 order of importance . Motives which were already present to some small extent in the great wars of [the early twentieth centuury]2215-the early twentieth centuury have now become dominant and are consciously recognized and acted upon . To understand the nature of the present war — for in spite of the regrouping which occurs every few years , it is al - ways the same war — one must realize in the first place that it is impossible for it to be decisive . [None of the three su - per - states]2216-none of the three su - per - states could be definitively conquered even by the other two in combination . [They]2216-none of the three su - per - states are too evenly matched , and [their]2216-none of the three su - per - states natural defences are too formidable . [Eurasia]8-eurasia is protected by [its]8-eurasia vast land spaces , [Oceania]5-oceania by the width of [the Atlantic]2217-the atlantic and [the Pacific]2218-the pacific , [Eastasia]9-eastasia by the fecundity and indus tri - ousness of [[its]8-eurasia inhabitants]2219-its inhabitants . Secondly , there is no longer , in a material sense , anything to fight about . With the estab - lishment of self - contained economies , in which production and consumption are geared to one another , the scramble for markets which was a main cause of previous wars has come to an end , while the competition for raw materials is no longer a matter of life and death . In any case each of the three super - states is so vast that it can obtain almost all the materials that it needs within its own boundaries . In so far as the war has a direct economic purpose , it is a war for la - bour power . Between [the frontiers of [the super - states]2221-the super - states]2220-the frontiers of the super - states , and not permanently in the possession of any of [them]2221-the super - states , there lies a rough quadrilateral with its corners at [Tangier]76-tangier , [Brazza - ville]77-brazza - ville , [Darwin]78-darwin , and [Hong Kong]79-hong kong , containing within [it]8-eurasia about a fifth of [the population of [the earth]651-the earth]2222-the population of the earth . It is for the posses - sion of [these thickly - populated regions]2224-these thickly - populated regions , and of the northern

Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet ice - cap , that the three powers are constantly struggling . In practice no one power ever controls the whole of [the disput- ed area]2225-the disput- ed area . Portions of it are constantly changing hands , and it is the chance of seizing this or that fragment by a sud - den stroke of treachery that dictates the endless changes of alignment . All of [the disputed territories]2226-the disputed territories contain valuable minerals , and some of them yield important vegetable products such as rubber which in colder climates it is necessary to syn - thesize by comparatively expensive methods . But above all [they]2226-the disputed territories contain a bottomless reserve of cheap labour . Which - ever power controls [equatorial Africa]70-africa , or [the countries of [the Middle East]81-the middle east]2227-the countries of the middle east , or [Southern India]82-southern india , or the [Indonesian Archipelago]83-indonesian archipelago , disposes also of the bodies of [scores or hun - dreds of millions of ill - paid and hard - working coolies]2228-scores or hun - dreds of millions of ill - paid and hard - working coolies . [The inhabitants of [these areas]2230-these areas]2229-the inhabitants of these areas , reduced more or less openly to the status of [slaves]2231-slaves , pass continually from conqueror to con- queror , and are expended like so much coal or oil in the race to turn out more armaments , to capture [more territory]2232-more territory , to control more labour power , to turn out more armaments , to capture [more territory]2232-more territory , and so on indefinitely . It should be noted that the fighting never really moves beyond [the edges of [the disputed areas]2235-the disputed areas]2234-the edges of the disputed areas . [The frontiers of [Eurasia]8-eurasia]2236-the frontiers of eurasia flow back and forth between [the basin of [the Congo]84-the congo]2237-the basin of the congo and [the northern shore of [the Mediterranean]2239-the mediterranean]2238-the northern shore of the mediterranean ; [the islands of [the In - dian Ocean]85-the in - dian ocean]2240-the islands of the in - dian ocean and [the Pacific]2218-the pacific are constantly being captured and recaptured by [Oceania]5-oceania or by [Eastasia]9-eastasia ; in [Mongolia]74-mongolia the dividing line between [Eurasia]8-eurasia and [Eastasia]9-eastasia is never stable ; round [the Pole]86-the pole all three powers lay claim to enormous terri-

19848 tories which in fact are largely unihabited and unexplored : but the balance of power always remains roughly even , and the territory which forms [the heartland of [each super - state]2243-each super - state]2242-the heartland of each super - state always remains inviolate . Moreover , the labour of [the ex - ploited peoples]2244-the ex - ploited peoples round [the Equator]87-the equator is not really necessary to [the world]318-the world ’s economy . [They]2244-the ex - ploited peoples add nothing to the wealth of [the world]318-the world , since whatever [they]2244-the ex - ploited peoples produce is used for purposes of war , and the object of waging a war is always to be in a bet - ter position in which to wage another war . By [their]2244-the ex - ploited peoples labour [the slave populations]2247-the slave populations allow the tempo of continuous war - fare to be speeded up . But if [they]2244-the ex - ploited peoples did not exist , the structure of [world society]2248-world society , and the process by which it maintains it - self , would not be essentially different . The primary aim of modern warfare ( in accordance with the principles of DOUBLETHINK , this aim is simul - taneously recognized and not recognized by the directing brains of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party ) is to use up the products of the machine without raising the general standard of living . Ever since the end of the nineteenth century , the problem of what to do with the surplus of consumption goods has been latent in [industrial society]2250-industrial society . At present , when [few human be - ings]2251-few human be - ings even have enough to eat , this problem is obviously not urgent , and it might not have become so , even if no artifi - cial processes of destruction had been at work . [The world of today]2252-the world of today is a bare , hungry , dilapidated place compared with [the world]318-the world that existed before 1914 , and still more so if com - pared with the imaginary future to which [the people of that period]2254-the people of that period looked forward . In the early twentieth century , the vision of [a future society unbelievably rich , leisured , orderly]2255-a future society unbelievably rich , leisured , orderly ,

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com and efficient — a glittering antiseptic world of glass and steel and snow - white concrete — was part of the consciousness of [nearly every literate person]2256-nearly every literate person . Science and technology were developing at a prodigious speed , and it seemed natural to assume that [they]2251-few human be - ings would go on developing . This failed to happen , partly because of the impoverishment caused by a long series of wars and revolutions , partly because scientific and technical progress depended on the empirical habit of thought , which could not survive in a strictly regimented society . As a whole [the world]318-the world is more primitive today than it was fifty years ago . [Certain backward areas]2258-certain backward areas have advanced , and various devices , always in some way connected with warfare and police espionage , have been developed , but experiment and invention have largely stopped , and the ravages of the atomic war of [the nineteen - fifties]2259-the nineteen - fifties have nev - er been fully repaired . Nevertheless the dangers inherent in the machine are still there . From the moment when the machine first made its appearance it was clear to all think - ing people that the need for human drudgery , and therefore to a great extent for human inequality , had disappeared . If the machine were used deliberately for that end , hunger , overwork , dirt , illiteracy , and disease could be eliminated within a few generations . And in fact , without being used for any such purpose , but by a sort of automatic process — by producing wealth which it was sometimes impossible not to distribute — [the machine]2260-the machine did raise the living standards of [the average humand]2261-the average humand being very greatly over a period of about fifty years at the end of the nineteenth and the begin - ning of the twentieth centuries .

198440 But it was also clear that an all - round increase in wealth threatened the destruction — indeed , in some sense was the destruction — of a hierarchical society . In a world in which [everyone]503-everyone worked short hours , had enough to eat , lived in [a house with a bathroom]2263-a house with a bathroom and a refrigerator , and possessed [a motor - car]2264-a motor - car or even [an aeroplane]2265-an aeroplane , the most obvious and per - haps the most important form of inequality would already have disappeared . If it once became general , wealth would confer no distinction . It was possible , no doubt , to imagine a society in which WEALTH , in the sense of personal pos - sessions and luxuries , should be evenly distributed , while [POWER]219-power remained in the hands of [a small privileged caste]2266-a small privileged caste . But in practice such a society could not long remain sta - ble . For if leisure and security were enjoyed by [all alike]2267-all alike , the great mass of [human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think for [themselves]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think ; and when once [they]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think had done this , [they]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think would sooner or later realize that [the privileged minority]2269-the privileged minority had no function , and [they]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think would sweep it away . In the long run , [a hierarchical society]2270-a hierarchical society was only possible on a basis of pov - erty and ignorance . To return to [the agricultural past]2271-the agricultural past , as [some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury dreamed of doing , was not a practicable solution . It conflicted with the tendency towards mechanization which had become quasi - instinctive throughout almost [the whole world]2273-the whole world , and moreover , any country which remained indus - trially backward was helpless in a military sense and was bound to be dominated , directly or indirectly , by [its more advanced rivals]2274-its more advanced rivals .

41Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com Nor was it a satisfactory solution to keep the masses in poverty by restricting the output of goods . This happened to a great extent during the final phase of capitalism , rough - ly between 1920 and 1940 . [The economy of [many countries]2276-many countries]2275-the economy of many countries was allowed to stagnate , [land]2277-land went out of cultivation , capital equipment was not added to , great blocks of [the popula - tion]2278-the popula - tion were prevented from working and kept half alive by State charity . But this , too , entailed military weakness , and since the privations it inflicted were obviously unneces - sary , it made opposition inevitable . The problem was how to keep the wheels of industry turning without increasing the real wealth of [the world]318-the world . Goods must be produced , but [they]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think must not be distributed . And in practice the only way of achieving this was by continuous warfare . The essential act of war is destruction , not necessarily of human lives , but of the products of human labour . War is a way of shattering to pieces , or pouring into the stratosphere , or sinking in the depths of [the sea]378-the sea , materials which might otherwise be used to make the masses too comfortable , and hence , in the long run , too intelligent . Even when weapons of war are not actually destroyed , [their]2268-human beings who are normally stupefied by poverty would become literate and would learn to think manufacture is still a convenient way of expending labour power without pro - ducing anything that can be consumed . [A Floating Fortress]2281-a floating fortress , for example , has locked up in [it]2281-a floating fortress the labour that would build [several hundred cargo - ships]2282-several hundred cargo - ships . Ultimately it is scrapped as obsolete , never having brought any material benefit to any - body , and with further enormous labours [another Floating Fortress]2283-another floating fortress is built . In principle the war effort is always so planned as to eat up any surplus that might exist after meet -

19844 ing the bare needs of [the population]2284-the population . In practice the needs of [the population]2284-the population are always underestimated , with the re - sult that there is a chronic shortage of half the necessities of life ; but this is looked on as an advantage . It is deliberate policy to keep even the favoured groups somewhere near the brink of hardship , because a general state of scarcity increases the importance of small privileges and thus mag - nifies the distinction between one group and another . By the standards of the early twentieth century , even a mem - ber of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party lives an austere , laborious kind of life . Nevertheless , the few luxuries that [he]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury does enjoy [his]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury large , well - appointed flat , the better texture of [his]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury clothes , the bet - ter quality of [his]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury food and drink and tobacco , [[his]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury two or three servants]2287-his two or three servants , [[his]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury private motor - car or helicopter]2288-his private motor - car or helicopter — set [him]2272-some thinkers about the beginning of the twentieth cen - tury in a different world from [a member of [the Outer Party]640-the outer party]2289-a member of the outer party , and [the members of [the Outer Party]640-the outer party]2291-the members of the outer party have a similar advantage in comparison with [the submerged masses whom [we]2293-we call ‘ [the proles ’]3733-the proles ’]3732-the submerged masses whom we call ‘ the proles ’[2293-we] . The social atmosphere is that of [a besieged city]2294-a besieged city , where the possession of a lump of horseflesh makes the dif - ference between wealth and poverty . And at the same time the consciousness of being at war , and therefore in danger , makes the handing - over of all power to a small caste seem the natural , unavoidable condition of survival . War , it will be seen , accomplishes the necessary destruc - tion , but accomplishes it in a psychologically acceptable way . In principle it would be quite simple to waste the surplus labour of [the world]318-the world by [building temples]2296-building temples and pyramids , by digging holes and filling [them]2291-the members of the outer party up again , or even by produc - ing vast quantities of goods and then setting fire to [them]2291-the members of the outer party .

4Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com But this would provide only the economic and not the emo - tional basis for [a hierarchical society]2270-a hierarchical society . What is concerned here is not the morale of [masses]2298-masses , whose attitude is unim - portant so long as [they]2298-masses are kept steadily at work , but the morale of the Party itself . Even [the humblest Party member]2299-the humblest party member is expected to be competent , industrious , and even intel - ligent within narrow limits , but it is also necessary that [he]2299-the humblest party member should be [a credulous and ignorant fanatic whose prevailing moods are fear , hatred , adulation , and orgiastic triumph]2300-a credulous and ignorant fanatic whose prevailing moods are fear , hatred , adulation , and orgiastic triumph . In other words it is necessary that [he]2299-the humblest party member should have the mental - ity appropriate to a state of war . It does not matter whether the war is actually happening , and , since no decisive victory is possible , it does not matter whether the war is going well or badly . All that is needed is that a state of war should ex - ist . The splitting of the intelligence which [the Party]418-the party requires of [its members]1019-its members , and which is more easily achieved in an at - mosphere of war , is now almost universal , but the higher up the ranks one goes , the more marked it becomes . It is precisely in the Inner Party that war hysteria and hatred of [the enemy]977-the enemy are strongest . In [his]2299-the humblest party member capacity as an administra - tor , it is often necessary for [a member of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party]425-a member of the inner party to know that this or that item of war news is untruthful , and [he]2299-the humblest party member may often be aware that the entire war is spurious and is either not happening or is being waged for purposes quite other than the declared ones : but such knowledge is easily neutralized by the technique of [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink . Mean - while [no Inner Party member]2306-no inner party member wavers for an instant in [his]2299-the humblest party member mystical belief that the war is real , and that it is bound to end victoriously , with [Oceania]5-oceania [the undisputed master of

198444 [the entire world]2308-the entire world]2307-the undisputed master of 198444 the entire world . [All members of the Inner Party]2309-all members of the inner party believe in this coming conquest as an article of faith . It is to be achieved either by gradually acquiring more and more territory and so build - ing up an overwhelming preponderance of power , or by the discovery of some new and unanswerable weapon . The search for new weapons continues unceasingly , and is one of the very few remaining activities in which the inventive or speculative type of mind can find any outlet . In Ocea - nia at the present day , [Science]221-science , in the old sense , has almost ceased to exist . In [Newspeak]134-newspeak there is no word for ‘ Science ’[221-science] . The empirical method of thought , on which all the scien - tific achievements of the past were founded , is opposed to the most fundamental principles of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . And even tech - nological progress only happens when its products can in some way be used for the diminution of human liberty . In all the useful arts [the world]318-the world is either standing still or go - ing backwards . [The fields]2311-the fields are cultivated with horse - ploughs while books are written by machinery . But in matters of vital importance — meaning , in effect , war and police espio - nage — the empirical approach is still encouraged , or at least tolerated . The two aims of [the Party]418-the party are to conquer the whole surface of [the earth]651-the earth and to extinguish once and for all the possibility of independent thought . There are therefore two great problems which [the Party]418-the party is concerned to solve . [One]2315-one is how to discover , against [his]2315-one will , what [another human be - ing]2316-another human be - ing is thinking , and the other is how to kill [several hundred million people]2317-several hundred million people in a few seconds without giving warning be - forehand . In so far as scientific research still continues , this

4Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com is its subject matter . [The scientist of today]2318-the scientist of today is either a mixture of [psychologist and inquisitor , studying with real ordinary minuteness the meaning of facial expressions , gestures , and tones of voice]2319-psychologist and inquisitor , studying with real ordinary minuteness the meaning of facial expressions , gestures , and tones of voice , and testing the truth - producing effects of drugs , shock therapy , hypnosis , and physical torture ; or [he]2318-the scientist of today is [chemist]2320-chemist , [physicist]2321-physicist , or biologist concerned only with such branches of [his]2318-the scientist of today special subject as are relevant to the taking of life . In [the vast laboratories of [the Ministry of Peace]790-the ministry of peace]2322-the vast laboratories of the ministry of peace , and in [the experimental stations hidden in [the Brazilian forests]2325-the brazilian forests]2324-the experimental stations hidden in the brazilian forests , or in [the Australian desert]2326-the australian desert , or on [lost islands of [the Ant - arctic]2328-the ant - arctic]2327-lost islands of the ant - arctic , [the teams of [experts]2330-experts]2329-the teams of experts are indefatigably at work . [Some]967-some are concerned simply with planning the logistics of future wars ; [others]777-others devise larger and larger rocket bombs , more and more powerful explosives , and more and more impen - etrable armour - plating ; others search for new and deadlier gases , or for soluble poisons capable of being produced in such quantities as to destroy the vegetation of whole con - tinents , or for breeds of disease germs immunized against all possible antibodies ; [others]777-others strive to produce [a vehicle]2334-a vehicle that shall bore its way under the soil like a submarine un - der the water , or [an aeroplane]2265-an aeroplane as independent of [its]2265-an aeroplane base as [a sailing - ship]2336-a sailing - ship ; [others]777-others explore even remoter possibilities such as focusing the sun ’s rays through lenses suspended thousands of kilometres away in space , or producing artifi - cial earthquakes and tidal waves by tapping the heat at [the earth]651-the earth ’s centre . But none of these projects ever comes anywhere near re - alization , and none of the three super - states ever gains a significant lead on the others . What is more remarkable is

19844 that all three powers already possess , in the atomic bomb , a weapon far more powerful than any that [their]777-others present researches are likely to discover . Although [the Party]418-the party , ac - cording to its habit , claims the invention for itself , atomic bombs first appeared as early as [the nineteen - forties]2340-the nineteen - forties , and were first used on a large scale about ten years later . At that time some hundreds of bombs were dropped on indus - trial centres , chiefly in [European Russia]88-european russia , [Western Europe]89-western europe , and [North America]90-north america . The effect was to convince the ruling groups of [all countries]2208-all countries that a few more atomic bombs would mean the end of [organized society]2342-organized society , and hence of [their]2342-organized society own power . Thereafter , although no formal agreement was ever made or hinted at , no more bombs were dropped . All three powers merely continue to produce atomic bombs and store [them]2342-organized society up against the decisive opportunity which [they]2342-organized society all believe will come sooner or later . And meanwhile the art of war has remained almost stationary for thirty or forty years . [Helicopters]2343-helicopters are more used than [they]2343-helicopters were formerly , [bombing planes]2344-bombing planes have been largely superseded by self - pro - pelled projectiles , and the fragile movable battleship has given way to [the almost unsinkable Floating Fortress]2345-the almost unsinkable floating fortress ; but otherwise there has been little development . [The tank]2346-the tank , [the submarine]2347-the submarine , the torpedo , the machine gun , even the rifle and the hand grenade are still in use . And in spite of the end - less slaughters reported in the Press and on the telescreens , the desperate battles of earlier wars , in which [hundreds of thousands or even millions of men]2348-hundreds of thousands or even millions of men were often killed in a few weeks , have never been repeated . [None of the three super - states]2349-none of the three super - states ever attempts any ma -

4Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet noeuvre which involves the risk of serious defeat . When any large operation is undertaken , it is usually a surprise attack against [an ally]2136-an ally . The strategy that all three powers are following , or pretend to [themselves]2349-none of the three super - states that [they]2349-none of the three super - states are following , is the same . The plan is , by a combination of fighting , bar - gaining , and well - timed strokes of treachery , to acquire a ring of bases completely encircling one or other of [the ri - val states]2351-the ri - val states , and then to sign a pact of friendship with [that rival]2352-that rival and remain on peaceful terms for so many years as to lull suspicion to sleep . During this time rockets loaded with atomic bombs can be assembled at all the strategic spots ; finally [they]2349-none of the three super - states will all be fired simultaneously , with effects so devastating as to make retaliation impossible . It will then be time to sign a pact of friendship with the remaining world- power , in preparation for another attack . This scheme , it is hardly necessary to say , is a mere daydream , impossible of realization . Moreover , no fighting ever occurs except in [the disputed areas round [the Equator]87-the equator and [the Pole]86-the pole]2353-the disputed areas round the equator and the pole : no invasion of [enemy territory]2354-enemy territory is ever undertaken . This explains the fact that in some places the frontiers between the superstates are arbitrary . [Eurasia]8-eurasia , for example , could easily conquer [the British Isles]69-the british isles , which are [geographically part of [Europe]65-europe]2355-geographically part of europe , or on the other hand it would be possible for [Oceania]5-oceania to push [its]5-oceania frontiers to [the Rhine]91-the rhine or even to [the Vistula]92-the vistula . But this would violate the principle , followed on all sides though never formulated , of cultural integrity . If [Oceania]5-oceania were to con - quer [the areas that used once to be known as [France]93-france and [Germany]94-germany]2356-the areas that used once to be known as france and germany , it would be necessary either to exterminate [the inhabitants]2357-the inhabitants , a task of great physical difficulty , or to assimi -

198448 late [a population of about a hundred million people]2358-a population of about a hundred million people , who , so far as technical development goes , are roughly on [the Oceanic level]2359-the oceanic level . The problem is the same for [all three super- states]2360-all three super- states . It is absolutely necessary to [their]2360-all three super- states structure that there should be no contact with [foreigners]1575-foreigners , except , to a limited extent , with [war prisoners]2362-war prisoners and [coloured slaves]2363-coloured slaves . Even the of - ficial ally of the moment is always regarded with the darkest suspicion . [War prisoners]2362-war prisoners apart , [the average citizen of [Ocea - nia]95-ocea - nia]2365-the average citizen of ocea - nia never sets eyes on [a citizen of either [Eurasia]8-eurasia or [Eastasia]9-eastasia]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia , and [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia is forbidden the knowledge of foreign languages . If [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia were allowed contact with [foreigners]1575-foreigners [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia would discover that [they]1575-foreigners are creatures similar to [himself]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia and that most of what [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia has been told about [them]1575-foreigners is lies . The sealed world in which [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia lives would be broken , and the fear , hatred , and self - righteousness on which [his]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia morale depends might evaporate . It is therefore realized on all sides that however often [Persia]96-persia , or [Egypt]97-egypt , or [Java]98-java , or [Ceylon]222-ceylon may change hands , the main frontiers must never be crossed by anything ex - cept bombs . Under this lies a fact never mentioned aloud , but tacitly understood and acted upon : namely , that the conditions of life in [all three super - states]2368-all three super - states are very much the same . In Oce - ania the prevailing philosophy is called [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc , in [Eurasia]8-eurasia it is called [Neo - Bolshevism]99-neo - bolshevism , and in [Eastasia]9-eastasia it is called by a Chinese name usually translated as [Death - Worship]223-death - worship , but perhaps better rendered as Obliteration of the Self . The citi - zen of [Oceania]5-oceania is not allowed to know anything of the tenets of the other two philosophies , but [he]2366-a citizen of either eurasia or eastasia is taught to execrate [them]1575-foreigners as barbarous outrages upon morality and common

49Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com sense . Actually the three philosophies are barely distin - guishable , and the social systems which [they]1575-foreigners support are not distinguishable at all . Everywhere there is the same py - ramidal structure , the same worship of [semi - divine leader]2369-semi - divine leader , the same economy existing by and for continuous warfare . It follows that [the three super - states]2196-the three super - states not only can not con - quer one another , but would gain no advantage by doing so . On the contrary , so long as [they]2196-the three super - states remain in conflict [they]2196-the three super - states prop [one another]594-one another up , like three sheaves of corn . And , as usual , the ruling groups of all three powers are simultane - ously aware and unaware of what [they]2196-the three super - states are doing . [Their]2196-the three super - states lives are dedicated to world conquest , but [they]2196-the three super - states also know that it is necessary that the war should continue everlastingly and without victory . Meanwhile the fact that there IS no danger of conquest makes possible the denial of reality which is the special feature of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc and its rival systems of thought . Here it is necessary to repeat what has been said earlier , that by becoming continuous war has fundamentally changed its character . In past ages , a war , almost by definition , was something that sooner or later came to an end , usually in unmistak - able victory or defeat . In the past , also , war was one of the main instruments by which [human societies]2372-human societies were kept in touch with physical reality . [All rulers in all ages]2373-all rulers in all ages have tried to impose a false view of [the world]318-the world upon [[their]2373-all rulers in all ages followers]2375-their followers , but [they]2373-all rulers in all ages could not afford to encourage any illusion that tended to impair military efficiency . So long as defeat meant the loss of independence , or some other result generally held to be undesirable , the precautions against defeat had to be

19840 serious . Physical facts could not be ignored . In philosophy , or religion , or ethics , or politics , [two and two]2376-two and two might make five , but when [one]441-one was designing a gun or [an aeroplane]2265-an aeroplane [they]2196-the three super - states had to make four . Inefficient nations were always conquered sooner or later , and the struggle for efficiency was inimi - cal to illusions . Moreover , to be efficient it was necessary to be able to learn from the past , which meant having a fairly accurate idea of what had happened in the past . [Newspa]224-newspa - pers and history books were , of course , always coloured and biased , but falsification of the kind that is practised today would have been impossible . War was a sure safeguard of sanity , and so far as [the ruling classes]2379-the ruling classes were concerned it was probably the most important of all safeguards . While wars could be won or lost , [no ruling class]2380-no ruling class could be completely ir - responsible . But when war becomes literally continuous , it also ceases to be dangerous . When war is continuous there is no such thing as military necessity . Technical progress can cease and the most palpable facts can be denied or disregarded . As [we]2381-we have seen , researches that could be called scientific are still carried out for the purposes of war , but [they]2196-the three super - states are es - sentially a kind of daydreaming , and [their]2196-the three super - states failure to show results is not important . Efficiency , even military efficiency , is no longer needed . Nothing is efficient in [Oceania]5-oceania except the Thought Police . Since each of [the three super - states]2196-the three super - states is unconquerable , each is in effect a separate universe within which almost any perversion of thought can be safely prac - tised . Reality only exerts its pressure through the needs of everyday life — the need to eat and drink , to get shelter and

1Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com clothing , to avoid swallowing poison or stepping out of top- storey windows , and the like . Between life and death , and between physical pleasure and physical pain , there is still a distinction , but that is all . Cut off from contact with [the outer world]2383-the outer world , and with the past , [the citizen of [Oceania]5-oceania]2384-the citizen of oceania is like [a man in interstellar space , who has no way of know - ing which direction is up and which is down]2385-a man in interstellar space , who has no way of know - ing which direction is up and which is down . [The rulers of such [a state]2387-a state]2386-the rulers of such a state are absolute , as [the Pharaohs]225-the pharaohs or [the Caesars]226-the caesars could not be . [They]2386-the rulers of such a state are obliged to prevent [[their]2386-the rulers of such a state followers]2375-their followers from starving to death in numbers large enough to be in - convenient , and [they]2386-the rulers of such a state are obliged to remain at the same low level of military technique as [[their]2386-the rulers of such a state rivals]2389-their rivals ; but once that minimum is achieved , [they]2386-the rulers of such a state can twist reality into whatever shape [they]2386-the rulers of such a state choose . The war , therefore , if [we]2390-we judge it by the standards of pre - vious wars , is merely an imposture . It is like the battles between certain ruminant animals whose horns are set at such an angle that [they]2386-the rulers of such a state are incapable of hurting one anoth - er . But though it is unreal it is not meaningless . It eats up the surplus of consumable goods , and it helps to preserve the special mental atmosphere that [a hierarchical society]2270-a hierarchical society needs . War , it will be seen , is now a purely internal affair . In the past , [the ruling groups of [all countries]2208-all countries]2392-the ruling groups of all countries , although [they]2392-the ruling groups of all countries might recognize [their]2392-the ruling groups of all countries common interest and therefore limit the destructiveness of war , did fight against one an - other , and [the victor]2394-the victor always plundered the vanquished . In [our]2390-we own day [they]2386-the rulers of such a state are not fighting against [one another]594-one another at all . The war is waged by [each ruling group against [its]2396-each ruling group against its own subjects own subjects]2396-each ruling group against its own subjects , and the object of the war is not to make or prevent

1984 conquests of territory , but to keep the structure of society intact . The very word ‘ war ’[2396-each ruling group against its own subjects] , therefore , has become mislead - ing . It would probably be accurate to say that by becoming continuous war has ceased to exist . The peculiar pressure that it exerted on human beings between the Neolithic Age and the early twentieth century has disappeared and been replaced by something quite different . The effect would be much the same if the three super - states , instead of fighting one another , should agree to live in perpetual peace , each inviolate within its own boundaries . For in that case each would still be a self - contained universe , freed for ever from the sobering influence of external danger . A peace that was truly permanent would be the same as a permanent war . This — although [the vast majority of [Party members]363-party members]2397-the vast majority of party members under - stand it only in a shallower sense — is the inner meaning of the Party slogan : WAR IS PEACE . [Winston]132-winston stopped reading for a moment . Somewhere in remote distance a rocket bomb thundered . The blissful feel - ing of being alone with the forbidden book , in a room with no telescreen , had not worn off . Solitude and safety were physical sensations , mixed up somehow with the tiredness of [his]132-winston body , the softness of the chair , the touch of the faint breeze from the window that played upon [his]132-winston cheek . The book fascinated [him]132-winston , or more exactly it reassured [him]132-winston . In a sense it told [him]132-winston nothing that was new , but that was part of the attraction . Presently [a new Middle group]2409-a new middle group splits off from [one of [the other groups]2411-the other groups]2410-one of the other groups , or from both of [them]2409-a new middle group , and the struggle begins over again . Of [the three groups]2412-the three groups , only the Low are never even temporarily successful in achieving [their]2412-the three groups aims . It would be an exaggeration to say that throughout history there has been no progress of a material kind . Even today , in a period of decline , [the average human being]2413-the average human being is physical - ly better off than [he]2413-the average human being was a few centuries ago . But no advance in wealth , no softening of manners , no reform or revolu - tion has ever brought human equality a millimetre nearer . From the point of view of [the Low]63-the low , no historic change has ever meant much more than a change in the name of [[their]2185-three kinds of people in the world masters]2414-their masters . By the late nineteenth century the recurrence of [this pat - tern]2415-this pat - tern had become obvious to [many observers]2416-many observers . There then rose schools of [thinkers who interpreted history as a cy - clical process and claimed to show that inequality was the unalterable law of human life]2417-thinkers who interpreted history as a cy - clical process and claimed to show that inequality was the unalterable law of human life . This doctrine , of course , had always had its adherents , but in the manner in which it was now put forward there was a significant change . In the past the need for a hierarchical form of society had been the doc- trine specifically of the High . It had been preached by [kings

1984]2418-kings 1984 and [aristocrats]2419-aristocrats and by [the priests]2420-the priests , [lawyers]2421-lawyers , and [the like who were parasitical upon [them]2420-the priests]2422-the like who were parasitical upon them , and it had generally been soft - ened by promises of compensation in [an imaginary world beyond the grave]2423-an imaginary world beyond the grave . [The Middle]2187-the middle , so long as it was struggling for power , had always made use of such terms as freedom , justice , and fraternity . Now , however , the concept of hu - man brotherhood began to be assailed by [people who were not yet in positions of command , but merely hoped to be so before long]2425-people who were not yet in positions of command , but merely hoped to be so before long . In the past [the Middle]2187-the middle had made revolutions under the banner of equality , and then had established a fresh tyranny as soon as [the old one]2427-the old one was overthrown . [The new Middle groups]2428-the new middle groups in effect proclaimed [their]2428-the new middle groups tyranny be - forehand . Socialism , a theory which appeared in the early nineteenth century and was the last link in a chain of thought stretching back to [the slave rebellions of antiquity]2429-the slave rebellions of antiquity , was still deeply infected by the Utopianism of past ages . But in each variant of Socialism that appeared from about 1900 onwards the aim of establishing liberty and equality was more and more openly abandoned . The new movements which appeared in the middle years of the century , [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc in [Oceania]5-oceania , [Neo - Bolshevism]99-neo - bolshevism in [Eurasia]8-eurasia , [Death - Worship]223-death - worship , as it is commonly called , in [Eastasia]9-eastasia , had the conscious aim of perpetuating UNfreedom and INequality . These new movements , of course , grew out of [the old ones]2430-the old ones and tended to keep [their]2430-the old ones names and pay lip - service to [their]2430-the old ones ideology . But the purpose of all of [them]2430-the old ones was to arrest progress and freeze history at a chosen moment . The familiar pendulum swing was to happen once more , and then stop . As usual , the High were to be turned out by the Middle , who would

Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet then become the High ; but this time , by conscious strategy , the High would be able to maintain [their]2428-the new middle groups position perma - nently . The new doctrines arose partly because of the accu - mulation of historical knowledge , and the growth of the historical sense , which had hardly existed before the nine - teenth century . The cyclical movement of history was now intelligible , or appeared to be so ; and if it was intelligible , then it was alterable . But the principal , underlying cause was that , as early as the beginning of the twentieth century , human equality had become technically possible . It was still true that [men]593-men were not equal in [their]593-men native talents and that functions had to be specialized in ways that favoured [some individuals against others]2432-some individuals against others ; but there was no longer any real need for class distinctions or for large differences of wealth . In earlier ages , class distinctions had been not only inevi - table but desirable . Inequality was the price of civilization . With the development of machine production , however , the case was altered . Even if it was still necessary for [human beings]3614-human beings to do different kinds of work , it was no longer neces - sary for [them]3614-human beings to live at different social or economic levels . Therefore , from the point of view of [the new groups who were on the point of seizing power , human equality]2434-the new groups who were on the point of seizing power , human equality was no longer an ideal to be striven after , but a danger to be avert - ed . In more primitive ages , when a just and peaceful society was in fact not possible , it had been fairly easy to believe it . The idea of an earthly paradise in which [men]593-men should live together in [a state of brotherhood , without laws and with - out brute labour]2436-a state of brotherhood , without laws and with - out brute labour , had haunted the human imagination for

19848 thousands of years . And this vision had had a certain hold even on the groups who actually profited by each histori - cal change . The heirs of the French , English , and American revolutions had partly believed in [their]2434-the new groups who were on the point of seizing power , human equality own phrases about the rights of [man]904-man , freedom of speech , equality before the law , and the like , and have even allowed [their]2434-the new groups who were on the point of seizing power , human equality conduct to be influenced by [them]2434-the new groups who were on the point of seizing power , human equality to some extent . But by the fourth decade of the twentieth century all the main currents of political thought were authoritarian . The earthly paradise had been discredited at exactly the moment when it became realizable . Every new political theory , by whatever name it called itself , led back to hierarchy and regimentation . And in the general hardening of outlook that set in round about 1930 , practices which had been long abandoned , in some cases for hundreds of years — imprisonment without trial , the use of [war prisoners]2362-war prisoners as [slaves]2231-slaves , public executions , torture to extract confessions , the use of [hostages]2440-hostages , and the depor - tation of [whole populations]2441-whole populations — not only became common again , but were tolerated and even defended by [people who considered [themselves]2442-people who considered themselves enlightened and progressive enlightened and progressive]2442-people who considered themselves enlightened and progressive . It was only after a decade of national wars , civil wars , revolutions , and counter - revolutions in all parts of [the world]318-the world that [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc and [its]145-ingsoc rivals emerged as fully worked- out political theories . But [they]2442-people who considered themselves enlightened and progressive had been foreshadowed by the various systems , generally called totalitarian , which had appeared earlier in the century , and the main outlines of [the world]318-the world which would emerge from the prevailing chaos had long been obvious . What kind of [people]324-people would control [this world]2446-this world had been equally obvious . The new aristocracy

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com was made up for the most part of [bureaucrats]2447-bureaucrats , [scientists]2448-scientists , [technicians]2449-technicians , [trade - union organizers]2450-trade - union organizers , [publicity experts]2451-publicity experts , so - ciologists , [teachers]2452-teachers , [journalists]2453-journalists , and [professional politicians]2454-professional politicians . [These people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class]2455-these people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class , had been shaped and brought together by [the barren world]2456-the barren world [of monopoly in - dustry and centralized government]2457-of monopoly in - dustry and centralized government . As compared with [their]2455-these people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class opposite numbers in past ages , [they]2455-these people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class were less avari - cious , less tempted by luxury , hungrier for pure power , and , above all , more conscious of what [they]2455-these people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class were doing and more intent on crushing opposition . This last difference was cardinal . By comparison with that existing today , all the tyrannies of the past were half - hearted and inefficient . [The ruling groups]2458-the ruling groups were always infected to some extent by lib - eral ideas , and were content to leave loose ends everywhere , to regard only the overt act and to be uninterested in what [their]2458-the ruling groups subjects were thinking . Even [the Catholic Church of the Middle Ages]2459-the catholic church of the middle ages was tolerant by modern standards . Part of the reason for this was that in the past [no government]2460-no government had the power to keep [[its]2460-no government citizens]2461-its citizens under constant surveillance . The invention of print , however , made it easier to manipu - late public opinion , and the film and the radio carried the process further . With the development of television , and the technical advance which made it possible to receive and transmit simultaneously on the same instrument , private life came to an end . [Every citizen]2462-every citizen , or at least [every citizen important enough to be worth watching]2463-every citizen important enough to be worth watching , could be kept for twenty - four hours a day under the eyes of [the police]397-the police and in the sound of official propaganda , with all other channels

19840 of communication closed . The possibility of enforcing not only complete obedience to the will of [the State]472-the state , but com - plete uniformity of opinion on all subjects , now existed for the first time . After the revolutionary period of the fifties and sixties , [society]2466-society regrouped itself , as always , into High , Middle , and Low . But the new High group , unlike [all its forerunners]2467-all its forerunners , did not act upon instinct but knew what was needed to safeguard [its]2466-society position . It had long been realized that the only secure basis for oligarchy is collectivism . Wealth and privilege are most easily defended when [they]2455-these people , whose origins lay in the salaried middle class and the upper grades of the working class are possessed jointly . The so - called ‘ abolition of private property ’[2469-a group in - stead of a mass of individuals] which took place in the middle years of the century meant , in effect , the con - centration of property in far fewer hands than before : but with this difference , that [the new owners]2468-the new owners were [a group in - stead of a mass of individuals]2469-a group in - stead of a mass of individuals . Individually , [no member of [the Party]418-the party]2470-no member of the party owns anything , except petty personal belongings . Collectively , [the Party]418-the party owns everything in [Oceania]5-oceania , be - cause it controls everything , and disposes of the products as it thinks fit . In the years following the Revolution it was able to step into this commanding position almost unop - posed , because the whole process was represented as an act of collectivization . It had always been assumed that if [the capitalist class]2473-the capitalist class were expropriated , [Socialism]227-socialism must follow : and unquestionably [the capitalists]1037-the capitalists had been expropriated . [Factories]3433-factories , mines , land , [houses]895-houses , transport — everything had been taken away from [them]2468-the new owners : and since these things were no longer [private property]2477-private property , it followed that [they]2468-the new owners must be [public property]2478-public property . Ingsoc , which grew out of the earlier So -

1Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com cialist movement and inherited its phraseology , has in fact carried out the main item in the Socialist programme ; with the result , foreseen and intended beforehand , that econom - ic inequality has been made permanent . But the problems of perpetuating a hierarchical soci - ety go deeper than this . There are only four ways in which [a ruling group]2479-a ruling group can fall from power . Either it is conquered from without , or it governs so inefficiently that [the masses]2480-the masses are stirred to revolt , or it allows [a strong and discontented Middle group]2481-a strong and discontented middle group to come into being , or it loses its own self- confidence and willingness to govern . These causes do not operate singly , and as a rule [all four of [them]340-all four of them]340-all four of them are present in some degree . A ruling class which could guard against [all of [them]340-all four of them]2483-all of them would remain in power permanently . Ultimately the determining factor is the mental attitude of the ruling class itself . After the middle of the present century , [the first dan - ger]2484-the first dan - ger had in reality disappeared . Each of the three powers which now divide [the world]318-the world is in fact unconquerable , and could only become conquerable through slow demographic changes which [a government with wide powers]2486-a government with wide powers can easi - ly avert . The second danger , also , is only a theoretical one . [The masses]2480-the masses never revolt of [their]2480-the masses own accord , and [they]2480-the masses never revolt merely because [they]2480-the masses are oppressed . Indeed , so long as [they]2480-the masses are not permitted to have standards of comparison , [they]2480-the masses never even become aware that [they]2480-the masses are oppressed . The recurrent economic crises of past times were totally un - necessary and are not now permitted to happen , but other and equally large dislocations can and do happen without

1984 having political results , because there is no way in which discontent can become articulate . As for the problem of over - production , which has been latent in [our]2488-our society since the development of machine technique , it is solved by the device of continuous warfare ( see Chapter III ) , which is also useful in keying up public morale to the necessary pitch . From the point of view of [[our]2488-our present rulers]2489-our present rulers , there - fore , the only genuine dangers are the splitting - off of [a new group of able , under - employed , power - hungry people]2490-a new group of able , under - employed , power - hungry people , and the growth of liberalism and scepticism in [their]2490-a new group of able , under - employed , power - hungry people own ranks . The problem , that is to say , is educational . It is a problem of continuously moulding the consciousness both of [the directing group]2491-the directing group and of [the larger executive group that lies immediately below it]2492-the larger executive group that lies immediately below it . The consciousness of [the masses]2480-the masses needs only to be influenced in a negative way . Given this background , [one]441-one could infer , if [one]441-one did not know it already , the general structure of [Oceanic society]2496-oceanic society . At the apex of [the pyramid]2497-the pyramid comes [Big Brother]126-big brother . [Big Brother]126-big brother is in- fallible and all - powerful . Every success , every achievement , every victory , every scientific discovery , all knowledge , all wisdom , all happiness , all virtue , are held to issue directly from [his]126-big brother leadership and inspiration . [Nobody]2498-nobody has ever seen [Big Brother]126-big brother . [He]126-big brother is a face on the hoardings , a voice on the telescreen . [We]2488-our may be reasonably sure that [he]126-big brother will never die , and there is already considerable uncertainty as to when [he]126-big brother was born . [Big Brother]126-big brother is the guise in which [the Party choos - es]2499-the party choos - es to exhibit itself to [the world]318-the world . [His]126-big brother function is to act as a focusing point for love , fear , and reverence , emotions which are more easily felt towards [an individual]2501-an individual than towards an

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com organization . Below [Big Brother]126-big brother comes [the Inner Party]426-the inner party . Its numbers limited to six millions , or something less than 2 per cent of [the population of [Oceania]5-oceania]719-the population of oceania . [The child of [Inner Party parents]2517-inner party parents]2516-the child of inner party parents is in theory not born into [the Inner Party]426-the inner party . Admission to either branch of [the Party]418-the party is by examination , taken at the age of sixteen . Nor is there any racial discrimination , or any marked domination of [one province]2520-one province by another . [[Its]95-ocea - nia rulers]2535-its rulers are not held together by blood - ties but by adherence to a common doctrine . It is true that [our]2536-our society is stratified , and very rigidly strat - ified , on what at first sight appear to be hereditary lines .

19844 There is far less to - and - fro movement between the differ - ent groups than happened under capitalism or even in the pre - industrial age . Between the two branches of [the Party]418-the party there is a certain amount of interchange , but only so much as will ensure that weaklings are excluded from the Inner Party and that [ambitious members of the Outer Party]2538-ambitious members of the outer party are made harmless by allowing [them]2538-ambitious members of the outer party to rise . [Proletarians]230-proletarians , in practice , are not allowed to graduate into [the Party]418-the party . [The most gifted among [them]2538-ambitious members of the outer party , who might possibly become nu - clei of discontent]2540-the most gifted among them , who might possibly become nu - clei of discontent , are simply marked down by [the Thought Police]137-police and eliminated . But this state of affairs is not neces - sarily permanent , nor is it a matter of principle . [The Party]418-the party is not a class in the old sense of the word . It does not aim at transmitting power to [[its]418-the party own children]2542-its own children , as such ; and if there were no other way of keeping [the ablest people]2543-the ablest people at the top , it would be perfectly prepared to recruit [an entire new generation]2544-an entire new generation from the ranks of the proletariat . In the crucial years , the fact that [the Party]418-the party was not [a hereditary body]2546-a hereditary body did a great deal to neutralize opposition . [The older kind of So - cialist , who had been trained to fight against something called ‘ class privilege ’[2547-the older kind of so - cialist , who had been trained to fight against something called ‘ class privilege ’ assumed that what is not hereditary] assumed that what is not hereditary]2547-the older kind of so - cialist , who had been trained to fight against something called ‘ class privilege ’ assumed that what is not hereditary can not be permanent . The essence of oligarchical rule is not [father - to - son inheritance]2549-father - to - son inheritance , but the persistence of a certain world - view and a certain way of life , imposed by the dead upon the living . A

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com ruling group is [a ruling group]2479-a ruling group so long as it can nominate [[its]418-the party successors]2551-its successors . [The Party]418-the party is not concerned with perpetuating its blood but with perpetuating itself . [WHO]2553-who wields power is not important , provided that the hierarchical structure remains always the same . All the beliefs , habits , tastes , emotions , mental attitudes that characterize [our]2554-our time are really designed to sustain the mystique of the Party and prevent the true nature of pres - ent - day society from being perceived . Physical rebellion , or any preliminary move towards rebellion , is at present not possible . From [the proletarians]2555-the proletarians nothing is to be feared . Left to [themselves]2555-the proletarians , [they]2555-the proletarians will continue from generation to gener - ation and from century to century , working , breeding , and dying , not only without any impulse to rebel , but without the power of grasping that [the world]318-the world could be other than it is . [They]2555-the proletarians could only become dangerous if the advance of in - dustrial technique made it necessary to educate [them]2555-the proletarians more highly ; but , since military and commercial rivalry are no longer important , the level of popular education is actually declining . What opinions [the masses]2480-the masses hold , or do not hold , is looked on as a matter of indifference . [They]2555-the proletarians can be granted intellectual liberty because [they]2555-the proletarians have no intellect . In [a Party member]948-a party member , on the other hand , not even the smallest deviation of opinion on the most unimportant subject can be toler - ated . [A Party member]948-a party member lives from birth to death under the eye of [the Thought Police]569-the thought police . Even when [he]948-a party member is alone [he]948-a party member can never be sure that [he]948-a party member is alone . Wherever [he]948-a party member may be , asleep or awake , working or resting , in [his]948-a party member bath or in bed , [he]948-a party member can be inspected

1984 without warning and without knowing that [he]948-a party member is being in - spected . Nothing that [he]948-a party member does is indifferent . [His]948-a party member friendships , [his]948-a party member relaxations , [his]948-a party member behaviour towards [[his]948-a party member wife]956-his wife and [children]3366-children , the expression of [his]948-a party member face when [he]948-a party member is alone , the words [he]948-a party member mutters in sleep , even the characteristic movements of [his]948-a party member body , are all jealously scrutinized . Not only any actual mis - demeanour , but any eccentricity , however small , any change of habits , any nervous mannerism that could possibly be the symptom of an inner struggle , is certain to be detected . [He]948-a party member has no freedom of choice in any direction whatever . On the other hand [his]948-a party member actions are not regulated by law or by any clearly formulated code of behaviour . In Oceania there is no law . Thoughts and actions which , when detected , mean certain death are not formally forbidden , and the endless purges , arrests , tortures , imprisonments , and vaporizations are not inflicted as punishment for crimes which have ac - tually been committed , but are merely the wiping - out of [persons who might perhaps commit a crime at some time in the future]2563-persons who might perhaps commit a crime at some time in the future . [A Party member]948-a party member is required to have not only the right opinions , but the right instincts . Many of the beliefs and attitudes demanded of [him]948-a party member are never plainly stated , and could not be stated without laying bare the contradictions inherent in [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . If [he]948-a party member is a person naturally orthodox ( in [Newspeak a GOODTHINKER]231-newspeak a goodthinker ) , [he]948-a party member will in all circumstanc - es know , without taking thought , what is the true belief or the desirable emotion . But in any case [an elaborate men]2565-an elaborate men - tal training , undergone in childhood and grouping itself round the Newspeak words CRIMESTOP , [BLACKWHITE]232-blackwhite , and [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink , makes [him]948-a party member unwilling and unable to

Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com think too deeply on any subject whatever . [A Party member]948-a party member is expected to have no private emotions and no respites from enthusiasm . [He]948-a party member is supposed to live in a continuous frenzy of hatred of [foreign enemies]2567-foreign enemies and internal traitors , triumph over victories , and self - abasement before the power and wisdom of [the Party]418-the party . The discontents pro - duced by [his]948-a party member bare , unsatisfying life are deliberately turned outwards and dissipated by such devices as the Two Minutes Hate , and the speculations which might possibly induce a sceptical or rebellious attitude are killed in advance by [his]948-a party member early acquired inner discipline . The first and simplest stage in the discipline , which can be taught even to young chil - dren , is called , in [Newspeak]134-newspeak , [CRIMESTOP]233-crimestop . [CRIMESTOP]233-crimestop means the faculty of stopping short , as though by instinct , at the threshold of any dangerous thought . It includes the power of not grasping analogies , of failing to perceive logi - cal errors , of misunderstanding the simplest arguments if they are inimical to [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc , and of being bored or repelled by any train of thought which is capable of leading in a heretical direction . CRIMESTOP , in short , means protec - tive stupidity . But stupidity is not enough . On the contrary , orthodoxy in the full sense demands a control over [one]441-one ’s own mental processes as complete as that of a contortion - ist over [his]948-a party member body . [Oceanic society]2496-oceanic society rests ultimately on the belief that [Big Brother]126-big brother is omnipotent and that [the Party]418-the party is infallible . But since in reality [Big Brother]126-big brother is not omnipotent and [the party]418-the party is not infallible , there is need for an unwea - rying , moment - to - moment flexibility in the treatment of facts . The keyword here is [BLACKWHITE]232-blackwhite . Like so many

19848 Newspeak words , this word has two mutually contradicto - ry meanings . Applied to [an opponent]3421-an opponent , it means the habit of impudently claiming that black is white , in contradiction of the plain facts . Applied to [a Party member]948-a party member , it means a loyal willingness to say that black is white when [Party]14-the party discipline demands this . But it means also the ability to BELIEVE that black is white , and more , to KNOW that black is white , and to forget that [one]441-one has ever believed the contrary . This de - mands a continuous alteration of the past , made possible by the system of thought which really embraces all the rest , and which is known in [Newspeak]134-newspeak as [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink . The alteration of the past is necessary for two reasons , one of which is subsidiary and , so to speak , precaution - ary . The subsidiary reason is that [the Party member]2576-the party member , like [the proletarian]2577-the proletarian , tolerates present - day conditions partly be - cause [he]2576-the party member has no standards of comparison . [He]2576-the party member must be cut off from the past , just as [he]2576-the party member must be cut off from [foreign countries]2578-foreign countries , because it is necessary for [him]2576-the party member to believe that [he]2576-the party member is better off than [[his]2576-the party member ancestors]2579-his ancestors and that the average lev - el of material comfort is constantly rising . But by far the more important reason for the readjustment of the past is the need to safeguard the infallibility of [the Party]418-the party . It is not merely that speeches , statistics , and records of every kind must be constantly brought up to date in order to show that the predictions of [the Party]418-the party were in all cases right . It is also that no change in doctrine or in political alignment can ever be admitted . For to change [one]441-one ’s mind , or even [one]441-one ’s policy , is a confession of weakness . If , for example , [Eurasia]8-eurasia or [Eastasia]9-eastasia ( whichever it may be ) is [the enemy]977-the enemy today , then

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [that country]2585-that country must always have been [the enemy]977-the enemy . And if the facts say otherwise then the facts must be altered . Thus [his]2576-the party member - tory is continuously rewritten . This day - to - day falsification of the past , carried out by [the Ministry of Truth]329-the ministry of truth , is as neces - sary to the stability of [the regime]2588-the regime as the work of repression and espionage carried out by [the Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love . The mutability of the past is the central tenet of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . Past events , it is argued , have no objective existence , but survive only in written records and in human memories . The past is whatever the records and the memories agree upon . And since [the Party]418-the party is in full control of all records and in equally full control of the minds of [its members]1019-its members , it follows that the past is whatever [the Party]418-the party chooses to make it . It also follows that though the past is alterable , it never has been altered in any specific instance . For when it has been recreated in whatever shape is needed at the moment , then this new version IS the past , and no different past can ever have existed . This holds good even when , as often hap - pens , the same event has to be altered out of recognition several times in the course of a year . At all times [the Party]418-the party is in possession of absolute truth , and clearly the absolute can never have been different from what it is now . It will be seen that the control of the past depends above all on the training of memory . To make sure that all written re - cords agree with the orthodoxy of the moment is merely a mechanical act . But it is also necessary to REMEMBER that events happened in the desired manner . And if it is necessary to rearrange [one]441-one ’s memories or to tamper with written records , then it is necessary to FORGET that [one

19840]2595-one 19840 has done so . The trick of doing this can be learned like any other mental technique . It is learned by [the majority of [Par - ty members]2597-par - ty members]2596-the majority of par - ty members , and certainly by [all who are intelligent as well as orthodox]2598-all who are intelligent as well as orthodox . In [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak it is called , quite frankly , ‘ reality control ’[165-oldspeak] . In Newspeak it is called [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink , though [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink comprises much else as well . [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink means the power of holding two contradictory beliefs in [one]441-one ’s mind simultaneously , and ac - cepting both of [them]2596-the majority of par - ty members . [The Party intellectual]2600-the party intellectual knows in which direction [his]2600-the party intellectual memories must be altered ; [he]2600-the party intellectual therefore knows that [he]2600-the party intellectual is playing tricks with reality ; but by the exercise of [DOUBLETHINK]2601-doublethink [he]2600-the party intellectual also satisfies [himself]2600-the party intellectual that reality is not violated . The process has to be conscious , or it would not be carried out with sufficient precision , but it also has to be unconscious , or it would bring with it a feeling of falsity and hence of guilt . [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink lies at the very heart of In - gsoc , since the essential act of [the Party]14-the party is to use conscious deception while retaining the firmness of purpose that goes with complete honesty . To tell deliberate lies while [genu]2602-genu - inely believing in [them]2596-the majority of par - ty members , to forget any fact that has become inconvenient , and then , when it becomes necessary again , to draw it back from oblivion for just so long as it is needed , to deny the existence of objective reality and all the while to take account of the reality which [one]441-one denies — all this is indispensably necessary . Even in using the word DOUBLE - THINK it is necessary to exercise [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink . For by using the word [one]441-one admits that one is tampering with reality ; by a fresh act of [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink one erases this knowledge ; and so on indefinitely , with the lie always one

1Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet leap ahead of the truth . Ultimately it is by means of [DOU - BLETHINK]235-dou - blethink that [the Party]418-the party has been able — and may , for all [we]2606-we know , continue to be able for thousands of years — to ar - rest the course of history . [All past oligarchies]2607-all past oligarchies have fallen from power either because [they]2607-all past oligarchies ossified or because [they]2607-all past oligarchies grew soft . Either [they]2607-all past oligarchies became stupid and arrogant , failed to adjust [themselves]2607-all past oligarchies to chang - ing circumstances , and were overthrown ; or [they]2607-all past oligarchies became liberal and cowardly , made concessions when [they]2607-all past oligarchies should have used force , and once again were overthrown . [They]2607-all past oligarchies fell , that is to say , either through consciousness or through un - consciousness . It is the achievement of [the Party]418-the party to have produced a system of thought in which both conditions can exist simultaneously . And upon no other intellectual basis could the dominion of [the Party]418-the party be made permanent . If [one]441-one is to rule , and to continue ruling , [one]441-one must be able to dis - locate the sense of reality . For the secret of [rulership]2612-rulership is to combine a belief in [one]441-one ’s own infallibility with the Power to learn from past mistakes . It need hardly be said that [the subtlest practitioners of [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink]2614-the subtlest practitioners of doublethink are [those who invented [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink]2615-those who invented doublethink and know that it is a vast system of mental cheating . In [[our]2606-we society]2616-our society , [those who have the best knowledge of what is happening are also those who are furthest from seeing [the world]318-the world as it is]2617-those who have the best knowledge of what is happening are also those who are furthest from seeing the world as it is . In general , the greater the understanding , the greater the delusion ; the more intelligent , the less sane . One clear illustration of this is the fact that war hysteria increas - es in intensity as one rises in the social scale . Those whose attitude towards the war is most nearly rational are [the sub -

1984 ject peoples of [the disputed territories]2226-the disputed territories]2619-the sub - 1984 ject peoples of the disputed territories .
