It is in the ranks of [the Party]418-the party , and above all of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party , that the true war enthusiasm is found . World - conquest is believed in most firmly by [those who know it to be impossible]2627-those who know it to be impossible . This peculiar linking - together of opposites — knowledge with ignorance , cynicism with fanaticism — is [one of the chief distinguish - ing marks of [Oceanic society]2496-oceanic society]2628-one of the chief distinguish - ing marks of oceanic society . The official ideology abounds with contradictions even when there is no practical reason for [them]1335-these people . Thus , [the Party]418-the party rejects and vilifies every principle for which [the Socialist movement]2631-the socialist movement originally stood , and it chooses to do this in the name of Socialism . [It]418-the party preaches a contempt for [the working class]2632-the working class unexampled for centuries past , and it dresses [[its]418-the party members]1019-its members in a uniform which was at one time peculiar to [manual workers]2634-manual workers and was adopted for that reason . It systematically undermines the solidarity of [the family]1733-the family , and it calls [its leader]2636-its leader by a name which is a direct appeal to the sentiment of family loyalty . Even the names of [the four Ministries]2637-the four ministries by which [we]2638-we are governed exhibit a sort

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com of impudence in [their]1733-the family deliberate reversal of the facts . The Ministry of Peace concerns itself with war , the Ministry of Truth with lies , the Ministry of Love with torture and [the Ministry of Plenty with starvation]2639-the ministry of plenty with starvation . These contradictions are not accidental , nor do [they]1733-the family result from ordinary hypoc - risy ; [they]1733-the family are deliberate exercises in [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink . For it is only by reconciling contradictions that power can be retained indefinitely . In no other way could the ancient cy - cle be broken . If human equality is to be for ever averted — if the High , as [we]2638-we have called [them]1733-the family , are to keep [their]1733-the family places permanently — then the prevailing mental condition must be controlled insanity . But there is one question which until this moment [we]2638-we have almost ignored . It is ; WHY should human equality be averted ? Supposing that the mechanics of the process have been rightly described , what is the motive for this huge , accurately planned effort to freeze history at a particular moment of time ? Here [we]2638-we reach [the central secret]2640-the central secret . As [we]2638-we have seen . the mystique of [the Party]418-the party , and above all of [the Inner Party]426-the inner party , de - pends upon [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink But deeper than this lies the original motive , the never - questioned instinct that first led to the seizure of power and brought [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink , the Thought Police , continuous warfare , and all the other nec - essary paraphernalia into existence afterwards . This motive really consists ... [Winston]132-winston became aware of silence , as one becomes aware of a new sound . 8Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com Chapter 1 H e did not know where [he]132-winston was . [He]132-winston was in a high - ceilinged windowless cell with walls of glittering white porcelain . Concealed lamps flood - ed it with cold light , and there was a low , steady humming sound which [he]132-winston supposed had something to do with the air supply . A bench , or shelf , just wide enough to sit on ran round the wall , broken only by the door and , at the end op - posite the door , a lavatory pan with no wooden seat . There were four telescreens , one in each wall . There was a dull aching in [his]132-winston belly . It had been there ever since [they]2732-they had bundled [him]132-winston into [the closed van]2733-the closed van and driven [him]132-winston away . But [he]132-winston was also hungry , with a gnaw - ing , unwholesome kind of hunger . It might be twenty - four hours since [he]132-winston had eaten , it might be thirty - six . [He]132-winston still did not know , probably never would know , whether it had been morning or evening when [they]2734-they arrested [him]132-winston . [He]132-winston sat as still as [he]132-winston could on the narrow bench , with [his]132-winston hands crossed on [his]132-winston knee . [He]132-winston had already learned to sit still . 198498 ing or squeaking , which seemed unconscious , came out of [him]2830-the chinless man . [Winston]132-winston was alone , and had been alone for hours . The pain of sitting on the narrow bench was such that often [he]132-winston got up and walked about , unreproved by the telescreen . 19840 at [him]132-winston . [The guard]2792-the guard was laughing at [his]132-winston contortions . One question at any rate was answered . 0Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com Chapter 2 H e was lying on something that felt like a camp bed , ex - cept that it was higher off the ground and that [he]132-winston was fixed down in some way so that [he]132-winston could not move . How long [he]132-winston had been down there [he]132-winston did not know . Since the moment when [they]2881-they arrest - ed [him]132-winston [he]132-winston had not seen darkness or daylight . Besides , [his]132-winston memories were not continuous . There had been times when consciousness , even the sort of consciousness that [one]441-one has in sleep , had stopped dead and started again after a blank interval . But whether the intervals were of days or weeks or only seconds , there was no way of knowing . With that first blow on the elbow the nightmare had started . Later [he]132-winston was to realize that all that then happened was merely a preliminary , a routine interrogation to which nearly [all prisoners]2883-all prisoners were subjected . There was a long range of crimes — espionage , sabotage , and the like — to which [ev - eryone]2884-ev - eryone had to confess as a matter of course . The confession

198404 was a formality , though the torture was real . How many times [he]132-winston had been beaten , how long the beatings had con - tinued , [he]132-winston could not remember . Always there were [five or six men in black uniforms]2885-five or six men in black uniforms at [him]132-winston simultaneously . Some - times it was fists , sometimes it was truncheons , sometimes it was steel rods , sometimes it was boots . There were times when [he]132-winston rolled about the floor , as shameless as an animal , writhing [his]132-winston body this way and that in an endless , hopeless effort to dodge the kicks , and simply inviting more and yet more kicks , in [his]132-winston ribs , in [his]132-winston belly , on [his]132-winston elbows , on [his]132-winston shins , in [his]132-winston groin , in [his]132-winston testicles , on the bone at the base of [his]132-winston spine . There were times when it went on and on un - til the cruel , wicked , unforgivable thing seemed to [him]132-winston not that [the guards]2748-the guards continued to beat [him]132-winston but that [he]132-winston could not force hirnself into losing consciousness . There were times when [his]132-winston nerve so forsook [him]132-winston that [he]132-winston began shouting for mercy even before the beating began , when the mere sight of a fist drawn back for a blow was enough to make [him]132-winston pour forth a confession of real and imaginary crimes . There were other times when [he]132-winston started out with the resolve of confessing nothing , when every word had to be forced out of [him]132-winston between gasps of pain , and there were times when [he]132-winston feebly tried to compromise , when [he]132-winston said to [himself]132-winston : ‘ [I]132-winston will confess , but not yet . There were also longer

0Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com periods of recovery . [He]132-winston remembered them dimly , because [they]2888-they were spent chiefly in sleep or stupor . [[His]132-winston questioners]2893-his questioners now were not ruffians in black uniforms but Party intellec - tuals , [little rotund men]2894-little rotund men with quick movements and flashing spectacles , who worked on [him]132-winston in relays over periods which lasted — [he]132-winston thought , [he]132-winston could not be sure — ten or twelve hours at a stretch . [These other questioners]2895-these other questioners saw to it that [he]132-winston was in constant slight pain , but it was not chiefly pain that [they]2895-these other questioners relied on . [They]2895-these other questioners slapped [his]132-winston face , wrung [his]132-winston ears , pulled [his]132-winston hair , made [him]132-winston stand on one leg , refused [him]132-winston leave to urinate , shone glaring lights in [his]132-winston face until [his]132-winston eyes ran with water ; but the aim of this was simply to humiliate [him]132-winston and destroy [his]132-winston power of arguing and reasoning . [Their]2895-these other questioners real weapon was the merciless questioning that went on and on , hour after hour , tripping [him]132-winston up , laying traps for [him]132-winston , twist- ing everything that [he]132-winston said , convicting [him]132-winston at every step of lies and self - contradiction until [he]132-winston began weeping as much from shame as from nervous fatigue . 19840 weep half a dozen times in a single session . When [his]132-winston nerves were in rags after hours of questioning , even this appeal could reduce [him]132-winston to snivel - ling tears . In the end the nagging voices broke [him]132-winston down more completely than the boots and fists of [the guards]2748-the guards . [He]132-winston became simply a mouth that uttered , a hand that signed , whatever was demanded of [him]132-winston . [His]132-winston sole concern was to find out what [they]2895-these other questioners wanted [him]132-winston to confess , and then confess it quickly , before the bullying started anew . And once — [Winston]132-winston could not remember whether it was in drugged sleep , or in normal sleep , or even in a moment of wakefulness — a voice murmured in [his]132-winston ear : ‘ Do n’t wor - ry , [Winston]132-winston ; [you]132-winston are in [my]132-winston keeping . [I]132-winston shall save [you]132-winston , [I]132-winston shall make [you]132-winston perfect . ’[132-winston] [He]132-winston was not sure whether it was [O’Brien]216-o’brien ’s voice ; but it was the same voice that had said to [him]132-winston , ‘ [We]3797-we shall meet in the place where there is no darkness , ’[132-winston] in that other dream , seven years ago . 09Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com of [his]132-winston head was gripped in some manner . [O’Brien]216-o’brien was look - ing down at [him]132-winston gravely and rather sadly . [He]132-winston was older than [Winston]132-winston had thought [him]132-winston ; [he]132-winston was perhaps forty - eight or fifty . [He]132-winston did not know whether the thing was really happening , or whether the effect was electrically pro - duced ; but [his]132-winston body was being wrenched out of shape , the joints were being slowly torn apart . 19840 persecutions of the past . In the Middle Ages there was [the Inquisitlon]244-the inquisitlon . It was a failure . It set out to eradicate heresy , and ended by perpetuating it . For every heretic it burned at the stake , thousands of [others]777-others rose up . Why was that ? Because [the Inquisition]2963-the inquisition killed [[its]2963-the inquisition enemies]1015-its enemies in the open , and killed [them]1015-its enemies while [they]1015-its enemies were still unrepentant : in fact , it killed [them]1015-its enemies because [they]1015-its enemies were unrepentant . [You]216-o’brien shall see the side view as well . ’[132-winston] [He]132-winston had stopped because [he]132-winston was frightened . A bowed , grey - coloured , skeleton - like thing was coming towards [him]132-winston . Its actual appearance was frightening , and not merely the fact that [he]132-winston knew it to be [himself]132-winston . [He]132-winston moved closer to the glass . The creature ’s face seemed to be protruded , be - cause of its bent carriage . A forlorn , jailbird ’s face with a nobby forehead running back into a bald scalp , a crooked nose , and battered - looking cheekbones above which [his]132-winston eyes were fierce and watchful . The cheeks were seamed , the mouth had a drawn - in look . Certainly it was [his]132-winston own face , but it seemed to [him]132-winston that it had changed more than [he]132-winston had changed inside . The emotions it registered would be differ - ent from the ones [he]132-winston felt . [He]132-winston had gone partially bald . For the

19844 first moment [he]132-winston had thought that [he]132-winston had gone grey as well , but it was only the scalp that was grey . Except for [his]132-winston hands and a circle of [his]132-winston face , [his]132-winston body was grey all over with an - cient , ingrained dirt . Here and there under the dirt there were the red scars of wounds , and near the ankle the vari - cose ulcer was an inflamed mass with flakes of skin peeling off it . But the truly frightening thing was the emaciation of [his]132-winston body . The barrel of the ribs was as narrow as that of a skeleton : the legs had shrunk so that the knees were thicker than the thighs . [He]132-winston saw now what [O’Brien]216-o’brien had meant about seeing the side view . The curvature of the spine was aston - ishing . The thin shoulders were hunched forward so as to make a cavity of the chest , the scraggy neck seemed to be bending double under the weight of the skull . At a guess [he]132-winston would have said that it was the body of [a man of sixty , suf - fering from some malignant disease]3092-a man of sixty , suf - fering from some malignant disease . ‘ [You]3092-a man of sixty , suf - fering from some malignant disease have thought sometimes , ’[216-o’brien] said [O’Brien]216-o’brien , ‘ that [my]132-winston face — the face of [a member of the Inner Party]425-a member of the inner party — looks old and worn . 19844 Chapter 4 H e was much better . [He]12-planet was growing fatter and stronger every day , if it was proper to speak of days . The white light and the humming sound were the same as ever , but [the cell]2793-the cell was a little more comfortable than the others [he]12-planet had been in . There was a pillow and a mattress on the plank bed , and a stool to sit on . [They]3103-they had given [him]12-planet a bath , and [they]3103-they allowed [him]12-planet to wash [himself]12-planet fairly frequent - ly in a tin basin . [They]3103-they even gave [him]12-planet warm water to wash with . [They]3103-they had given [him]12-planet new underclothes and a clean suit of overalls . [They]3103-they had dressed [his]12-planet varicose ulcer with sooth - ing ointment . [They]3103-they had pulled out the remnants of [his]12-planet teeth and given [him]12-planet a new set of dentures . Weeks or months must have passed . It would have been possible now to keep count of the passage of time , if [he]12-planet had felt any interest in doing so , since [he]12-planet was being fed at what appeared to be regular intervals . [He]12-planet was getting , [he]12-planet judged , three meals in the twenty - four hours ; sometimes [he]12-planet won - dered dimly whether [he]12-planet was getting [them]3103-they by night or by day . The food was surprisingly good , with meat at every third meal . Once there was even a packet of cigarettes . [He]12-planet had no matches , but [the never - speaking guard who brought [his]12-planet food]3104-the never - speaking guard who brought his food would give [him]12-planet a light . The first time [he]12-planet tried to smoke it made [him]12-planet sick , but [he]12-planet persevered , and spun the packet out for a long time , smoking half a cigarette after each meal .

4Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com [They]3103-they had given [him]12-planet a white slate with a stump of pencil tied to the corner . At first [he]12-planet made no use of it . Even when [he]12-planet was awake [he]12-planet was completely torpid . Often [he]12-planet would lie from one meal to the next almost without stirring , some - times asleep , sometimes waking into vague reveries in which it was too much trouble to open [his]12-planet eyes . [He]12-planet had long grown used to sleeping with a strong light on [his]12-planet face . It seemed to make no difference , except that one ’s dreams were more coherent . [He]12-planet dreamed a great deal all through this time , and [they]3103-they were always happy dreams . [He]12-planet was in [the Golden Country]111-the golden country , or [he]12-planet was sitting among enormous glorious , sunlit ruins , with [[his]12-planet mother]602-his mother , with [Julia]207-julia , with [O’Brien]216-o’brien — not do - ing anything , merely sitting in the sun , talking of peaceful things . Such thoughts as [he]12-planet had when [he]12-planet was awake were mostly about [his]12-planet dreams . [He]12-planet seemed to have lost the power of intellectual effort , now that the stimulus of pain had been removed . [He]12-planet was not bored , [he]12-planet had no desire for conversa - tion or distraction . Merely to be alone , not to be beaten or questioned , to have enough to eat , and to be clean all over , was completely satisfying . By degrees [he]12-planet came to spend less time in sleep , but [he]12-planet still felt no impulse to get off the bed . All [he]12-planet cared for was to lie quiet and feel the strength gathering in [his]12-planet body . [He]12-planet would finger [himself]12-planet here and there , trying to make sure that it was not an illusion that [his]12-planet muscles were growing round - er and [his]12-planet skin tauter . Finally it was established beyond a doubt that [he]12-planet was growing fatter ; [his]12-planet thighs were now defi - nitely thicker than [his]12-planet knees . After that , reluctantly at first , [he]12-planet began exercising [himself]12-planet regularly . In a little while [he]12-planet

198448 could walk three kilometres , measured by pacing the cell , and [his]12-planet bowed shoulders were growing straighter . [He]12-planet at - tempted more elaborate exercises , and was astonished and humiliated to find what things [he]12-planet could not do . [He]12-planet could not move out of a walk , [he]12-planet could not hold [his]12-planet stool out at arm ’s length , [he]12-planet could not stand on one leg without falling over . [He]12-planet squatted down on [his]12-planet heels , and found that with agonizing pains in thigh and calf [he]12-planet could just lift [himself]12-planet to a standing position . [He]12-planet lay flat on [his]12-planet belly and tried to lift [his]12-planet weight by [his]12-planet hands . It was hopeless , [he]12-planet could not raise [himself]12-planet a centimetre . But after a few more days — a few more mealtimes — even that feat was accomplished . A time came when [he]12-planet could do it six times running . [He]12-planet began to grow actually proud of [his]12-planet body , and to cherish an inter - mittent belief that [his]12-planet face also was growing back to normal . Only when [he]12-planet chanced to put [his]12-planet hand on [his]12-planet bald scalp did [he]12-planet remember the seamed , ruined face that had looked back at [him]12-planet out of the mirror . [His]12-planet mind grew more active . [He]12-planet sat down on the plank bed , [his]12-planet back against the wall and the slate on [his]12-planet knees , and set to work deliberately at the task of re - educating [him]12-planet - self . [He]12-planet had capitulated , that was agreed . In reality , as [he]12-planet saw now , [he]12-planet had been ready to capitulate long before [he]12-planet had taken the decision . From the moment when [he]12-planet was inside [the Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love — and yes , even during those minutes when [he]12-planet and [Julia]207-julia had stood helpless while the iron voice from the telescreen told [them]3107-they what to do — [he]12-planet had grasped the frivolity , the shallowness of [his]12-planet attempt to set [himself]12-planet

49Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com up against the power of [the Party]418-the party . [He]12-planet knew now that for seven years the Thought [Police]137-police had watched [him]12-planet like a bee - tle under a magnifying glass . There was no physical act , no word spoken aloud , that [they]3107-they had not noticed , no train of thought that [they]3107-they had not been able to infer . Even the speck of whitish dust on the cover of [his]12-planet diary [they]3107-they had careful - ly replaced . [They]3107-they had played sound - tracks to [him]12-planet , shown [him]12-planet photographs . [Some of [them]3107-they]2749-some of them were photographs of [Julia]207-julia and [himself]12-planet . Yes , even ... [He]12-planet could not fight against [the Party]418-the party any longer . Besides , [the Party]418-the party was in the right . It must be so ; how could [the immortal]3112-the immortal , collective brain be mistaken ? By what external standard could [you]3113-you check its judgements ? Sanity was statistical . It was merely a question of learning to think as [they]3107-they thought . Only — — ! The pencil felt thick and awkward in [his]12-planet fingers . [He]12-planet be - gan to write down the thoughts that came into [his]12-planet head . [He]12-planet wrote first in large clumsy capitals : FREEDOM IS SLAVERY Then almost without a pause [he]12-planet wrote beneath it : TWO AND TWO MAKE FIVE But then there came a sort of check . [His]12-planet mind , as though shying away from something , seemed unable to concen - trate . [He]12-planet knew that [he]12-planet knew what came next , but for the moment [he]12-planet could not recall it . When [he]12-planet did recall it , it was only by consciously reasoning out what it must be : it did not

19840 come of its own accord . [He]12-planet wrote : [GOD]242-god IS POWER [He]12-planet accepted everything . The past was alterable . The past never had been altered . [Oceania]5-oceania was at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia . [Oceania]5-oceania had always been at war with [Eastasia]9-eastasia . [Jones]183-jones , [Aar - onson]248-aar - onson , and [Rutherford]185-rutherford were guilty of the crimes [they]3114-they were charged with . [He]12-planet had never seen the photograph that dis - proved [their]3114-they guilt . It had never existed , [he]12-planet had invented it . [He]12-planet remembered remembering contrary things , but those were false memories , products of self - deception . How easy it all was ! Only surrender , and everything else followed . It was like swimming against a current that swept [you]3115-you backwards however hard [you]3115-you struggled , and then suddenly deciding to turn round and go with the current instead of opposing it . Nothing had changed except [your]3115-you own attitude : the predes - tined thing happened in any case . [He]12-planet hardly knew why [he]12-planet had ever rebelled . Everything was easy , except — — ! Anything could be true . The so - called laws of [Na - ture]112-na - ture were nonsense . The law of gravity was nonsense . ‘ If [I]216-o’brien wished , ’[216-o’brien] [O’Brien]216-o’brien had said , ‘ [I]132-winston could float off this floor like a soap bubble . ’[132-winston] [Winston]132-winston worked it out . ‘ If [he]132-winston THINKS [he]132-winston floats off the floor , and if [I]132-winston simultaneously THINK [I]132-winston see [him]132-winston do it , then the thing happens . ’[132-winston] Suddenly , like a lump of submerged wreckage breaking the surface of water , the thought burst into [his]132-winston mind : ‘ It does n’t really happen . [We]3117-we imagine it . It is hallucination . ’[132-winston] [He]132-winston pushed the thought un - der instantly . The fallacy was obvious . It presupposed that

1Free eBooks at [Planet eBook.com]12-planet somewhere or other , outside [oneself]3116-oneself , there was a ‘ real ’[3116-oneself] world where ‘ real ’[3116-oneself] things happened . But how could there be such a world ? What knowledge have [we]3117-we of anything , save through [our]3117-we own minds ? All happenings are in the mind . Whatever happens in all minds , truly happens . [He]132-winston had no difficulty in disposing of the fallacy , and [he]132-winston was in no danger of succumbing to it . [He]132-winston realized , never - theless , that it ought never to have occurred to [him]132-winston . The mind should develop a blind spot whenever a dangerous thought presented itself . The process should be automatic , instinctive . [CRIMESTOP]233-crimestop , [they]233-crimestop called it in [Newspeak]134-newspeak . [He]132-winston set to work to exercise [himself]132-winston in crimestop . [He]132-winston pre - sented [himself]132-winston with [propositions—’the Party]14-the party says [the earth]651-the earth is flat ’ , ‘[418-the party] [the party]418-the party says that ice is heavier than water’—and trained [himself]132-winston in not seeing or not understanding the ar - guments that contradicted [them]233-crimestop . It was not easy . It needed great powers of reasoning and improvisation . The arith - metical problems raised , for instance , by such a statement as ‘ two and two make five ’[132-winston] were beyond [his]132-winston intellectual grasp . It needed also a sort of athleticism of mind , an ability at one moment to make the most delicate use of logic and at the next to be unconscious of the crudest logical errors . Stupidity was as necessary as intelligence , and as difficult to attain . All the while , with one part of [his]132-winston mind , [he]132-winston wondered how soon [they]233-crimestop would shoot [him]132-winston . ‘ Everything depends on [yourself]3904-yourself , ’[216-o’brien] [O’Brien]216-o’brien had said ; but [he]132-winston knew that there was no conscious act by which [he]132-winston could bring it nearer . It might be ten minutes hence , or ten years . [They]233-crimestop might keep [him]132-winston

1984 for years in solitary confinement , [they]233-crimestop might send [him]132-winston to [a labour - camp]3772-a labour - camp , [they]233-crimestop might release [him]132-winston for a while , as [they]233-crimestop sometimes did . It was perfectly possible that before [he]132-winston was shot the whole drama of [his]132-winston arrest and interrogation would be enacted all over again . The one certain thing was that death never came at an expected moment . The tradition — the unspoken tradition : somehow [you]3121-you knew it , though [you]3121-you never heard it said — was that [they]233-crimestop shot [you]3121-you from behind ; always in the back of the head , without warning , as [you]3122-you walked down [a corridor from cell to [cell]3124-cell]3123-a corridor from cell to cell . One day — but ‘ one day ’[132-winston] was not the right expression ; just as probably it was in the middle of the night : once — [he]132-winston fell into a strange , blissful reverie . [He]132-winston was walking down [the corridor]421-the corridor , waiting for the bullet . [He]132-winston knew that it was com - ing in another moment . Everything was settled , smoothed out , reconciled . There were no more doubts , [no more argu - ments]3126-no more argu - ments , no more pain , no more fear . [His]132-winston body was healthy and strong . [He]132-winston walked easily , with a joy of movement and with a feeling of walking in sunlight . [He]132-winston was not any longer in [the narrow white corridors in [the Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love]3127-the narrow white corridors in the ministry of love , [he]132-winston was in the enormous sunlit passage , a kilometre wide , down which [he]132-winston had seemed to walk in the delirium induced by drugs . [He]132-winston was in [the Golden Country]633-the golden country , following the foot- track across the old rabbit - cropped pasture . [He]132-winston could feel the short springy turf under [his]132-winston feet and the gentle sun - shine on [his]132-winston face . At the edge of [the field]637-the field were the elm trees , faintly stirring , and somewhere beyond that was the stream where the dace lay in the green pools under the willows . Suddenly [he]132-winston started up with a shock of horror . The

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com sweat broke out on [his]132-winston backbone . [He]132-winston had heard [himself]132-winston cry aloud : ‘ [Julia]207-julia ! [Julia]207-julia ! [Julia]207-julia , [my]132-winston love ! [Julia]207-julia ! ’[132-winston] For a moment [he]132-winston had had an overwhelming hallucina - tion of [her]3131-she presence . [She]3131-she had seemed to be not merely with [him]132-winston , but inside [him]132-winston . It was as though [she]3131-she had got into the texture of [his]132-winston skin . In that moment [he]132-winston had loved [her]3131-she far more than [he]132-winston had ever done when [they]3132-they were together and free . Also [he]132-winston knew that somewhere or other [she]3131-she was still alive and needed [his]132-winston help . [He]132-winston lay back on the bed and tried to compose [himself]132-winston . What had [he]132-winston done ? How many years had [he]132-winston added to [his]132-winston servitude by that moment of weakness ? In another moment [he]132-winston would hear the tramp of boots outside . [They]3132-they could not let such an outburst go unpunished . [They]3132-they would know now , if [they]3132-they had not known before , that [he]132-winston was breaking the agreement [he]132-winston had made with [them]3132-they . [He]132-winston obeyed the Party , but [he]132-winston still hated the Party . In the old days [he]132-winston had hidden a heretical mind beneath an appear - ance of conformity . Now [he]132-winston had retreated a step further : in the mind [he]132-winston had surrendered , but [he]132-winston had hoped to keep the inner heart inviolate . [He]132-winston knew that [he]132-winston was in the wrong , but [he]132-winston preferred to be in the wrong . [They]3132-they would understand that — [O’Brien]216-o’brien would understand it . [He]132-winston had seen [her]3193-her ; [he]132-winston had even spoken to [her]3193-her . There was no danger in it . [He]132-winston knew as though instinctively that [they]3198-they now took almost no interest in [his]132-winston doings . [He]132-winston could have arranged to meet [her]3193-her a second time if [either of [them]3198-they]3199-either of them had wanted to . Actually it was by chance that [they]3198-they had met . It was in [the Park]3365-the park , on a vile , biting day in March , when [the earth]651-the earth was like iron and all the grass seemed dead and there was not a bud anywhere except a few crocuses which had pushed [themselves]3198-they up to be dismembered by the wind . [He]132-winston was hurrying along with frozen hands and watering eyes when [he]132-winston saw [her]3193-her not ten metres away from [him]132-winston . It struck [him]132-winston at once that [she]3193-her had changed in some ill - defined way . [They]3198-they almost passed [one another]594-one another without a sign , then [he]132-winston turned and followed [her]3193-her , not very eagerly . [He]132-winston knew that there was no danger , [nobody]398-nobody would take any interest in [him]132-winston . [She]3193-her did not speak . [She]3193-her walked obliquely away across the grass as though trying to get rid of [him]132-winston , then seemed to re - sign [herself]3193-her to having [him]132-winston at [her]3193-her side . Presently [they]3198-they were in among a clump of ragged leafless shrubs , useless either for concealment or as protection from the wind . [They]3198-they halted . It was vilely cold . The wind whistled through the twigs and fretted the occasional , dirty - looking crocuses . [He]132-winston put [his]132-winston

19848 arm round [her]3193-her waist . There was no telescreen , but there must be hidden microphones : besides , [they]3198-they could be seen . It did not mat - ter , nothing mattered . [They]3198-they could have lain down on the ground and done THAT if [they]3198-they had wanted to . [His]132-winston flesh froze with horror at the thought of it . [She]3193-her made no response whatever to the clasp of [his]132-winston arm ; [she]3193-her did not even try to dis - engage [herself]3193-her . It was that [her]3193-her waist had grown thicker , and , in a surprising way , had stiffened . [He]132-winston remembered how once , after the explosion of a rocket bomb , [he]132-winston had helped to drag a corpse out of some ruins , and had been astonished not only by the incredible weight of the thing , but by its rigidity and awkwardness to handle , which made it seem more like stone than flesh . Already an excited voice was gabbling from the tele - screen , but even as it started it was almost drowned by a roar of cheering from outside . The news had run round [the streets]3435-the streets like magic . [He]132-winston looked up again at the portrait of [Big Brother]126-big brother . The colossus that bestrode [the world]318-the world ! The rock against which [the hordes of [Asia]10-asia]492-the hordes of asia dashed [themselves]492-the hordes of asia in vain ! [He]132-winston thought how ten minutes ago — yes , only ten minutes — there had still been equivocation in [his]132-winston heart as [he]132-winston wondered whether the news from the front would be of victory or defeat . Ah , it was more than [a Eur - asian army that had perished]3939-a eur - asian army that had perished ! Much had changed in [him]132-winston since that first day in [the Ministry of Love]345-the ministry of love , but the final , in - dispensable , healing change had never happened , until this moment . The voice from the telescreen was still pouring forth its tale of [prisoners]1577-prisoners and booty and slaughter , but the shouting outside had died down a little . [The waiters]3238-the waiters were turning back to [their]3238-the waiters work . [One of [them]3238-the waiters]406-one of them approached with the gin bottle . [He]132-winston was walking down [the white - tiled corridor]3946-the white - tiled corridor , with the feeling of walking in sunlight , and [an armed guard at [his]132-winston back]3947-an armed guard at his back . The long - hoped - for bullet was entering [his]132-winston brain . [He]132-winston gazed up at the enormous face . Forty years it had tak -[3241-he]

1984 en [him]3241-he to learn what kind of smile was hidden beneath the dark moustache . O cruel , needless misunderstanding ! O stubborn , self - willed exile from the loving breast ! Two gin- scented tears trickled down the sides of [his]3241-he nose . But it was all right , everything was all right , the struggle was finished . [He]3241-he had won the victory over [himself]3241-he . [He]3241-he loved [Big Brother]126-big brother . THE END APPENDIX . The Principles of [Newspeak Newspeak]134-newspeak was the official language of [Oceania]5-oceania and had been devised to meet the ideological needs of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc , or English Socialism . In the year 1984 there was not as yet [anyone who used [Newspeak]134-newspeak as [his]134-newspeak sole means of commu - nication]3242-anyone who used newspeak as his sole means of commu - nication , either in speech or writing . The leading articles in ‘ The Times ’[3242-anyone who used newspeak as his sole means of commu - nication] were written in it , but this was a TOUR DE FORCE which could only be carried out by [a specialist]3243-a specialist . It was expected that [Newspeak]134-newspeak would have finally supersed - ed [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak ( or Standard English , as [we]3244-we should call it ) by about the year 2050 . Meanwhile it gained ground steadi - ly , [all Party members]3245-all party members tending to use [Newspeak]134-newspeak words and grammatical constructions more and more in [their]3245-all party members every - day speech . The version in use in 1984 , and embodied in the Ninth and Tenth Editions of the Newspeak Dictionary , was a provisional one , and contained many superfluous words and archaic formations which were due to be suppressed later . It is with the final , perfected version , as embodied in the Eleventh Edition of the Dictionary , that [we]3244-we are con - cerned here . The purpose of [Newspeak]134-newspeak was not only to provide a

Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com medium of expression for the world - view and mental hab - its proper to [the devotees of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc]3246-the devotees of ingsoc , but to make all other modes of thought impossible . It was intended that when [Newspeak]134-newspeak had been adopted once and for all and [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak forgotten , a heretical thought — that is , a thought diverging from the principles of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc — should be literally unthink - able , at least so far as thought is dependent on words . Its vocabulary was so constructed as to give exact and of - ten very subtle expression to every meaning that [a Party member]948-a party member could properly wish to express , while excluding all other meanings and also the possibility of arriving at [them]948-a party member by indirect methods . This was done partly by the invention of new words , but chiefly by eliminating unde - sirable words and by stripping such words as remained of unorthodox meanings , and so far as possible of all second - ary meanings whatever . To give a single example . The word FREE still existed in [Newspeak]134-newspeak , but it could only be used in such statements as ‘ This dog is free from lice ’[134-newspeak] or ‘ [This field]3948-this field is free from weeds ’[134-newspeak] . It could not be used in its old sense of ‘ politically free ’[134-newspeak] or ‘ intellectually free ’[134-newspeak] since political and in - tellectual freedom no longer existed even as concepts , and were therefore of necessity nameless . Quite apart from the suppression of definitely heretical words , reduction of vo - cabulary was regarded as an end in itself , and no word that could be dispensed with was allowed to survive . [Newspeak]134-newspeak was designed not to extend but to [DIMINISH]3248-diminish the range of thought , and this purpose was indirectly assisted by cutting the choice of words down to a minimum . [Newspeak]134-newspeak was founded on the English language as [we]3244-we

19848 now know it , though many Newspeak sentences , even when not containing newly - created words , would be barely intel - ligible to [an English - speaker of [our]3244-we own day]3249-an english - speaker of our own day . [Newspeak]134-newspeak words were divided into three distinct classes , known as the A vocabulary , the B vocabulary ( also called compound words ) , and the C vocabulary . It will be simpler to discuss [each class]3250-each class separately , but the grammatical peculiarities of the language can be dealt with in the section devoted to the A vocabulary , since the same rules held good for all three categories . THE A VOCABULARY . The A vocabulary consisted of the words needed for the business of everyday life — for such things as eating , drinking , working , putting on one ’s clothes , going up and down [stairs]3251-stairs , riding in vehicles , garden- ing , cooking , and the like . It was composed almost entirely of words that [we]3244-we already possess words like [HIT]255-hit , RUN , [DOG]256-dog , TREE , [SUGAR]257-sugar , HOUSE , FIELD — but in compari - son with the present - day English vocabulary [their]948-a party member number was extremely small , while [their]948-a party member meanings were far more rigidly defined . All ambiguities and shades of meaning had been purged out of [them]948-a party member . So far as it could be achieved , a Newspeak word of [this class]3252-this class was simply a staccato sound expressing [ONE]3253-one clearly understood concept . It would have been quite impossible to use the A vocabulary for literary purposes or for political or philosophical discussion . It was intended only to express simple , purposive thoughts , usu - ally involving concrete objects or physical actions . The grammar of [Newspeak]134-newspeak had two outstanding pe - culiarities . The first of these was an almost complete

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com interchangeability between different parts of speech . Any word in the language ( in principle this applied even to very abstract words such as IF or WHEN ) could be used either as verb , noun , adjective , or adverb . Between the verb and the noun form , when [they]948-a party member were of the same root , there was never any variation , this rule of [itself]3253-one involving the de - struction of many archaic forms . The word THOUGHT , for example , did not exist in [Newspeak]134-newspeak . Its place was tak - en by THINK , which did duty for both noun and verb . No etymological principle was followed here : in some cases it was the original noun that was chosen for retention , in oth - er cases the verb . Even where a noun and verb of kindred meaning were not etymologically connected , one or other of [them]948-a party member was frequently suppressed . There was , for example , no such word as [CUT]258-cut , its meaning being sufficiently cov - ered by the noun - verb KNIFE . Adjectives were formed by adding the suffix -FUL to the noun - verb , and adverbs by adding -WISE . Thus for example , [SPEEDFUL]259-speedful meant ‘ rapid ’[259-speedful] and SPEEDWISE meant ‘ quickly ’[259-speedful] . Certain of [our]3244-we present- day adjectives , such as GOOD , STRONG , BIG , BLACK , SOFT , were retained , but [their]948-a party member total number was very small . There was little need for [them]948-a party member , since almost any adjectival meaning could be arrived at by adding -FUL to a noun - verb . None of the now - existing adverbs was retained , except for a very few already ending in -WISE : the -WISE termination was invariable . The word WELL , for example , was replaced by [GOODWISE]260-goodwise . In addition , any word — this again applied in principle to every word in the language — could be negatived by add -

198480 ing the affix UN- , or could be strengthened by the affix PLUS- , or , for still greater emphasis , [DOUBLEPLUS-]3254-doubleplus- . Thus , for example , [UNCOLD]261-uncold meant ‘ warm ’[261-uncold] , while [PLUSCOLD]262-pluscold and [DOUBLEPLUSCOLD]263-doublepluscold meant , respectively , ‘ very cold ’[262-pluscold] and ‘ superlatively cold ’[262-pluscold] . It was also possible , as in present- day English , to modify the meaning of almost any word by prepositional affixes such as [ANTE-]264-ante- , POST- , [UP-]265-up- , DOWN- , etc . By such methods it was found possible to bring about an enormous diminution of vocabulary . Given , for instance , the word GOOD , there was no need for such a word as BAD , since the required meaning was equally well — indeed , bet - ter — expressed by [UNGOOD]162-ungood . All that was necessary , in any case where two words formed a natural pair of oppo - sites , was to decide which of [them]948-a party member to suppress . DARK , for example , could be replaced by [UNLIGHT]266-unlight , or LIGHT by [UNDARK]267-undark , according to preference . The second distinguishing mark of [Newspeak gram - mar]3255-newspeak gram - mar was its regularity . Subject to a few exceptions which are mentioned below all inflexions followed the same rules . Thus , in all verbs the preterite and the past participle were the same and ended in -ED . The preterite of STEAL was [STEALED]3256-stealed , the preterite of THINK was THINKED , and so on throughout the language , all such forms as [SWAM]268-swam , GAVE , [BROUGHT]269-brought , SPOKE , [TAKEN]270-taken , etc . , being abolished . All plurals were made by adding -S or -ES as the case might be . The plurals OF [MAN]250-man , OX , LIFE , were [MANS]271-mans , [OXES]272-oxes , LIFES . Comparison of adjectives was invariably made by adding -ER , -EST ( GOOD , [GOODER]273-gooder , GOODEST ) , ir - regular forms and the MORE , MOST formation being

81Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com suppressed . The only classes of words that were still allowed to inflect irregularly were the pronouns , [the relatives]3257-the relatives , the demonstra - tive adjectives , and the auxiliary verbs . All of these followed [their]3257-the relatives ancient usage , except that WHOM had been scrapped as unnecessary , and the SHALL , SHOULD tenses had been dropped , all [their]3257-the relatives uses being covered by [WILL]274-will and WOULD . There were also certain irregularities in word - formation arising out of the need for rapid and easy speech . A word which was difficult to utter , or was liable to be incorrectly heard , was held to be ipso facto a bad word ; occasionally therefore , for the sake of euphony , extra letters were insert - ed into a word or an archaic formation was retained . But this need made itself felt chiefly in connexion with the B vocabulary . WHY so great an importance was attached to ease of pronunciation will be made clear later in this essay . THE B VOCABULARY . The B vocabulary consisted of words which had been deliberately constructed for political purposes : words , that is to say , which not only had in every case a political implication , but were intended to impose a desirable mental attitude upon [the person]1957-the person using [them]1957-the person . Without a full understanding of the principles of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc it was difficult to use these words correctly . In some cases [they]1957-the person could be translated into [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak , or even into words taken from the A vocabulary , but this usually demanded a long paraphrase and always involved the loss of certain overtones . The B words were a sort of verbal shorthand , of - ten packing whole ranges of ideas into a few syllables , and at the same time more accurate and forcible than ordinary

19848 language . The B words were in all cases compound words . [ Com - pound words such as SPEAKWRITE , were of course to be found in the A vocabulary , but these were merely convenient abbreviations and had no special ideologcal colour . ] [They]3259-they consisted of two or more words , or portions of words , weld- ed together in an easily pronounceable form . The resulting amalgam was always a noun - verb , and inflected according to the ordinary rules . To take a single example : the word GOODTHINK , meaning , very roughly , ‘ orthodoxy ’[275-good - think] , or , if [one]441-one chose to regard it as a verb , ‘ to think in an orthodox manner ’[441-one] . This inflected as follows : noun - verb , [GOOD - THINK]275-good - think ; past tense and past participle , [GOODTHINKED]276-goodthinked ; present participle , GOOD - THINKING ; adjective , [GOOD - THINKFUL]277-good - thinkful ; adverb , [GOODTHINKWISE]278-goodthinkwise ; verbal noun , [GOODTHINKER]231-newspeak a goodthinker . The B words were not constructed on any etymological plan . The words of which [they]3259-they were made up could be any parts of speech , and could be placed in any order and muti - lated in any way which made [them]3259-they easy to pronounce while indicating [their]3259-they derivation . In the word CRIMETHINK ( thoughtcrime ) , for instance , the THINK came second , whereas in [THINKPOL]279-thinkpol ( [Thought Police]137-police ) it came first , and in the latter word [POLICE]137-police had lost its second syllable . Because of the great difficulty in securing euphony , irregu - lar formations were commoner in the B vocabulary than in the A vocabulary . For example , the adjective forms of MINITRUE , [MINIPAX]127-minipax , and [MINILUV]128-miniluv were , respectively , MINITRUTHFUL , [MINIPEACEFUL]280-minipeaceful , and [MINILOVELY]281-minilovely ,

8Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com simply because -TRUEFUL , -PAXFUL , and -LOVEFUL were slightly awkward to pronounce . In principle , however , all B words could inflect , and all inflected in exactly the same way . Some of the B words had highly subtilized meanings , barely intelligible to [anyone who had not mastered the language as a whole]3261-anyone who had not mastered the language as a whole . Consider , for example , such a typical sentence from a ‘ Times ’[165-oldspeak] leading article as [OLDTHINKERS UNBELLYFEEL INGSOC]145-ingsoc . The shortest rendering that [one]441-one could make of this in [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak would be : ‘ Those whose ideas were formed before the Revolution can not have a full emotional understanding of the principles of English So - cialism . ’[165-oldspeak] But this is not an adequate translation . To begin with , in order to grasp the full meaning of the Newspeak sentence quoted above , one would have to have a clear idea of what is meant by [INGSOC]145-ingsoc . And in addition , only [a per - son]3263-a per - son thoroughly grounded in [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc could appreciate the full force of the word BELLYFEEL , which implied a blind , enthusiastic acceptance difficult to imagine today ; or of the word OLDTHINK , which was inextricably mixed up with the idea of wickedness and decadence . But the special func - tion of certain Newspeak words , of which [OLDTHINK]282-oldthink was one , was not so much to express meanings as to [de - stroy]3264-de - stroy [them]3259-they . These words , necessarily few in number , had had [their]3259-they meanings extended until [they]3259-they contained within [themselves]3259-they whole batteries of words which , as [they]3259-they were sufficiently covered by a single comprehensive term , could now be scrapped and forgotten . The greatest difficulty fac - ing the compilers of the Newspeak Dictionary was not to

198484 invent new words , but , having invented [them]3259-they , to make sure what [they]3259-they meant : to make sure , that is to say , what ranges of words [they]3259-they cancelled by [their]3259-they existence . As [we]3265-we have already seen in the case of the word FREE , words which had once borne a heretical meaning were sometimes retained for the sake of convenience , but only with the undesirable meanings purged out of [them]3259-they . Count - less other words such as HONOUR , [JUSTICE]283-justice , MORALITY , INTERNATIONALISM , DEMOCRACY , SCIENCE , and RELIGION had simply ceased to exist . A few blanket words covered them , and , in covering [them]3259-they , abolished [them]3259-they . All words grouping [themselves]3259-they round the concepts of liber - ty and equality , for instance , were contained in the single word CRIMETHINK , while all words grouping [themselves]3259-they round the concepts of objectivity and rationalism were contained in the single word OLDTHINK . Greater preci - sion would have been dangerous . What was required in [a Party member]948-a party member was an outlook similar to that of [the ancient Hebrew who knew , without knowing much else]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else , that all na - tions other than [[his]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else own worshipped ‘ false gods]3949-his own worshipped ‘ false gods ’[3949-his own worshipped ‘ false gods] . [He]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else did not need to know that [these gods]3268-these gods were called [Baal]284-baal , [Osiris]285-osiris , [Moloch]286-moloch , [Ashtaroth]287-ashtaroth , and the like : probably the less [he]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else knew about [them]3268-these gods the better for [his]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else orthodoxy . [He]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else knew [Jehovah]288-jehovah and the commandments of [Jehovah]288-jehovah : [he]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else knew , therefore , that [all gods]3269-all gods with other names or other attributes were [false gods]3270-false gods . In somewhat the same way , [the party member]2576-the party member knew what constituted right conduct , and in exceedingly vague , generalized terms [he]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else knew what kinds of departure from it were possible . [His]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else sexual life , for example , was entirely

8Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com regulated by the two Newspeak words SEXCRIME ( sex - ual immorality ) and [GOODSEX]289-goodsex ( chastity ) . SEXCRIME covered all sexual misdeeds whatever . It covered fornica - tion , adultery , homosexuality , and other perversions , and , in addition , normal intercourse practised for its own sake . There was no need to enumerate [them]3269-all gods separately , since [they]3269-all gods were all equally culpable , and , in principle , all punishable by death . In the C vocabulary , which consisted of scientific and technical words , it might be necessary to give special - ized names to certain sexual aberrations , but [the ordinary citizen]3272-the ordinary citizen had no need of [them]3269-all gods . [He]3267-the ancient hebrew who knew , without knowing much else knew what was meant by [GOODSEX]289-goodsex — that is to say , normal intercourse between [man]904-man and [wife]3274-wife , for the sole purpose of [begetting children]3275-begetting children , and without physical pleasure on the part of [the woman]386-the woman : all else was [SEXCRIME]3277-sexcrime . In Newspeak it was seldom possible to follow a heretical thought further than the perception that it WAS heretical : beyond that point the necessary words were nonexistent . No word in the B vocabulary was ideologically neutral . A great many were euphemisms . Such words , for instance , as [JOYCAMP]290-joycamp ( forced - labour camp ) or [MINIPAX Minis]127-minipax - try of Peace , i.e. Ministry of War ) meant almost the exact opposite of what [they]3269-all gods appeared to mean . Some words , on the other hand , displayed a frank and contemptuous un - derstanding of the real nature of [Oceanic society]2496-oceanic society . An example was [PROLEFEED]3279-prolefeed , meaning the rubbishy enter - tainment and spurious news which [the Party]418-the party handed out to [the masses]2480-the masses . Other words , again , were ambivalent , hav - ing the connotation ‘ good ’[3279-prolefeed] when applied to the Party and

19848 ‘ bad ’[3279-prolefeed] when applied to [its]418-the party enemies . But in addition there were great numbers of words which at first sight appeared to be mere abbreviations and which derived [their]3269-all gods ideological co - lour not from [their]3269-all gods meaning , but from [their]3269-all gods structure . So far as it could be contrived , everything that had or might have political significance of any kind was fitted into the B vocabulary . The name of [every organization]3282-every organization , or body of [people]324-people , or doctrine , or [country]3284-country , or institution , or [public building]3285-public building , was invariably cut down into the familiar shape ; that is , a single easily pronounced word with the smallest number of syllables that would preserve the original deri - vation . In [the Ministry of Truth]329-the ministry of truth , for example , [the Records Department , in which [Winston Smith]132-winston worked]3287-the records department , in which winston smith worked , was called [RECDEP]291-recdep , [the Fiction Department]409-the fiction department was called [FICDEP]121-ficdep , [the Teleprogrammes Department]3289-the teleprogrammes department was called [TELEDEP]292-teledep , and so on . This was not done solely with the object of saving time . Even in the early decades of the twentieth century , tele - scoped words and phrases had been one of the characteristic features of political language ; and it had been noticed that the tendency to use abbreviations of this kind was most marked in totalitarian countries and totalitarian organi - zations . Examples were such words as NAZI , [GESTAPO]293-gestapo , COMINTERN , INPRECORR , [AGITPROP]294-agitprop . In the begin - ning the practice had been adopted as it were instinctively , but in [Newspeak]134-newspeak it was used with a conscious purpose . It was perceived that in thus abbreviating a name one nar - rowed and subtly altered its meaning , by cutting out most of the associations that would otherwise cling to it . The words [COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL]3290-communist international , for instance , call up

8Free eBooks at [Planet]12-planet eBook.com a composite picture of universal human brotherhood , red flags , barricades , [Karl Marx]295-karl marx , and the [Paris Commune]122-paris commune . The word COMINTERN , on the other hand , suggests merely a tightly - knit organization and a well - defined body of doc - trine . It refers to something almost as easily recognized , and as limited in purpose , as a chair or a table . [COMIN - TERN]296-comin - tern is a word that can be uttered almost without taking thought , whereas [COMMUNIST INTERNATIONAL]297-communist international is a phrase over which one is obliged to linger at least mo - mentarily . In the same way , the associations called up by a word like [MINITRUE]298-minitrue are fewer and more controllable than those called up by MINISTRY OF TRUTH . This accounted not only for the habit of abbreviating whenever possible , but also for the almost exaggerated care that was taken to make every word easily pronounceable . In [Newspeak]134-newspeak , euphony outweighed every consideration other than exactitude of meaning . Regularity of grammar was always sacrificed to it when it seemed necessary . And rightly so , since what was required , above all for political purposes , was short clipped words of unmistakable mean - ing which could be uttered rapidly and which roused the minimum of echoes in [the speaker]2148-the speaker ’s mind . The words of the B vocabulary even gained in force from the fact that nearly [all of [them]2483-all of them]2483-all of them were very much alike . Almost invariably these words — [GOODTHINK]299-goodthink , [MINIPAX]127-minipax , PROLEFEED , [SEX - CRIME]300-sex - crime , [JOYCAMP]290-joycamp , [INGSOC]145-ingsoc , [BELLYFEEL]301-bellyfeel , [THINKPOL]279-thinkpol , and countless others — were words of two or three syllables , with the stress distributed equally between the first syllable and the last . The use of [them]2483-all of them encouraged a gabbling style of

198488 speech , at once staccato and monotonous . And this was ex - actly what was aimed at . The intention was to make speech , and especially speech on any subject not ideologically neu - tral , as nearly as possible independent of consciousness . For the purposes of everyday life it was no doubt necessary , or sometimes necessary , to reflect before speaking , but [a Party member]948-a party member called upon to make [a political or ethical judge - ment]3294-a political or ethical judge - ment should be able to spray forth the correct opinions as automatically as a machine gun spraying forth bullets . [His]948-a party member training fitted [him]948-a party member to do this , the language gave [him]948-a party member an al - most foolproof instrument , and the texture of the words , with [their]2483-all of them harsh sound and a certain wilful ugliness which was in accord with the spirit of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc , assisted the process still further . So did the fact of having very few words to choose from . Relative to [our]3295-our own , the Newspeak vocabulary was tiny , and new ways of reducing it were constantly being devised . [Newspeak]134-newspeak , indeed , differed from most all other languages in that [its]134-newspeak vocabulary grew smaller instead of larger every year . Each reduction was a gain , since the smaller the area of choice , the smaller the temptation to take thought . [Ulti]302-ulti - mately it was hoped to make articulate speech issue from the larynx without involving the higher brain centres at all . This aim was frankly admitted in the Newspeak word [DUCKSPEAK]3296-duckspeak , meaning ‘ to quack like a duck ’[3296-duckspeak] . Like various other words in the B vocabulary , [DUCKSPEAK]169-duckspeak was ambiv - alent in meaning . Provided that the opinions which were quacked out were [orthodox ones]3297-orthodox ones , it implied nothing but praise , and when ‘ The Times ’[3296-duckspeak] referred to one of the orators

89Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com of [the Party]418-the party as a [DOUBLEPLUSGOOD DUCKSPEAKER]303-doubleplusgood duckspeaker [it]303-doubleplusgood duckspeaker was paying a warm and valued compliment . THE C VOCABULARY . The C vocabulary was supple - mentary to the others and consisted entirely of scientific and technical terms . These resembled the scientific terms in use today , and were constructed from the same roots , but the usual care was taken to define [them]2483-all of them rigidly and strip them of undesirable meanings . [They]2483-all of them followed the same grammatical rules as the words in [the other two vocabu - laries]3299-the other two vocabu - laries . Very few of the C words had any currency either in everyday speech or in political speech . Any scientific work - er or [technician]3300-technician could find all the words [he]3300-technician needed in the list devoted to [his]3300-technician own speciality , but [he]3300-technician seldom had more than a smattering of the words occurring in the other lists . Only a very few words were common to all lists , and there was no vocabulary expressing the function of Science as a habit of mind , or a method of thought , irrespective of its particular branches . There was , indeed , no word for ‘ Sci - ence ’[304-equal] , any meaning that it could possibly bear being already sufficiently covered by the word INGSOC . From the foregoing account it will be seen that in New - speak the expression of unorthodox opinions , above a very low level , was well - nigh impossible . It was of course pos - sible to utter heresies of a very crude kind , a species of blasphemy . It would have been possible , for example , to say [BIG BROTHER]126-big brother IS [UNGOOD]162-ungood . But this statement , which to [an orthodox ear]3301-an orthodox ear merely conveyed [a self - evident absur - dity]3302-a self - evident absur - dity , could not have been sustained by reasoned argument , because the necessary words were not available . Ideas inim -

198490 ical to [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc could only be entertained in a vague wordless form , and could only be named in very broad terms which lumped together and condemned [whole groups of heresies]3303-whole groups of heresies without defining [them]3303-whole groups of heresies in doing so . [One]441-one could , in fact , only use [Newspeak]134-newspeak for unorthodox purposes by illegitimately translating some of the words back into [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak . For ex - ample , ALL [MANS]271-mans ARE EQUAL was a possible Newspeak sentence , but only in the same sense in which [ALL MEN]3738-all men ARE REDHAIRED is a possible Oldspeak sentence . It did not contain a grammatical error , but it expressed a palpa - ble untruth — i.e. that all [men]593-men are of equal size , weight , or strength . The concept of political equality no longer existed , and this secondary meaning had accordingly been purged out of the word EQUAL . In 1984 , when [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak was still the normal means of communication , the danger theo - retically existed that in using [Newspeak]134-newspeak words one might remember [their]3303-whole groups of heresies original meanings . In practice it was not difficult for [any person well grounded in [DOUBLETHINK]220-doublethink]3307-any person well grounded in doublethink to avoid doing this , but within a couple of generations even the possibility of such a lapse would have vaished . [A per - son growing up with [Newspeak]134-newspeak as [his]134-newspeak sole language]3308-a per - son growing up with newspeak as his sole language would no more know that [EQUAL]304-equal had once had the second - ary meaning of ‘ politically equal ’[305-free] , or that [FREE]305-free had once meant ‘ intellectually free ’[None-None] , than for instance , [a person who had never heard of chess]3309-a person who had never heard of chess would be aware of the secondary meanings attaching to [QUEEN]306-queen and [ROOK]307-rook . There would be many crimes and errors which it would be beyond [his]3309-a person who had never heard of chess power to commit , simply because [they]3303-whole groups of heresies were nameless and therefore unimaginable . And it was to be foreseen that with

91Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com the passage of time the distinguishing characteristics of [Newspeak]134-newspeak would become more and more pronounced — its words growing fewer and fewer , [their]3303-whole groups of heresies meanings more and more rigid , and the chance of putting [them]3303-whole groups of heresies to improper uses always diminishing . When [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak had been once and for all superseded , the last link with the past would have been severed . History had already been rewritten , but fragments of the literature of the past survived here and there , imperfectly censored , and so long as [one]441-one retained one ’s knowledge of [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak it was possible to read [them]165-oldspeak . In the future such fragments , even if [they]165-oldspeak chanced to survive , would be unintelligible and untranslatable . It was impossible to translate any pas - sage of [Oldspeak]165-oldspeak into [Newspeak]134-newspeak unless it either referred to some technical process or some very simple everyday ac - tion , or was already orthodox ( GOODTHINKFUL would be the Newspeak expression ) in tendency . In practice this meant that no book written before approximately 1960 could be translated as a whole . Pre - revolutionary literature could only be subjected to ideological translation — that is , alteration in sense as well as language . Take for example the well - known passage from the Declaration of [Indepen -]123-indepen - dence : [WE]3311-we HOLD THESE TRUTHS TO BE SELF - EVIDENT , THAT [ALL MEN ARE CREATED EQUAL]3312-all men are created equal , THAT [THEY]3312-all men are created equal ARE ENDOWED BY [[THEIR]3312-all men are created equal CREATOR]3313-their creator WITH CERTAIN INALIENABLE RIGHTS , THAT AMONG THESE ARE LIFE , [LIBERTY]308-liberty , AND THE PURSUIT OF HAPPINESS .

19849 THAT TO SECURE THESE RIGHTS , [GOVERNMENTS ARE INSTITUTED AMONG MEN]3314-governments are instituted among men , [DERIVING]3315-deriving [THEIR]3314-governments are instituted among men POWERS FROM THE CONSENT OF THE GOVERNED . THAT WHENEVER ANY FORM OF GOVERNMENT BECOMES DESTRUCTIVE OF THOSE ENDS , IT IS THE RIGHT OF [THE PEOPLE]443-the people TO ALTER OR ABOLISH IT , AND TO [INSTITUTE NEW GOVERNMENT]3317-institute new government ... It would have been quite impossible to render this into [Newspeak]134-newspeak while keeping to the sense of the original . [The nearest one]3318-the nearest one could come to doing so would be to swallow the whole passage up in the single word CRIMETHINK . A full translation could only be an ideological translation , where - by [Jefferson]309-jefferson ’s words would be changed into a panegyric on absolute government . A good deal of the literature of the past was , indeed , al - ready being transformed in this way . Considerations of prestige made it desirable to preserve the memory of cer - tain historical figures , while at the same time bringing [their]3312-all men are created equal achievements into line with the philosophy of [Ingsoc]145-ingsoc . [Various writers]3319-various writers , such as [Shakespeare]167-shakespeare , [Milton]168-milton , [Swift]310-swift , [By - ron]3320-by - ron , [Dickens]311-dickens , and [some others]3321-some others were therefore in process of translation : when the task had been completed , [their]3321-some others orig - inal writings , with all else that survived of the literature of the past , would be destroyed . These translations were a slow and difficult business , and it was not expected that [they]3321-some others would be finished before the first or second decade of the twenty - first century . There were also large quantities of merely utilitarian literature — indispensable technical man -

9Free eBooks at Planet eBook.com uals , and the like — that had to be treated in the same way . It was chiefly in order to allow time for the preliminary work of translation that the final adoption of [Newspeak]134-newspeak had been fixed for so late a date as 2050 .
